One: A Transgender Woman‚Äôs Operatic Path to Markgraf & Sasha Cooke share the role of the transgender protagonist in ‚ÄòAs One‚Äô | Photo by Lynn Lane Often, as queer folks, our stories are told as reactions to those around us. \nComing out tales generally revolve around how that act is received by ________ [Fill in the blank: friends, family, religion, community, etc.] and the suspense is whether they will accept us. We‚Äôre just American Gladiators navigating an obstacle course of bigotry, bullying and rejection. In a theatrical or literary context, this makes some sense: Coming out provides conflict; it makes good drama.\nBut the brilliance of As One, the new chamber opera that had its world premiere this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is that the drama is (mostly) internal. With only one character, Hannah, that choice allows for a complex and nuanced portrayal of the coming out experience on stage. There are no ‚Äúthere‚Äôs something I have to tell you‚Äù scenes, no dramatization of strained relationships. Hannah doesn‚Äôt have to justify her identity to the outside world. Instead, drama is wrung from the obstacle course within, where she must scale mountains of confusion, transverse gulfs of isolation and dodge bullets of self-doubt.\nThe story of Hannah is inspired in part by the story of Kimberly Reed, a filmmaker and Out100 honoree, whose 2008 documPresented by American Opera Projects. Photo by Ken Howardentary Prodigal Sons explored her transition from male to female and the strained relationship with her adopted brother. Reed is a co-librettist here, sharing the writing credit with Mark Campbell. The simplicity of their language gives the opera a stream-of-consciousness ease and accessibility; they prefer small, sometimes humorous, personal observations to the sweeping pronouncements often favored by opera It worries me because I value control and with hrt I have to trust. I have to place my trust in a second puberty when the first was for all purposes disfiguring. I would hope that the second would be relieving and rid me of my dysphoria or at least some of it. But I don‚Äôt know. Will I see the dramatic results that some of my trans sisters have seen? I don‚Äôt know. Will it help the world see me as the woman I am or will it leave me in some middle state? I don‚Äôt know. Will it be able to do enough to ‚Äúfix‚Äù the damage that testosterone has done? I don‚Äôt know. I hate the fact that all the hrt guides and knowledge bases have told me everything that wont change and all the rest is ‚Äúymmv‚Äù aka good luck. I get why that is necessary but still it doesn‚Äôt help a mind that worries. Also the guides and advice and knowledge is all over the place. No two sources agree on everything. \n\nAlso I have been told 1000 times that I shouldn‚Äôt care if I pass or not, but I do. I am not hoping to be a super model. Hell I don‚Äôt even care if I am ‚Äúattractive.‚Äù I just hope hrt lets me live the rest of my life as an ordinary woman. I only care that I can be treated like a woman and more over a person. I just want to be another face in the crowd. Another woman on her way to work or out for a stroll. I am scared that I wont pass and will be forever treated as a monster or something to be mocked, ridiculed and disgusted of.\n\nBut what scares me the most is that I am going through with it. Because it feels like my only option. I have wanted this for as long as I knew it was a thing. Since I was in 8th grade and I was holding that birth control pill and I knew it had hormones in it and all I could think was maybe it would make me a girl. I knew then. I knew before then. I knew after then. I know now. I just hope I‚Äôm not too late. I know its never too late to live an honest life but I just hope I can right this ship and still have a life. I have to trust in the hrt. I have to trust in people. I have to trust in my family. And I am going to have to trust myself. I‚Äôm going to have to trust. A lot. And that is scary to I know you didn‚Äôt understand why I didn‚Äôt feed you when all you were trying to do was keep me alive, I know that after twenty-one years I should have learned your language by now. We never really harmonized, I guess I tend to forget that you feel my pain, too. \n\nDear Sarah,\n\nI‚Äôm trying to forgive you for being the daughter my parents always wanted. I‚Äôm learning that taking care of myself means taking care of you, too. sexuality in Gendered Worlds. The word ‚Äúhomophobia‚Äù was coined in 1972, when George Weinberg was trying to figure out what had happened during the nazi regime. A man (if you can call him that) named Heinrich Himmler hated gay men and had over 100 thousand gay men arrested, half of which were imprisoned with many going to concentration camps. Gay men and suspected gay men even had to wear special arm bands with a pink triangle on it. It is believed Himmler hated gay men because he thought they were weak and ‚Äúlike women‚Äù and would ruin the ‚ÄúAryan‚Äù race. So Weinberg used the term ‚Äúhomophobia‚Äù to describe this and described it as being an actual fear of being ‚Äúgay‚Äù by the very fact that you associated with gay men, ‚Äúfear of contagion‚Äù, that maybe you could ‚Äúcatch‚Äù the gay. Basically, it‚Äôs more a fear that your masculinity would be questioned, rather than a legitimate fear of actual gay men individually. Anyway, it‚Äôs now (well, and then obviously but they didn‚Äôt use the term as loosely as we do now) used as a justification of acting like a dickhead and used to explain why someone would commit a hate crime. It‚Äôs not an excuse and I‚Äôm just sharing this because I think the origins of where these words and expressions we use today came from are fascinating. But regardless and in conclusion, this quote still holds true, you are a complete asshole if you think your masculinity, or femininity, would be in question if you just let people of another sexuality than you just live their life the way they see fit.","image_permalink":"http://redheadtalkinginallcaps.tumblr.com/image/97520556196","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":500,"height":750,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":600,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":375,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":150,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":500,"height":750,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_500.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"vanquishedvaliant","id":97520417184,"post_url":"http://vanquishedvaliant.tumblr.com/post/97520417184/i-had-someone-come-and-tell-me-today-that-id","slug":"i-had-someone-come-and-tell-me-today-that-id","type":"text","date":"2014-09-15 00:07:52 GMT","timestamp":1410739672,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"o6d651h3","tags":["Kaptains Log","trans","trans*","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZZFZzw1QqgtcW","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"title":"","body":"I had someone come and tell me today that I‚Äôd inspired them and helped them realize that they were trans. I mean\n\nI came across two terms that described what I was feeling. Trans-attraction and trans-orientation. Neither one is official or common, but their use is growing due to the increasing demand for a way to categorize people who are attracted to transgender people.\n\nhow\n\nI don‚Äôt always describe myself as trans-attracted, but the label helped me feel like I had a place in the queer community and it helps others understand my sexuality.\n\ncan I\n\nSo why bother coming out? It holds exclusive attraction to cis people as the norm, not addressing it for what it is‚Äîtransphobia. Thankyou x","answer":"I can see how that would be tricky! Honestly, it‚Äôs probably going to be a lot of the same things you went through, but in a different way. Lots of introspection and self examination - would they feel more comfortable using male pronouns? Do the labels ‚Äúgirl/woman/female‚Äù make them uncomfortable/do they not really associate with them? Something I found that helped was looking into a mirror and saying ‚ÄúI am a girl‚Äù, ‚ÄúI am a boy‚Äù and ‚ÄúI am not a girl or a boy‚Äù and seeing what I felt most comfortable with.\n\nGender is really complex. ‚ÄúMale identity‚Äù is still something I‚Äôm learning about. I‚Äôm still figuring out how to express my masculinity in ways I‚Äôm completely comfortable with. Because there isn‚Äôt just one way to be male. People associate masculinity and manliness with many different things, especially as you move into the trans community. So encourage them to educate themselves, and consider what masculinity means to them. They‚Äôre the only ones who can really know their gender, after all.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"castielwnchster","id":97505534401,"post_url":"http://castielwnchster.tumblr.com/post/97505534401/wwyd-if-you-thought-you-started-falling-4-a-girl-but","slug":"wwyd-if-you-thought-you-started-falling-4-a-girl-but","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-14 20:59:00 GMT","timestamp":1410728340,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"oyyWiiE5","tags":["replies","trans","anon"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zf1nPx1Qpo671","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"wwyd if you thought you started falling 4 a girl but then she started transitioning like to a guy ahh thoughts and feelings are cheesing crazy dude. also sweet blog, man.","answer":"i don‚Äôt think it‚Äôd change anything (in my case, anyways)\n\nin fact i hope that i might try to help out :)\n\nit might seem strange at first but keep an open mind and try to understand her/his situation - in the process, you might discover whether your feelings have strengthened, stayed the same, or perhaps gone.\n\nand yea thoughts and feelings are crazy, i feel ya OwO\n\nalso - abt my blog - thank you!! xx","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"amazoniantranswomaninthemood","id":97505469964,"post_url":"http://amazoniantranswomaninthemood.tumblr.com/post/97505469964/2-years-ago-today-i-was-in-hospital-for-self-harm","slug":"2-years-ago-today-i-was-in-hospital-for-self-harm","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-14 20:58:00 GMT","timestamp":1410728280,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"uIwKceMw","tags":["trans","mtf","transition"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZRs-Wn1QpnsOC","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"caption":"2 Years ago today i was in hospital for self harm and a half assed suicide attempt. So I guess I do it as a way to cope with the dysphoria of not passing because when I don‚Äôt past I feel like I need to change something. And the thing that I can change all the time is my hair.","photoset_layout":"2","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_1280.jpg"},{"width":422,"height":750,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_500.jpg"},{"width":338,"height":600,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_400.jpg"},{"width":225,"height":400,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":178,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_1280.jpg"}},{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_1280.jpg"},{"width":422,"height":750,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_500.jpg"},{"width":338,"height":600,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_400.jpg"},{"width":225,"height":400,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":178,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_1280.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"girlwhocriedsupernova","id":97500584442,"post_url":"http://girlwhocriedsupernova.tumblr.com/post/97500584442/hrt","slug":"hrt","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 20:02:03 GMT","timestamp":1410724923,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"6WNvRKD1","tags":["gender","trans","o"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZiDNks1QpVDdw","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":5,"title":"HRT","body":"I think that there are a lot of experiences that trans women, transfeminine people, and generally AMAB trans people have in common, that we largely don‚Äôt know about because we don‚Äôt talk about them. With that in mind, therefore, I would like to share my experiences with deciding whether to start hormone replacement therapy, which I did, in hopes that it will be helpful to someone out there.\n\nFor those who don‚Äôt know, HRT is the process of replacing or supplementing the hormones naturally produced by your body, particularly the sex hormones (testosterone/androgens, estrogen, progesterone, etc.). It is used to treat both cis and trans people, and in trans people it is used to trigger a second puberty in order to relieve dysphoria.\n\nWhen I first figured out that I was trans, I didn‚Äôt think I would seek HRT or any other medical transition treatment. It‚Äôs just a body, I reasoned. It‚Äôs not me, I just happen to live inside of it, so who cares what it looks like. That is an incredibly unhealthy attitude, but one which I had necessarily developed as a child in order to protect myself from dysphoria.\n\nAs I continued processing things, however, I began to change my mind. I discovered that just as I had erected mental walls to protect myself from fully experiencing social dysphoria, I had erected even taller, thicker walls to protect myself from my body. These walls had been very effective, but I immediately started poking at them (trying to actually see myself when looking in the mirror, for instance). Bad idea.\n\nSo I figured out pretty quickly that I was interested in HRT, but I was still very apprehensive about it. It felt like a very permanent thing, and I was very scared about making a choice that I might later regret. On the other hand, I might also regret the choice to delay any longer, because I was almost 25 and bodies age differently according to what hormones are in them.\n\nAt this point, I would like to break to tell you some fun facts about sex hormones:\n\nBoth testosterone and estrogen have permanent effects during ‚Äúfirst‚Äù puberty, such as affecting bone structure.\nTestosterone has permanent effects whenever in life it is started (facial hair, deepening voice).\nEstrogen has practically no permanent effects when started post-puberty. The only two things it does that cannot be undone by switching back to testosterone are breast development (which can be partially undone, but requires surgery to be fully undone; doesn‚Äôt even start for a month or two, isn‚Äôt noticeable for closer to sixish months) and infertility (that is, for people with testes, not for people with ovaries, obviously; declines gradually, usually gone after a year, maybe less)\nAll of this creates double-edged sword for AMAB trans folks: hormones alone cannot undo some of the things we might be dysphoric about (although I promise there are other means for dealing with the hair and the voice, it‚Äôs just more work); however trying HRT is relatively risk-free for us.\n\nMy therapist told me that many trans women who are not totally sure about HRT just try it for a little, and use that as a test to see if they are comfortable, knowing that they can stop and turn around at any time. For most cis men, HRT will likely make you feel depressed - for most dysphoric trans women it will make you feel less depressed. Obviously this is not universal, but it means you can try HRT for a little bit and see how you feel as a test for whether it might help you to be on it, which is what I did.\n\nThe first physical effects you are supposed to notice are softer skin and thinner body hair. For me, however, the first thing that happened was that I felt dramatically less anxious - like in a week or two, there was a dramatic effect. I still deal with anxiety on the regular, but the only times it goes back to what it was like before are when I forget to take my hormones! Which is pretty good affirmation for me, that I made the right decision.\n\nSo I felt pretty good, and I therefore never made the decision to stop HRT. I did have one crisis about it that lasted for a few days. I think this happened after three or four months on estrogen. One night in bed, I was lying there thinking, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to have boobs now. That‚Äôs just how it‚Äôs going to be from now on and soon enough there will be more or less no going back.‚Äù I was very dysphoric about not having breasts my whole life, like my upper torso felt this strange emptiness, but I think the permanence of it really got to me, because I had never had breasts before and now I was just going to choose to have them forevermore. Change is scary I guess. I talked it over with a couple friends and my therapist and realized that even though it was scary it was what I needed.\n\nAnyway, it‚Äôs been about 22 months since I started HRT and about 16 months since I‚Äôve been on a full, stable dose/had my hormone levels in the medically designated ‚Äúfemale‚Äù range. It was absolutely the right decision for me. My body is definitely not the body I would have chosen, if I could choose what my body would look like, but it is definitely a body I can live in and often be present in, none of which I could have said two years ago ago.\n\nI would encourage anyone considering this to talk to a good gender specialist about this, if you are able to (what constitutes a ‚Äúgood‚Äù gender therapist is a whole ‚Äònother story, and maybe I or someone else can make a post about that sometime - you may or may not have access to one depending on health care coverage and where you live), and maybe try it for a couple weeks to see how you feel (again, if you are able to do that - access to health care, especially what is deemed ‚Äútrans‚Äù health care is very spotty almost everywhere, so you may need help trying to navigate that labyrinth as well). I am 100% always open for questions from trans or questioning people about this topic.\n\nGo in peace and be well and remember to love yourselves as much as you can manage, and if you can‚Äôt manage, find some friends to do it for you.\n\nReblogs are encouraged on this post if you think it will help your followers.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"helloiammaggie","id":97500400192,"post_url":"http://helloiammaggie.tumblr.com/post/97500400192/lazy-sunday-selfies","slug":"lazy-sunday-selfies","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-14 am Transgender\n\nAllyson Robinson at TEDx Nightingale Bamford School:\n\nI set out on this journey to become the person, the woman that I had always known myself to be, not to become transgender. I mean, who wants to identify with a medical condition, right? Who would willingly embrace a label that brings with it such fear and such loathing? [‚Ä¶] Because of it I shook with fear under barrages of slurs and threats hurled at me by strangers on the street. I shuddered in pain under needles and scalpels as my body was remade to affirm the image of myself that was imprinted on my mind.\n\n  Somewhere along the journey, something changed: Despite all of the pain and travail, I grew not only to accept my journey, but to treasure it. Today I am accepted by the world without question as the woman I am and have indeed always been and I no longer have to wear a maligned and misunderstood medical condition as my identity. And yet today I choose to.\n\n Today I say it with pride: I am transgender. And with no small amount of gratitude either. Because today I see it as one of the greatest gifts that I have ever received. I am thankful that I am transgender because being trans has shown me that there were other perspectives, other ways of viewing and experiencing the World that were just as valid as my own, maybe even more so.\n\nAllyson Robinson was recently ordained a Baptist Come & experience for yourself.\n\nIf you require any further information regarding this email or the group itself please contact us on 0208¬†509¬†3898 or email us info@elop.org","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"nbselfielove","id":97489179093,"post_url":"http://nbselfielove.tumblr.com/post/97489179093/ive-never-felt-like-a-girl-but-i-have-a-girls-body","slug":"ive-never-felt-like-a-girl-but-i-have-a-girls-body","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-14 17:45:35 GMT","timestamp":1410716735,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"f2eGHs5p","tags":["gender neutral","genderfluid","dyshporia","trans","trans masculine","genitalia mention","misogyny mention","problematic language","Anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZpReno1Qopj7L","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":10,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"I've never felt like a girl but I have a girls body which is ok. (Although there is some penis envy but mostly cos you can play WAY more with it. Like even have fun while peeing..!) If someone asked what gender I feel like inside \"neither\" would probably be most accurate, but i usually feel more masculine/not girl when around other girls. Genderneutral sounds right to me cos spirit isn't gender but can you explain the difference between that and genderfluid?","answer":"I do love questions!\n\nOne thing to keep in mind is that the definitions of gender aren‚Äôt all-inclusive things set in stone. There‚Äôs no one right way to be any gender (or lack of gender).\n\nBut I am comfortable speaking in generalities. In general, genderfluid people are more than one gender, and that gender changes. It can change from day to day, or throughout the day, or over the course of a longer period of time. For example, I‚Äôm genderfluid. Sometimes I‚Äôm a girl, sometimes demiboy, sometimes androgyne, sometimes agender. Some people shift between male and female, or female and agender, or any other combination of genders. Genderfluid people may also be more than one gender at any given time, but the ‚Äúfluid‚Äù part suggests that there are changes involved over time.\n\nFrom what I have seen, people who are gender neutral do not all agree on what that means as a gender identity. Some say it is a lack of gender. Some don‚Äôt really feel it‚Äôs a gender identity, but a gender presentation: a way to look and act that doesn‚Äôt identify you as any specific gender. Maybe some folks who identify as gender neutral can chime in with their experiences? \n\nA couple of things to keep in mind when you‚Äôre talking about gender: if you‚Äôre not a girl then you don‚Äôt have a girl‚Äôs body. There are men and non-binary people who have vaginas, breasts, etc. If you want to specify what gender the doctors and your parents picked for you, you can say you were assigned female at birth (AFAB) or designated female at birth (DFAB). \n\nAnother word that you may find helpful is trans masculine. Trans masculine people are AFAB folks who identify as at least somewhat masculine.\n\nAs you share experiences with being trans, people are going to bring up dysphoria. In the most general terms, dysphoria is simply knowing that you‚Äôre a different gender than you were assigned at birth. But it can also be used to talk more specifically about things like ‚Äúpenis envy.‚Äù If you feel you would be happier with a penis and/or you experience distress because you don‚Äôt have one, then that can be described as sex dyshporia. Being uncomfortable with being identified as female by other people (like when they use the wrong pronouns for you) is often called social dysphoria. (ps, be aware that the concept of ‚Äúpenis envy‚Äù is rooted in misogyny).\n\nIgnore anyone who tells you that dyshporia is required to be trans, because they don‚Äôt understand what dyshpria actually is, and they distort the meaning of it in order to exclude people they don‚Äôt like.\n\nA final note, to hopefully ward off the kind of people who make a fuss about this: there are folks out there who will tell you that gender neutral is not a gender identity, that it just refers to presentation. But they‚Äôre wrong. There are people who identify as gender neutral, and there‚Äôs nothing wrong with that. If it is right for you, that‚Äôs what‚Äôs important.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ineffablyfebruary","id":97488187337,"post_url":"http://ineffablyfebruary.tumblr.com/post/97488187337/morning","slug":"morning","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-14 Any suggestions on fashion, buying underwear and finding good sizes?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"an-andreja-pejic-blog","id":97477588983,"post_url":"http://an-andreja-pejic-blog.tumblr.com/post/97477588983/how-andreja-pejic-fashioned-her-own-version-of","slug":"how-andreja-pejic-fashioned-her-own-version-of","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 15:18:11 GMT","timestamp":1410707891,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"5i2A2TSX","tags":["andreja pejic","andrejapejic","buzzfeed","ashley c ford","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z8g7tu1Qo7VVt","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":21,"source_url":"http://www.buzzfeed.com/ashleyford/how-andreja-pejic-fashioned-her-own-version-of-womanhood#2ifgujn","source_title":"BuzzFeed","title":"How Andreja Pejiƒá Fashioned Her Own Version Of Womanhood","body":"By Ashley C. Ford \n\nWhen she was 13 years old, Andreja Pejiƒá googled the word ‚Äútransitioning.‚Äù Puberty was approaching, and she was loathe to see her body grow into something even further away from what she wanted to see in the mirror. Google helped her find the answers she needed. ‚ÄúI discovered it was a national community, and there were doctors, and medical help. It wasn‚Äôt something ‚Äòfreaky‚Äô or ‚Äòbizarre‚Äô; there was a system.‚Äù She describes herself as a ‚Äúgeeky boy‚Äù eager to become physically female.\n\nThe visual of a ‚Äúgeeky boy‚Äù is hard to reconcile with the ethereal supermodel we see draped in couture fashions today. Known for her ability to conquer the runway dressed as a man or woman, androgyny has been her schtick since Andreja was known as Andrej. In 2011, New York magazine named Pejiƒá ‚ÄúThe Prettiest Boy in the World,‚Äù a title Pejiƒá wasn‚Äôt altogether comfortable with. ‚ÄúThe plan was to enjoy modeling, then get out, and transition. The more and more known I became, the harder that goal was. The whole world already knew me.‚Äù\n\nWell before the world knew her name, Pejiƒá lived with her family in a Serbian refugee camp. Despite their living conditions, she describes her childhood as carefree. ‚ÄúI remember playing in the street a lot. I adored South American soap operas and pretending to speak Spanish. I had a happy childhood, but not a lot of material things.‚Äù Pejiƒá‚Äôs mother, Jadranka Saviƒá, had been formally educated as a lawyer, but took a series of a rural jobs to support her children, Andreja, and her brother Igor. Pejiƒá‚Äôs parents were divorced, and even with the help of her own mother, Jadranka found it difficult to provide for her family.\n\n‚ÄúI think my mom and grandma struggled a lot to provide for us. There were almost no jobs. We could barely afford honey.‚Äù\n\nOnce the family immigrated to Australia, they found slightly less financial hardship, but now had to deal with assimilating. At 9 years old, Pejiƒá did not blend into her new surroundings seamlessly. ‚ÄúI was a very shy child. I was learning how to navigate a different world in several ways: a whole new language, a whole new culture. It was very different from European culture. Even things as simple as asking your grandmother to pack you a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, instead of a lasagna. I did that just so I could fit in with the other Australian kids.‚Äù\n\nWhat Pejiƒá found hardest to assimilate to in her new surrounding wasn‚Äôt the culinary fare, but gendered expectations she was reluctant to take on. ‚ÄúI could no longer get away with playing with dolls. I had to integrate into a boy. In order to not be bullied, and not be seen as weird, and not be an outsider. I learned how to behave like a boy and suppress my natural characteristics, the way I walked and the way I talked. It was just about getting through the day without too much trouble. It wasn‚Äôt the best time in my life.‚Äù\n\nPejiƒá believes she survived this particular time in her life due to a rich fantasy life inside her own head. ‚ÄúI was saved by my imagination. I would imagine what it would be like to go shopping with my mother as a girl. Some would say these were really mundane things, but I would dream about what life would be like as a girl, and it made me very happy.‚Äù\n\nPejiƒá‚Äôs decision to transition was not as sudden as it seemed. She‚Äôs been transitioning since she was 13 years old. ‚ÄúI ordered medication online, saw doctors, and I came out to my mom. Once I had the support of my family, I had more confidence. Then, I started going to a liberal high school.‚Äù It was at University High that Pejiƒá first embraced an androgynous identity. ‚ÄúAndrogyny became a way of expressing my femininity, being pretty, and wearing girly clothing or unisex clothing. I didn‚Äôt have to explain things about gender identity, sexuality, or genetics. It didn‚Äôt have to go that deep and I felt like my peers wouldn‚Äôt understand what it means to be trans.‚Äù\n\nStill, it was her androgynous look that first got her noticed in the fashion industry, and ultimately catapulted her into a career as one of the most sought-after high fashion models, something Pejiƒá says she never saw coming. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt expect to become famous. I didn‚Äôt expect to have the career that I have. I became kind of a poster child for androgyny. In the beginning I wasn‚Äôt ready to talk about wanting to transition or my internal feelings about gender dysmorphia, because it‚Äôs one thing to come out to your mom; it‚Äôs another to come out to the public.‚Äù\n\nPejiƒá notes the intensely image-conscious fashion community as just one of the reasons she didn‚Äôt initially come out as trans. Despite her involvement in the community, few knew about her desire to transition. ‚ÄúSome people were very supportive and some people thought I would lose something, that I would no longer be special. I‚Äôm still the same person with the same ideas. But I had to do it for myself. I couldn‚Äôt worry about doing it for anyone else.‚Äù So how did she get to the point where she felt safe to tell the world she was a woman, and have the surgery she‚Äôd wanted since she was 13? ‚ÄúAt the beginning of last year, I sat myself down and stared in the mirror and said, ‚ÄòDo you want to spend the rest of your life wondering what it would be like to feel completely comfortable in your own body?‚Äô‚Äù\n\nPejiƒá felt she was at a place where she had a lot to lose if her industry would not accept her as a trans woman. While recognizing this could be true, Pejiƒá decided she didn‚Äôt care. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt let your career decide anymore when you‚Äôre going to do this. If I didn‚Äôt do it then, I wouldn‚Äôt have done it. I would have put it off for way too long, and I would be miserable. There was a need. A constant internal need. It was always there.‚Äù\n\nNearly 10 years after searching Google for a way out of her body, Pejiƒá decided to have sexual reassignment surgery. She slowly let her close friends know what she was planning to do and received their loving support. One friend, filmmaker Eric Miclette, went even further than support and immediately encouraged Pejiƒá to film the process of her transitioning. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve worked on small projects before, and when I said, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going in for SRS in a few weeks,‚Äô he said, ‚ÄòYou need to get some footage. You have one chance and you need to tell your story.‚Äô‚Äù\n\nAt first, Pejiƒá was reluctant. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt say that I wanted to capture that or that having a camera around was the way I dreamt of it being. It was a very personal thing and I wanted it to keep it that way. I‚Äôm a very private person, and yes, very shy. It wasn‚Äôt my dream to have a camera there. But he really changed my mind about that. He asked me to think about the people who‚Äôve had to hide their whole lives and who will find inspiration because you decided to go public with this.‚Äù They decided to collaborate on an intimate documentary, with Pejiƒá insisting she didn‚Äôt want a lot of cameras involved, just Miclette.\n\nFor his own part, Miclette asked for access into the model‚Äôs life, past and present, though neither of them wanted the documentary to be a ‚Äúvanity project.‚Äù In their commitment to this shared goal, Pejiƒá is in no way involved in the film except as its focus. ‚ÄúI remain a subject of the documentary. I‚Äôm not a producer or a director. I think in order to create a critical work, an objective work, I needed to be a subject with no creative influence. I had to show the true me, and allow [Miclette] into my life completely, and not worry about looking good all the time or saying the right thing. I had to let go of all of that.‚Äù\n\nFor now, Andrej(a) is still in production with a Kickstarter campaign that has already raised over $25,000 to see it come to fruition as a distributable film. Since the launch of the campaign, Pejiƒá has been most excited to see messages and mail from the people she believes need to see this film most. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been getting all kinds of incredible messages, many of them from parents. I think parents are a big target for this because I was lucky to have a family, and to have their support. Too many kids in the LGBT community are being abandoned. It‚Äôs not right. Everyone should have their parents‚Äô support. I hope this film brings parents understanding.‚Äù\nPejiƒá says that while her mother was supportive, she was also concerned about the quality of life her child could expect to lead as a trans woman, something her daughter worried about as well. Ultimately, it was the desire for a life lived most authentically that gave Pejiƒá the confidence she needed to ‚Äúfeel comfortable in her own skin.‚Äù That happiness is something she thinks all parents want for their children, and something more trans folks can have access to with more understanding. She said, ‚ÄúTransitioning isn‚Äôt just physical, it‚Äôs also social. It‚Äôs not enough to just change your looks and your body; you also have a need to be accepted by society and the people around you in the gender role that you feel you are. I definitely feel like I‚Äôm more comfortable. I feel like I can live the life of being a girl I‚Äôve always wanted.‚Äù\n\nFrom BuzzFeed","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"shemail-delivery","id":97477373503,"post_url":"http://shemail-delivery.tumblr.com/post/97477373503/um-so-i-ordered-a-m-sized-binder-and-it-doesnt-do","slug":"um-so-i-ordered-a-m-sized-binder-and-it-doesnt-do","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 15:15:00 GMT","timestamp":1410707700,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"LJQpEhIS","tags":["underworks","binder","ftm","trans","chest binder"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z_D5yp1Qo6gu-","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"Um so I ordered a M sized binder and it doesn't do shit??","body":"I figured since I‚Äôm a 36-38¬†C/D (sometimes) that M would be the correct size, well it didn‚Äôt do shit and I‚Äôm pretty upset. My brother loves to throw shade.‚Äù\n\nThe conversation between Cox and Lamar was the kickoff event of Baruch College‚Äôs weeklong GenderFluid festival. Running through Sept. 13, this week of binary-challenging performances and events is organized by Spin Cycle NYC. It celebrates trans and genderfluid artists and features the legendary gender outlaw Kate Bornstein, Holly Woodlawn and more. When Cox and Lamar took to the stage, Lamar quipped a bit about literal ‚Äúgender fluids‚Äù such as the many fluids men and women could secrete.\n\nCox took a slightly more serious approach to introducing the topic after Lamar talked about how people don‚Äôt see him in the light of stereotypical black masculinity. ‚ÄúGender isn‚Äôt something anyone should decide for you,‚Äù said Cox. ‚ÄúWe need to live in and out of our own terms of gender.‚Äù\n\nThe evening often played out in this sort of debate. Lamar, for instance, was more critical of mainstream corporate culture during the discussion, while Cox advocated for the other side. Lamar even went so far as to criticize his sister‚Äôs claim to fame, Orange is the New Black, saying he is not interested in black roles written by white people.\n\n‚ÄúMy job is not to judge the material,‚Äù said Cox. She went on to say that her main efforts are put towards bringing humanity and her personal interpretation to all her work. She continued, saying she has really enjoyed everything that OITNB has done for women.\n\nLamar, further fueling apropos discussion with his sister, called into question her potential tokenism, feeling that Hollywood may assume it has fulfilled its black, trans woman quota.\n\nCox responded with a quote by Sidney Poitier, who himself felt that black people didn‚Äôt overcome with his winning the Oscar because he was the only one. She feels like it‚Äôs her job, while she has this time in the spotlight, to push other trans women forward and to continue to discuss the death rates and mistreatment of trans women of color, which, statistically, is more than other members of the LBGT community.\n\nLamar applauded his sister‚Äôs efforts.\n\nThings got a bit emotional for Cox when the two began to talk about their upbringing. Lamar hasn‚Äôt spoken to his mother in 15 years. Though the two had different opinions about their alleged familial trauma, Cox articulated that some topics are hard to discuss, but there is such a need to push through, without feeling judged, in order to create safer spaces for people to talk through their trauma. Vulnerability is necessary for connection.\n\n‚ÄúWhen we begin to connect with people, healing happens,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúReal love starts with [the] self. After that, we can really love each other. confused","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"awkwardtransboy","id":97464152156,"post_url":"http://awkwardtransboy.tumblr.com/post/97464152156/what-is-the-best-binder-for-someone-with-a-size-c","slug":"what-is-the-best-binder-for-someone-with-a-size-c","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-14 11:16:49 GMT","timestamp":1410693409,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"uNEe1GFy","tags":["trans","binding","afab trans","resources","chest binding","Anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZCXAjn1QnKF1S","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"What is the best binder for someone with a size C chest?","answer":"it really depends on what type of c you are! your size depends both on strap length and cup size. like a 34B and a 32C have the same cup volume but different strap lengths. and a 32D has the same cup volume as a 34C, but the smaller number means smaller strap lengths, so they fit differently. if you have a bigger cup volume, you‚Äôll have to go bigger with the binder size\n\ni was a 34C before i started T and afterwards my size actually reduced a little bit, which was nice but ofc i had surgery anyways cause i still had significant breast tissue. \n\nmy preferred type of binder is velcro short ones, because they bind well but also you can loosen / tighten them easily. i used these two different kinds for most of my binding needs, and they worked great. \n\nwhen binding, it‚Äôs important that you find a binder that fits you well, and that doesnt impair your breathing. remember that you shouldnt wear it for extended periods of time, and if you have to wear it continuously, go into a bathroom or something to take like 5 minute binderless breaks every once in a while. binding can be dangerous. also, never sleep with your binder on!!!\n\nu could bruise or break your ribs or develop breathing problems if you bind too tight or for too long. so please be careful. \n\nlesloveboat is my favourite site for trans related stuff cause they have so many options in terms of binders, including binding swimwear. and they also have lots of resources for packing and scar treatment after surgery. basically theyve got it all! definitely check it Rain","url":"http://www.advocate.com/politics/transgender/2014/09/13/watch-meet-trailblazing-two-spirit-performer-iceis-rain","link_image":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbv59kG8jC1qb6re5_og.jpg","description":"ICEIS Rain is opening doors for indigenous gender-nonconforming artists, reports Canada‚Äôs CBC News. This week, the entertainer ‚Äî who identifies as both female and male ‚Äî became the first two-spirit person to perform at the Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Awards.\n\nICEIS Rain is also Massey Whiteknife, a 35-year-old member of the Mikisew Cree First Nation, who identifies as as a man sometimes and as Rain, a woman, at other times. Being two-spirit, he explains to CBC, means ‚Äúyou have accepted both your masculinity and femininity and you embrace both your spirits.‚Äù\n\n‚ÄúTwo-spirit\" is an identification used by some First Nations people to describe their nonbinary gender identity. Some consider it most closely synonymous with the Western concept of \"bi-gender\" people and include it in the \"transgender umbrella\" of identifiers. Other sources, such as the CBC report below, equate \"being two-spirited\" with being \"gay.\" The term, however, is not exactly equivalent to either \"transgender\" and/or \"gay.\"\n\nFor Whiteknife, living his two-spirit identity means that, by day, he is a gay male business owner in the sub-arctic Alberta oil sands. At night, she is ICEIS Rain, a female karaoke performer. Whiteknife and Rain share the same body, he explained to CBC, but each has their own passions and pursuits.\n\nAs Rain, she gained notoriety last year as a featured performer in the documentary Oil Sands Karaoke, and is working on a singing career. As Whiteknife, he gained accolades as a business tycoon, building up several oil sands-based businesses very quickly into a multi-million dollar operation.\n\nWhiteknife says Rain, as his formidable, ‚Äúqueen‚Äù-like second spirit, helped him overcome childhood sexual abuse, bullying, and gang rape to become highly admired in both his careers as a businessman and as an entertainer.\n\nRain, who is known for her anti-bullying anthem, ‚ÄúThe Queen,‚Äù has now been nominated for two Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Awards. Whiteknife tells CBC he is humbled by the attention and to be the first two-spirit person to take the award ceremony‚Äôs performance stage.\n\n\"I don‚Äôt even have the words to express the emotions,\" he added. \"I‚Äôm overwhelmed, I‚Äôm honored.\"","can_reply":false}]

would realise the big mistake and everyone will notice how obvious it has been that i‚Äôm really male!\nI mean i‚Äôve been thinking this since i was a little kid. Even like bathing and looking at lower body parts I was sure they were not female parts, that doctors and parents were just mistaken.\n\n It‚Äôs so weird to think about, i mean, once puberty hit it was like, oh, i have those inside bits. I was always like maybe, just maybe i had the correct parts (for me) all along hidden inside! like when you hear of testicles not descending in fetal stages and such. \n\n Even now, i think, well, maybe i have intersex chromosomes, that it can‚Äôt just be my brain that‚Äôs male. because it feels so physical and real to be transgender, and i think most cis people, and even trans, forget this.\nThat its so physical a feeling, not just an emotional one.\nLike when people say ‚Äúwas a girl‚Äù or ‚Äúfemale to male‚Äù\nI‚Äôm so sure i‚Äôve always been male, its just been a long weird trip of dressing up and going with the flow, wondering when people will discover the truth.\n\nThat‚Äôs why despite liking more ‚Äúgirly‚Äù things emotionally, or recreational activities, i am 100% sure i am a guy physically.\nThe two are very different for me, and it just makes me so sure being trans (for me) is a thing from birth and not a mental misalignment caused by life or interests.\nIt makes the transitioning process really annoying because there are hours and hours talking about childhood and life and interests and sexuality and none of these things have ever influenced my gender, the only things that have are peoples perception and language used against non-femme afab people, which made me think being masculine as an afab person was shameful. love.\n\nShirota-san, a senior in the office, and 2 others are in the film.\n\n Firstly the protagonist, Erik played by Shirota Yuu.\n\nAlthough I‚Äôve known Shirota-san from D-BOYS, whatever he does I‚Äôm not even mad, just a bit aggravated that, with money so tight, I‚Äôm going to have to toss down fifteen bucks for a new one. But regardless, we got invited out by a generous friend and I had a wonderful time.\n\nMy big change for today, I guess may not be as coincidental as I thought. Apparently, vision changes can happen depending on how your body deals with HRT. I noticed first that signs far away from me were near illegible, despite having my corrective lenses in. That was a bit distressing, but not terribly so. On the other hand, I noticed that colors are amazingly, gorgeously vibrant! \"Âä™ÂäõÂä†È§êÈ•≠\": A translation of a heartfelt letter written by a cfan for Luhan","body":"This was originally written by a cfan, @NiobiumDeer on Weibo (http://m.weibo.cn/5041575610/3752885924328667?sourcetype=page&amp;lfid=1076035041575610_-_WEIBO_SECOND_PROFILE_WEIBO&amp;lcardid=1076035041575610_-_WEIBO_SECOND_PROFILE_WEIBO_-_3752885924328667&amp;luicode=10000198&amp;_status_id=3752885924328667&amp;featurecode=10000001&amp;uicode=10000002) and I spent about two hours translating what she wrote because I was really touched by and really agreed with what she said, and I want to share it with those who can‚Äôt read Mandarin, so please don‚Äôt claim the credits for something 1) you didn‚Äôt write and 2) you didn‚Äôt translate. Please credit properly.\n\n  Also‚Ä¶I tried translate as accurately as possible but I‚Äôm no professional and also, there‚Äôs just some things about another language that‚Ä¶the beauty in its words just can‚Äôt be translate across‚Ä¶With that said, please take a moment to appreciate, even if you‚Äôre not his fan/stan, the hard work Lu Han (and all other members in EXO and other idols) has put into getting where he stands today‚Ä¶and my heart really hurts for he who‚Ä¶has also suffered so much..in getting here‚Ä¶and staying here. I love you, deer of dawn.\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nI stayed with my uncle when I was young, and my cousin was only six years older than me. He was a very unruly kid, but he had an almost extreme dedication/passion for cars.\n\n  His family wanted him to study, get into college and become a doctor, and so they nagged at him everyday, but he could (only wanted to) study things related to cars/things about cars, and the area of car models in his room far exceeds the area occupied by his bed. When he was seventeen, he ran away from home and nobody knew where he went. When I was in high school, relatives from ÂÆâÂæΩ (An Hui - a place in China) brought back the message that he was managing a car dealing company there and business was good. The family wanted my uncle to contact him (get in touch with him) but my uncle was equally stubborn and so he furiously rejected the idea.\n\n  The year I was done with high school, we heard (from people in An Hui) that my cousin got injured and broke his leg while on his way to discuss a contract. My uncle took a flight there in a rush, and he brought back my cousin, who was tanned, skinny and walking with a limp. Over a meal (a family meal), my cousin suddenly started crying, and his tears fell in the soup bowl.\n\n  My uncle wordlessly changed the bowl, and told him, ‚ÄúEat, it‚Äôs getting cold.‚Äù\n\n  ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî\n\n  It‚Äôs said that to be a good man, one has to dare to venture, and to be a real man one has to be able to get out there and shoulder (responsibilities), doing whatever possible (no matter how tough) to earn a living and support his family back home, and he would do anything to cover a gunshot wound on his shoulder with a shoulder of medals (this basically means earning glory and honour at the expense of injuries etc).\n\n  No matter how bruised and battered, but at the very least he had achievements and had done his parents proud. I always thought that was what growing up meant.\n\n  But that day I suddenly came to an understanding. The ones who love you don‚Äôt care for whether or not the place you are standing is full of glory and glamour, they care more about whether or not you have a bowl of steamy rice before you when you‚Äôre hungry, whether or not you have someone accompanying you when you‚Äôre sick, when you‚Äôre in pain, and when you‚Äôre struck down and at a loss of what to do.\n\n  ‚Äî‚Äî-\n\n  I used to ask/expect a lot of/from you.\n\n  I wished for you to keep improving, to step up to the top of thus world, and I wished for you to seize every opportunity possible so the next day, you can become the eternally shining star everyone knows about. I once was like many others, getting angry because you couldn‚Äôt get the things we felt you deserved (because of your losses, basically), and it was hard for me to sleep and eat, and like a revolutionary soldier, I forwent sleep to send the same email all night.\n\n  Back then, a lot of those who have gotten in touch with you were already saying that there were issues with your health. But back then, I was blinded by the desire I had built upon you, and I fervently joined the almost ritualistic activities that I‚Äôve been anticipating for a long time.\n\n  And just an hour before I read the news, I was thinking, once the concert is over, I must continue sending those emails, I must not let you be the only one left with nothing to do (no schedules). (We) Must let everything that can possibly happen happen to you (meaning to give the best possible arrangements etc to Luhan).\n\n  ‚Äî‚Äî\n\n  The instant I saw the news, the picture, all the wishes that had been so loud and fervent inside me lost their voices. And all the details which had been overlooked resurfaced.\n\n  I remember, in February, during an interview, when you talked about going into the sea in the middle of winter, you used the words ÂçÉÂàÄ‰∏áÂâê (like being sliced ten thousand times by a thousand knives).\n\n  I remember, in April, I saw with my own eyes, after your dance performance had ended, you were panting heavily, hidden in a corner where the light couldn‚Äôt reach.\n\n  I remember, back when the group was promoting Miracles In December, your eyes were bloodshot from fever, I remember you turning away from the microphone during the recording for Happy Camp to cough as softly as possible, I remember you massaging/hitting your thigh, in pain, when you were rehearsing for SMTOWN, and I remember how you deliberately tried to hide the tremble/instability in your walk back in Xi An (airport?).\n\n  ‚Äî‚Äî\n\n  You left home at the age of eighteen to a foreign land for your studies, and behind you stood so many people who didn‚Äôt understand your decision, or perhaps wholly disapproved of your choices. I once imagined you, that month of that year, in a foreign place, having to wait - without anything you can expect to happen/without anything you can count on happening - even if you had clenched your teeth (a metaphor for waiting, enduring) until your whole mouth tasted of acid.\n\n  At the age of eighteen, most of us won‚Äôt have to struggle to feed and support the family, and the only faith we have to support us is to give this world a tight, loud slap with our own hands, to prove that our determination is not for a mere daydream, to prove that we can live a fruitful life as we are supported by our own youthful dreams.\n\n  And you did indeed live humbly, staying silent in spite of all the hardships you were going through. And most of us, at your age, no matter what, wouldn‚Äôt have dared to take such a gamble and held our breath through it all. That was the majority which you had set yourself apart from, and you fought on, all by yourself, and in the tough silence you finally made your way to the front of the crowd.\n\n  I really wish to know, that year, in your phone call home, if you were always like the ‚Äúyou‚Äù captured by all the lenses this year, always full of life and energy, as if by standing there, there would be an infallible wall (protecting you).\n\n  ‚Äî‚Äî-\n\n  And then you debuted, and it appeared as though you valued (having to shoulder all those responsibilities), having all those labels stuck on you, and you had to be careful even when you speak. A single tree standing out amongst the forest faces the danger of being the first to fall/to be destroyed, and so one must fight the merciless wind and rain. And you stayed the same, just like the ‚Äúyou‚Äù when you first set sail.\n\n  That year, on stage, you held the microphone and said buwangchuxin (to never forget the heart you set sailed with/to never forget one‚Äôs original goals and purpose and attitude etc), and you were so sincere, I thought you were making/reading a vow. And then, just like you said, you carried yourself as if you would never tire.\n\n  Do you remember when you said when you first started playing the rubric cube, and you just couldn‚Äôt resist and had to hold it in your hands and practise? That moment, I guessed that you‚Äôre someone who always asked too much of himself, and as long as you‚Äôre learning something, you pay more attention than anyone on the details, even if you‚Äôre always practising. In the days following that, at the airports and in between recordings, you are always seen dancing the moves you‚Äôve been dancing hundreds and thousands of times, just because you‚Äôre scared of making one mistake. \n\n  I really wanted to live my life the way you do, but I know there isn‚Äôt a second person who has developed the same unyielding power you have. They can be just like you, but they‚Äôre not /you/.\n\n  ‚Äî‚Äî\n\n  The song that you participated in shot to fame and so, you got to stand on countless stages to receive all the awards. Only once did your eyes turn red. That year, at the end of the year, you looked into the camera and said what your new year resolution was. You said, you want to be someone outstanding.\n\n  Finally, I couldn‚Äôt bring myself to try feeling whatever it was that you‚Äôre feeling, I couldn‚Äôt possibly guess, as you were repeatedly practising all those dances and all those songs, just how vast is/was the sky that you‚Äôre aiming for.\n\n  I‚Äôve seen for myself that you‚Äôre already standing at the peak where many others have to spend a great deal more time to reach, so why do I feel that your eyes are still filled with the anticipation and eagerness they contained when you first set sailed?\n\n  Finally, this year, the year I had predicted that would dim all the glow/shine. Your Êú¨ÂëΩÂπ¥ (), as if it‚Äôs been cursed.\n\n  With your new identity and all the new awards you‚Äôve earned, and with a life more splendid than the ones others have ever lived, and having received more love than before. They were drawn to ‚Äúfeminine‚Äù things, like dresses and dolls and make up. And while girls don‚Äôt have to even like feminine things, this royal felt like girl fit them better than boy. They always wished to be a girl since they were little.\n\nBut in their teens they learned more about trans people, and realized that if they identified as a girl, that would mean that they were a girl. They realized that they had always really been a girl.\n\nBut her parents would not hear of such things. Once she came out to them, they refused to accept that she was a girl and banned her from ‚Äúfeminine‚Äù things, thinking that would somehow stop her from being a girl. She was forced to remain in the closet, only ever revealing her true self to her best friend. She was forced to only learn and do things that her parents considered ‚Äúboyish‚Äù. Sword fighting being the only one she actually enjoyed.\n\nSo the young princess grew up, unable to show her true self to her people. Sheltered by her parents. Her parents kept her hidden from the public as much as her parents could get away with. Her younger brother, on the other hand, they took great pride in.\n\nHe was the heir. He loved his sister and accepted her, but could not do much about how horrid their parents were.\n\nThe princess had to stay in the closet‚Ä¶ Until one day‚Ä¶\n\nOn the way to a meeting with a neighboring kingdom (which she of course was not invited to, since her parents considered her the black sheep in the family), her parent‚Äôs train hit another train head on.\n\nHer parents were killed.\n\nShe was depressed for about a month, but then decided that she actually didn‚Äôt care much. Her parents never cared for her. They were ashamed of her. Their deaths would not change the mental abuse and transphobia they had shown her her entire life. They were not worthy of being called her parents. Their deaths did not mean that she owed them any respect.\n\nHer brother was more torn up about it, but finally got better after two months of mourning. Once he got out of his depression, he made a shocking proclamation:\n\n‚ÄúThere is no better person to rule this kingdom than Riley. They deserve it more than I do. I relinquish my rights to the crown to them.‚Äù\n\nRiley was shocked. A few weeks later, her brother left to fight in a war. He writes home sometimes.\n\nToday Riley is 17. She struggles with her gender identity. Now that her parents are gone, she is trying to regain the love for her real gender and overcome the transphobic insults, misgendering, and invalidation her parents had forced upon her.\n\nWill she come out to her subjects? Will she be able to be herself? Or will transphobia keep her in the closet? How will things work out for her?\n\nIn just two months, she will be crowned ruler of the kingdom. Will she stay in the closet and accept being crowned a king? Or will she accept who she really is, and take her rightful position as Queen?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"eternalfemininity","id":97361494085,"post_url":"http://eternalfemininity.tumblr.com/post/97361494085/had-to-call-out-someone-from-my-schools-womens","slug":"had-to-call-out-someone-from-my-schools-womens","type":"text","date":"2014-09-13 03:57:00 GMT","timestamp":1410580620,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"y6R2sNLk","tags":["trans","trans women","transgender","memoir","personal","2nd person memoir","gwen araujo"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-CYhu1Qgrl0b","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"Maybe it was this way for you too","body":"Maybe it was this way for you too. You hid it all and didn‚Äôt tell anyone else what was going on. But a little bit of courage built every day. And the conviction came that it was now and you were going to do‚Ä¶ something. Maybe not shout it from the rooftops, but tell someone close. You were going to share your pain.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. Her name was Gwen and she was your age and she lived less than fifty miles away. At first she was missing, but there was no real doubt. She had been killed. She was seventeen. You were seventeen. She had been living as you wanted to and she was killed for that. They blamed their rage on her existence. These murderers so much like the boys you called friends. They buried her in the woods. You would only look up the news stories late at night after everyone else had gone to bed because there was only one computer and the whole family used it. You hid her pictures in a folder buried deep on the computer‚Äîa place no one else would ever even look‚Äîand erased your history. You would do the same the next night and the next and the next and the next and try to follow the case even though nothing changed and she was dead and that wouldn‚Äôt change. In your history class the only teacher you ever heard talk about this killing, who called it a tragedy, also called Gwen by the wrong name. You told no one.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. You realized there was no one to talk to about this. No one to mention this death that was so removed and so close to you. Gwen was dead and you never knew her but you wished you had. You weren‚Äôt part of the cool queer outcasts‚Äîa group of maybe two at your school. You were some stupid jock playing baseball and skipping class to go to the movies. You weren‚Äôt even supposed to know the word transgender. You were called fag only ever in a joking way‚Äîjust like all the guys called each other‚Äînot with the menace of violence behind it. There was no way for them to know the fear you held.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. You had worn girls clothing, two sizes too small and stolen from your sister, under your jeans. You did this in September of 2002 but after October 3rd you never did it again. You went from being kind of a loner to having no friends at all. You felt close to no one. You skipped class even more. You wrote a short story in first person from a female perspective‚Äîbut just as an exercise, you tell the classmates you didn‚Äôt realize would be reading it. You tried your best to control your voice and listen and hope they don‚Äôt notice your panicked sweat. You think of the frying pan they struck her with. The shovel they left to get and then used to strike her unconscious body. The rope they strangled her with. You know there‚Äôs no real chance of that but the images come to your mind because this was the only other seventeen-year-old trans girl in the world you‚Äôd ever heard of. It was just you and her and she was dead now and you were alone. Gwen you never knew.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. It was so easy being the withdrawn jock. Just play baseball and drive away to eat lunch each day. No one will ever ask more from you. Sure, you‚Äôre grades are too low to go to college even though everyone you know is applying. And yeah it‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre good enough at baseball to have a future there. Hell, you hardly see the field that year. You‚Äôre just some dumb C- student who will probably start working construction with your dad and brothers after high school. What else could you even hope for. What other option is there. You saw what happens when you let it out and show people. They buried it back down for you in a shallow grave.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. When you took the Army aptitude test you get a perfect score on their intelligence measure‚Äîit‚Äôs not really a hard test. You were never really dumb, just shitty at school, and everyone knew that so no one is surprised or anything. But when the recruiter comes and talks to you and asks you to sign papers and go in for a physical and mentions college it‚Äôs the first time you believe that escape is real and so even though it‚Äôs the last damn thing you want you sign up and after you do and the dread sets in you don‚Äôt understand that quitting is an option and you can walk away. You sign your letter to join the Army in March of 2003 and on the radio on the way back home with your father they announce that the first bombs have been dropped on Iraq. You are seventeen and have another year of high school left still, but it‚Äôs okay, they have a special program for you to start early.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. Your sense of doom and depression climb and climb and at least you stop actively thinking about her and how they killed her just for breathing. You move from station to station as the school year ends and boot camp begins and on the plane you hide the tears from the sleeping middle aged man next to you. You imagine elaborate fantasies of leaving almost upon arrival. The other recruits seem just as nervous and uncertain as you though and there‚Äôs at least some comfort in that. And by the time they drive you to camp you‚Äôre so lost that you wouldn‚Äôt even know which direction to flee. Eventually you find a map and you try to figure out how long you‚Äôd have before they would discover your empty bed and maybe it would be better to try and convince some other scared guy to make out but then everyone would think you were gay and you‚Äôve convinced yourself that was worse than this. So you push through. You‚Äôre bright and athletic and used to hiding your emotions. You are very good at basic training, for whatever that‚Äôs worth.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. When you return people look at you weird. You are technically a soldier, but you‚Äôve done nothing other than gone to a camp where some people yell at you for ten weeks. Your one friend, the one who was taking the damn test so you tagged along with in the first place, the one you don‚Äôt even really care about but he‚Äôs probably just as lonely as you and it‚Äôs easier to stand next to someone before school than no one, he‚Äôs joining the Marines after school‚Äôs out and so you talk about military stuff. That is until you freak out and drive 500 miles south before turning right around because you just need to leave. Your life gets put on pause in some ways‚Äîyou don‚Äôt have to deal with school other than a half an hour in a small room out in the woods where a teacher asks you about what you‚Äôve read lately and gives you some math worksheets. And you have to drive thirty miles one weekend a month to stand around and not know what to do while people work in an office and wear army fatigues. Eventually you just stop showing up to these and somehow this was all you needed to do to get discharged. Finally your passivity pays off. Of course you don‚Äôt know this at the time and you dread the eventual meetings and talks and is this even legal? Can they put you in prison for this? You don‚Äôt see why not.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. You graduate and start working at a lumber yard and everything seems back to the track you were on. But at the last minute you decide to attend the community college and sign up for whatever class you can. You get a really great English teacher in this accelerated pace class designed to help students transfer quicker. It is the perfect match for you. You‚Äôve never done so well in school in your life‚Äînot even to the earliest years when you could never avoid trouble and would sometimes start crying if things went wrong. You even have a plan set that will free you from this place. You start to see the shape of a life that‚Äôs not so bad. Yeah, the depression and dysphoria come to visit you often, but at least in those other days it feels like you could maybe be okay. Not happy, but okay. You‚Äôve never thought that was an option before.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. The life you were living was getting better and others seemed happy for you but you didn‚Äôt feel it at all. You constantly circled back to those trans thoughts and spent hours wandering down what-if paths. You wanted nothing more than to run away again from this good, respectable life you were building. You pushed away a woman you loved in no small part because you wanted and feared a future with her. You had to hide your thoughts from her and resented her for asking so often what is wrong. You couldn‚Äôt answer and said nothing and magnified her faults in your mind. And when you dump her you think it‚Äôs better and now you can find someone who will make you happy, even though you‚Äôve never been happy.\n\nMaybe it was this way for you too. You saw it all clearly and the cycle was plainly shown. You realized it wasn‚Äôt going away. You are 28 and Gwen never got past 17, but she lived more than you ever have. And you know she wasn‚Äôt the only trans girl your age. You watch hours and hours worth of timeline videos on youtube and lurk reddit to see the beautiful trans girls who are your age and living proof that you were wrong and this can be done. You realize how much the death of Gwen was a product of the violence trans women of color face and how even though she lived near you and was your age you probably can‚Äôt relate to her experience. She faced a violence and oppression that you won‚Äôt know. Yet you still think of her and wonder if anyone else knows her name. How could you ever even begin to explain to someone just how important she was to your life. How could you ever begin to talk about her. What could you even say. She was born in the same year as you, nine months before you, and she was killed because she was a girl like you. You were just beginning to understand how real this was and name what it was. It was getting clear and you were thinking of ways to make it real and live that life and then they killed her for being a girl. That was the price. She was the only other trans girl in the world and they had killed her. But she wasn‚Äôt the only one. You were a trans girl too even if you ran from that and tried to ignore it into oblivion. You are trans and that never changes. You are trans and many others are too. You hid and you ran but that‚Äôs okay. You did what you had to survive and yeah it sucks that you weren‚Äôt really living your life for the last ten years like you could have been, but you‚Äôre here. You are twenty-eight and trans and a women and have hormones and all of that seemed so fucking impossible to you in October of 2002. You are alive and scared but ready to exist. It‚Äôs okay if it took you a while to get here, we‚Äôre just happy you did.\n\n‚ÄîEmma","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"margaretshock","id":97355390909,"post_url":"http://margaretshock.tumblr.com/post/97355390909/meet-my-first-trans-woman-character-florence","slug":"meet-my-first-trans-woman-character-florence","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-13 03:56:00 GMT","timestamp":1410580560,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"YfUZENtx","tags":["trans","transsexual","transgender","trans-woman","margaret shock","historical You zoomed in on ONE word in my entire ask. I used it mostly because there's a character limit. What I meant is that they haven't actually said \"I'm trans\", they would be deciding to say something, confirm it with them self, I guess. And, no, actually, I have never once told them that they shouldn't be trans or that its a bad thing. I haven't said anything negative to them on the subject at all. I also think that if that's what they really feel and want","answer":"[2/3] (okay I lied it was more than two) then they should absolutely go for it. Being my best friend, I WILL support them no matter what happens. I don‚Äôt want them to feel worse if that‚Äôs not what they really are in the end. No, I dont know them better than them self, but I do know them better than you. They can‚Äôt just say ‚ÄúOh, I guess I was cis afterall.‚Äù and be fine. It would destroy them to be so wrong about something. One more point is that I have nothing against trans people at all. I don‚Äôt think that lots and lots of trans people are only like that from past trauma, I think they‚Äôre people who genuinely feel different than the set norm and make steps to be their true self, as you could say. No, I don‚Äôt know a super duper lot about trans people. I‚Äôve never met one in my life. So, yes, I might say something that offends you, because I know language is really important to you. Its mostly because I don‚Äôt know what words and phrases you might use, so I‚Äôm sorry if I get it wrong.\n\nI‚Äôm glad to hear that you intend to support your friend whatever they may do, but I zoomed in on ‚Äòone word‚Äô for an important reason - trans people do not ‚Äòdecide‚Äô to be trans, and that‚Äôs an important distinction to make. I‚Äôm glad that it was a result of limited space rather than thinking that we do ‚Äòdecide‚Äô to be trans (as opposed to maybe making a decision regarding how & when we transition, which some of us do make a decision on), but I stand by my correction, because I couldn‚Äôt know unless you clarified.\n\nI don‚Äôt know why you came to me for help if you‚Äôre going to resist what I tell you. I appreciate that you‚Äôre not going to get the wording right all the time, but it‚Äôs still important to maybe find out a bit more about trans people and start learning the terminology, to help your friend, especially if they do realise they are trans.\n\nThe best thing for your friend, if they are questioning, is to let them question and to support them through it. Yes, they might realise they are not trans, and that might be a blow to them, but it‚Äôs still an important step for some people.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"transoregon","id":97341034397,"post_url":"http://transoregon.tumblr.com/post/97341034397/theres-transmasculine-and-transfemine-groups-that-meet","slug":"theres-transmasculine-and-transfemine-groups-that-meet","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-13 00:28:00 GMT","timestamp":1410568080,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"UOpdpuSn","tags":["portland","q center","transmasculine","transfeminine","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zs1ahw1Qf_a_T","followed":false,"post_author":"oddment-tweak","highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"asking_name":"lionsmustroamfree","asking_url":"http://lionsmustroamfree.tumblr.com/","question":"There's transmasculine and transfemine groups that meet at the Q Center every week. certainty selecting the color scheme for this blog than I do writing in it. When did the lines between verbal and written expression start to blur? I mean, half my life has been spent orating, whether it be at my job, to my friends or to myself as I sit alone in the car. But now, as I sit in front of a keyboard, I struggle to articulate this tangled mass of emotions I have trapped inside. Not to say that it‚Äôs any easier, trying to sort through it aloud. But at least in that respect I can bullshit my point across‚Ä¶ At least, I can most days.\n\nFake it until you make it, right? That‚Äôs what my dear old Dad used to say.\n\nNo, for the most part I‚Äôm totally and utterly blocked. Which sucks, especially considering the fact I have a new love vibrating in my chest, bouncing from corridor to corridor, urging to be free. Maybe that‚Äôs where all this tangible, physical pain is coming from? (At least, I like to joke that way in my head.) But seriously. It‚Äôs storybook love, the kind I haven‚Äôt felt since high school - that shout it from the rooftops kind of reaffirming love. And guess what? \n\nHe‚Äôs trans*.\n\nWhich is not of course, the defining aspect to his character. Oh no, when I think of Alec, I think of those fertile blue-green eyes set against his alabaster skin, or the way his dark hair falls when he tips his head against the pillow. Or the way he knows instictively how to curve his lips to mine in a way I haven‚Äôt felt all my life. I mean, for fuck‚Äôs sake, I was with Jamie for four or five years and not once did he try to adapt to me. No, I was the one forced to change, mold, adapt. But with Alec, I for once feel free. I feel closer and closer to being‚Ä¶ Me.\n\nBut he‚Äôs trans*. Which poses a small problem.\n\nNot for my Dad, gods bless him. Despite his total inadequacy as a parent, I will eternally credit him for being my best friend. ‚ÄúAs long as you‚Äôre happy, I‚Äôm happy,‚Äù he said. He could care less. In fact, my non-binary gender sort of lends itself well to Alec, which is something he noted later on. And you know, it poses no problems for my immediate friends, either. They all adore him. No, the only concern I have is in relation to my super religious co-workers and even then (as I try to be the best ally I can) I of course, refuse to out him. But he doesn‚Äôt pass well. After all, he came out for the first time in March. They haven‚Äôt met him. All they know is that I‚Äôm seeing a guy named Alec and as far as I‚Äôm concerned, that‚Äôs all they need to know.\n\nBut still. I love him! I want to take him to our work christmas party and show him off in a vest and tie. I want to declare in front of God and everyone that this is the person for me. But I‚Äôm not the issue. It‚Äôs about making him feel comfortable. I‚Äôd rather stab myself in the leg than see him misgendered. slandered or abused.\n\nAnd then there is a whole other issue in the form of my best friend Amber. She saw my graceful departure from Jamie a few months back and as I suspected, began to feel the same. Now, she‚Äôs having doubts about her own boyfriend. But.. They‚Äôre presenting themselves in the form of another. Like, another guy. And I hate to watch her do this to herself and to him. Eric is a good person. Jobless? Sure. Sometimes callous with a complete and utter lack of motivation? Sure. But who isn‚Äôt twenty-something and at least a little bit like that? I certainly have no room to talk, at least when it comes to motivation. But he‚Äôs also loyal, patient, considerate and kind. Were she to work up the courage to talk to him about it, I‚Äôm more than certain they might‚Äôve worked through some of these issues. But instead she was afraid. And now, the love very well may be gone.\n\nBut wait! There‚Äôs more. I have axillary swelling under my armpit that is totally mysterious. Chest pain that comes and goes. Blood work? Fine. Ultrasound? No lumps! Gee, I wonder what‚Äôs wrong with me? WHO KNOWS? Not my doctor, that‚Äôs for sure.\n\nBut the drinking certainly helps‚Ä¶ As does the cymbalta. Or at least, it seems to be helping.\n\nAnyway, that‚Äôs all for now.
