After living in a hazy, post traumatic state for over two decades, it feels strange to stop for a moment and realize that I‚Äôm safe. There are moments, still, when I can feel that unspoken tension between myself and another. For a moment it feels like our spirits, in some other realm, are battling. There is the chaos, the smoke of judgment, the shrieking whistle of preconception. A checkout line has become a battlefield.\n\nAnd I know of course that much of this is my own projection. My own defensiveness. And so I‚Äôve begun to forgive myself. And them. \n\nInstead of battling what I assume to be their words, I battle my own. I combat every harsh critique with a kind utterance, parry each perceived insult with compassion. My head is often spinning with darkness. Years of anger and bitterness have built to an uncertain, internal cacophony. But I will speak over each negative voice, let my mental narrative burst with love and kindness. With patience, I will build a chorus of light within me that beats back the darkness. \n\nI will learn to forgive.\n\nIt isn‚Äôt their fault they cannot see me. It‚Äôs just the world they know.\n\nAnger drains me. I was mostly scared shitless of getting an air bubble in the syringe and killing myself, so I double, triple, and quadruple checked that there weren‚Äôt any air bubbles. I foresee that being the thing my anxiety fixates on as this becomes a habit, because I‚Äôm already still mildly panicky over it. \n\nActually putting the needle in my thigh wasn‚Äôt that bad. It actually hurt less than most shots I‚Äôve had in my arm. I pulled up on the plunger to see if I hit a vein, and there was no blood, so all in all, I‚Äôd say it was a good first shot. Though, I‚Äôm bleeding a little bit, because my hands were so shaky and I didn‚Äôt pull the needle out as quickly or as smoothly as I should have. But live and learn, right?\n\nFollowing putting the band aid on, I decided to grab the box that I usually store my kit in. As someone who struggles/ed with self-harm (like 95% of everyone else on this website), I was pretty ritualistic in where I kept my medical supplies and sharp objects. But i decided it was time that that box had a new use, so I cleaned it out and put my T vial in there, along with extra band aids and alcohol swabs. I‚Äôm actually pretty lucky I‚Äôve got a decent stock of decent medical supplies, because the pharmacy only gave me syringes, no swabs or anything else. I think I might buy Batman band aids the next time I go to town, just as a treat for myself, because I‚Äôm really just an overgrown child. \n\nSo yeah, that‚Äôs week 1. Can‚Äôt wait to see what the next few will be like!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"feministroosterteeth","id":97316886086,"post_url":"http://feministroosterteeth.tumblr.com/post/97316886086/i-really-hate-how-people-make-fun-of-the-way-famous","slug":"i-really-hate-how-people-make-fun-of-the-way-famous","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-12 18:47:23 GMT","timestamp":1410547643,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"h3IdCmVY","tags":["Anonymous","body positivity","social justice","trans","transgender","transmisogyny","misogyny","sexism","frtasks"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZHQdjr1QeYTP6","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"I really hate how people make fun of the way famous women look when just because they're problematic. The thing is, from what I know about them they're saying these things/feeling this way because of past trauma, and it's like they don't want to be their gender because they don't feel safe. If they really felt that way and said something more, I would support them, but I feel like as of now it would be for unhealthy reasons, and I wouldn't want that. Does that make sense?","answer":"No. Not really. The whole ‚Äòyou‚Äôre only doing this because past trauma‚Äô thing is thrown at trans people soooo much, and it‚Äôs really fucked up. Don‚Äôt define us (or our gender) by our past experiences. Also, even if your friend is uncomfortable with their gender because of past trauma, refusing to support them in that because it‚Äôs ‚Äòunhealthy‚Äô is really shitty. There‚Äôs nothing unhealthy about exploring one‚Äôs gender identity - that‚Äôs how we discover ourselves.\n\nSupport your friend. I was also very lucky to have pretty cool Etsy shops donate a few of their goods to us to give to our donors as well! Glitter Wurst is donating zines and The Pissed is donating pins! There are more small businesses that will so generously be donating as well (in a way, as my personal way of helping out small businesses by helping them with advertising)! Stay tuned for that by checking back from time to time!\n\nIf you like handmade items, the lgbtqia community, and lending a helping hand, please donate to Dylan‚Äôs Top Surgery Fund.","link_url":"http://www.gofundme.com/dylanstopsurgeryfund","image_permalink":"http://trans-itionfundcollective.tumblr.com/image/97297765611","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":448,"height":800,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/1a11209e2e539692b1c6f02b115c1d84/tumblr_nbs26uOKCf1r7mzeno1_1280.jpg"},{"width":420,"height":750,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/1a11209e2e539692b1c6f02b115c1d84/tumblr_nbs26uOKCf1r7mzeno1_500.jpg"},{"width":336,"height":600,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/1a11209e2e539692b1c6f02b115c1d84/tumblr_nbs26uOKCf1r7mzeno1_400.jpg"},{"width":224,"height":400,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/1a11209e2e539692b1c6f02b115c1d84/tumblr_nbs26uOKCf1r7mzeno1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":179,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/1a11209e2e539692b1c6f02b115c1d84/tumblr_nbs26uOKCf1r7mzeno1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/1a11209e2e539692b1c6f02b115c1d84/tumblr_nbs26uOKCf1r7mzeno1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":448,"height":800,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/1a11209e2e539692b1c6f02b115c1d84/tumblr_nbs26uOKCf1r7mzeno1_1280.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"shineetown","id":97297729916,"post_url":"http://shineetown.tumblr.com/post/97297729916/trans-140912-140912-key-instagram-update-with","slug":"trans-140912-140912-key-instagram-update-with","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-12 12:49:49 GMT","timestamp":1410526189,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"yywh1Kfr","tags":["key","instagram","shinee","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z8ve9y1QdPOby","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":128,"caption":"[TRANS] 140912¬†140912 Key - How open & big is the trans* community there?","answer":"I personally have never lived anywhere other than Portland so I can‚Äôt really compare it to communities in other cities. I can get you started with a few relevant things in town: both PSU and PCC have some resources for trans and GNC students; the Trans and/or Women‚Äôs Action Camp is planned locally and held nearby annually; the Q Center hosts trans groups; there was a trans pride march at Pride this year (the photos from that event might help answer your question more eloquently than I can). Even if it takes a long time, they‚Äôre willing to wait as long as it takes because dealing with the body dysforia is torture and to be a man/woman physically is what they‚Äôve always wanted. \n\nWhat breaks my heart is to hear that when some of these people come out to their families and tell them that they are transgender, they are practically shown the door. They get kicked out or even abused at home because they aren‚Äôt considered normal or because their family thinks they can beat the nonsense out of them. But they can‚Äôt. Its not possible. oloud","id":97270077916,"post_url":"http://soulstooloud.tumblr.com/post/97270077916/i-was-walking-into-a-friends-house-earlier-and-a","slug":"i-was-walking-into-a-friends-house-earlier-and-a","type":"text","date":"2014-09-12 However, because of my age I was told I needed to attend six sessions. This bumbed me out to the max. Luckily, they shortened it to three for me. I have now completed two, so then i have one more- and the PRESCRIPTION FOR TESTERONE DAY. So excited to start taking T and have the physical changes. I am so close right now. warning: self-esteem, self-depreciation\n\nAfter some encouragement and reading countless stories on this blog, I have felt a little more and more motivated to write down my account, for anyone like me who needs a little push, or a little encouragement to tell themselves that they are beautiful. I am so thankful that I have taken my first baby steps toward loving myself after all these years, and this is my first pebble I‚Äôd like to toss, to get the ripple effect going, one which says this: I am beautiful, and proud to be me.\n\nI will begin by saying this: I have been diagnosed with a few things out of my control, but not necessarily things that define me or my attitude. There are things I haven‚Äôt been diagnosed for, things I will come to accept or change about myself, once I come to terms with whether or not it‚Äôs a part of me that‚Äôs good for me.\n\nI was diagnosed first with a blood disorder, then bipolar II, then I made the biggest step forward in my life that has changed my life for so many good reasons: I told the truth about myself. I am a transgender guy. I was born with a female body, with everything else about me screaming YOU ARE MALE.\n\nFor years I thought the major part of my depression stemmed from my poor body esteem. For years I tried to cope and find me.\n\nMy poor body image, however, came long before I came out. I had been a few pounds underweight for a good portion of my life, but I still hated the small stomach I had. I never wore flattering clothes, and always tried to hide my body.\n\nI thought surgery would change this, as though eliminating the parts of me I was unhappy about would suddenly bring about a miraculous era of love for myself. Instead I was greeted with the side effects of medication and surgery: keloids and weight gain. The perfect chest I‚Äôd always dreamed of came with drawbacks, the scars will never heal and they caused 18 months of physical pain before I could finally afford help in terms of dermatology.\n\nI have had binge eating problems (where I eat, and feel guilty about it later, or ‚ÄúI eat my emotions.‚Äù) and now I am finally facing those issues because they are finally visible. Now I have stretch marks everywhere. Knees, thighs, back, stomach, arms, chest, you name it. My body image and self-esteem are at the lowest point they have ever been, and having the doctors tell me I need to lose weight repeatedly has never helped, or motivated me. Because of my chronic depression, I feel even less motivation to get around to ‚Äúfeeling better about me.‚Äù There was a time in my life where I absolutely thought I couldn‚Äôt take it anymore, and a year later I wound up checking myself into a hospital to prevent myself from taking my own life.\n\nYou know what though? I‚Äôm proud that I did that. I would not become the amazing person I am today if I had given in. And I‚Äôm proud that I admitted I needed help. Everyone thinks that if you go to a hospital for ‚Äúmental issues,‚Äù you are crazy. I actually remember, however, this five day experience as one of the happiest times of my life. I learned that there was nothing wrong with me, I am beautiful the way I am. My second problem was that I didn‚Äôt love or accept the people around me, and that I couldn‚Äôt see that I am strong, wise, inspirational, and brave.\n\nI am still working on my self-esteem as I‚Äôve said, but I want to truly love me, and part of me is loving and accepting this vessel I was given. You only get one, as they say. Part of loving me means loving who I am and what makes me the wonderful person I am.\n\nI want you to know above all, there are people like you out there. There are people whose surgeries didn‚Äôt give them the body of a god/goddess. There are people out there just like you who struggle just like you. I am one of these people. And I don‚Äôt care who you are or what your situation is.\n\nYOU. ARE. BEAUTIFUL, and I love you. Never let anyone make you feel/tell you otherwise.\n\nI am willing to listen if you ever need to talk, and also willing to make friends here.\n\nMy blog is: fullmetalchampion\n\nfullmetalchampion.tumblr.com\n\n  BE BRAVE! He acknowledged and apologized for past slights and behaviors at the heart of a significant gap between HRC and the trans community in the hopes that fences can finally be mended. Just as important, he pledged that the organization would do better in the future.\n\nI‚Äôve been thinking about this for a few days now, letting it seep in and settle in my consciousness. What happened in 2007, when then-HRC president Joe Solmonese stood on that very same stage making promises and commitments that would prove to be inconvenient and hollow less than six weeks later, continues to be a dagger between the shoulders for many of us who dared to believe back then. Perhaps nobody felt that pain more acutely than I.\n\nAt the time I was the first and only trans member of the HRC board of directors. I was the cochair of the diversity committee. Jamison Green and I worked tirelessly for the business council, and many of the workplace protections and benefits that have become such an important reality for many trans people today are a direct result of the work that we started. As a board member, I raised a significant amount of money to fund the critical work we were doing, and I spoke passionately and tirelessly at dinners around the country. I rolled up my sleeves and wasn‚Äôt afraid to fight on the front lines wherever and whenever necessary. Why? Because I believed. I trusted that the organization would stay true to the lofty ideals I thought we represented. When it proved that it didn‚Äôt, I had to go.\n\nKnowing what I know of the backstory of what happened, all I can say is that my sense of betrayal, anger, hurt, and frustration continues to this day. Time has dulled some of it, but the scab has still not healed. I realize we all need to put the past behind us in order to move forward, and I‚Äôm trying my best to do that, I really am. What happened was deeply, deeply personal, and there has still been no closure for me. But that‚Äôs water under the bridge at this point, and none of that is Chad‚Äôs fault.\n\nAlthough Chad stood on that stage and apologized last week, the truth is that he fell on a sword that wasn‚Äôt his to fall on. It was drawn by leaders in the organization who are no longer there and who I can say without hesitation were directly responsible for what unfolded and how. Chad inherited their ill-conceived legacy of anger and distrust, and has pledged to fix it. I respect him for that.\n\nIt‚Äôs important to recognize that HRC today is not the same organization it was then. At the same time, the collective trans community (and entire LGBT community, for that matter) has changed too. We have matured. We have weathered tests that strained the bonds of ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù and challenged our collective commitment to the high ideals I spoke of in my resignation letter. Whether we realize it or not, we have emerged the stronger for it.\n\nI have never met Chad Griffin, so I have no personal sense of his commitment to his words or his ability to keep his promises. Although I give him the benefit of the doubt, I hope to meet with him at some point to form my own opinion, as I trust my instincts. However, he‚Äôs off to a good start. The organization that he leads is already light-years ahead of where it was when I first got involved more than a decade ago. People I admire and respect greatly who left the organization around the ‚Äúdark time‚Äù are back in leadership positions. Jay Brown, the director of foundation program strategies, is someone I‚Äôd stand with in battle any time, anywhere. Brandon Braud again leads the initiatives involving historically black colleges and universities with passion and skill. I met Hayden Mora, the deputy chief of staff, at Southern Comfort and came away impressed and hopeful. Internally, the organization has revamped and realigned its foundation structure to address the issues that affect the daily lives of many LGBT people.\n\nCan the organization do more? Of course it can. Per Chad‚Äôs speech, he recognizes that, and he pledged to address it through action. I have several nuggets of constructive personal advice for him. Let us help you keep the commitments that you made Friday. Don‚Äôt think you are doing things for us ‚Äî do them with us. Actively reach out and engage those of us who may not have sipped the Kool-Aid yet, and take what we tell you seriously. Ask us what we need and what our priorities are; don‚Äôt presume to tell us. Don‚Äôt patronize us or placate us ‚Äî it will only make us angry. Lead through example. Respect us, include us, embrace us, but most important of all, for God‚Äôs sake, realize that honesty and integrity must be nonnegotiable if this relationship is going to work. Without that, there is nothing.\n\nI want to believe that things are different now. I really do. It‚Äôs not that I‚Äôm a glutton for punishment. Rather, I consider myself a pragmatist first and foremost. We need to make this relationship work, not simply for the sake of the T but for the sake of all who define themselves by some letter of our continually growing LGBTQ+ alphabet soup. We‚Äôre either in this together or we‚Äôre not. Anything gained for some at the expense of others will ultimately prove itself to be a hollow victory for all. Been there, done that.\n\nErnest Hemingway once said, ‚ÄúThe best way to find out if you can trust somebody is to trust them.‚Äù Based on Chad‚Äôs comments last week, all I can promise in return is to do my best to try. Let‚Äôs start with that and see where it goes. If enough of us feel similarly ‚Äî well, I dare to dream.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"massagemybellyfat","id":97262630739,"post_url":"http://massagemybellyfat.tumblr.com/post/97262630739/im-thinking-about-the-name-maddock-nickname-mac","slug":"im-thinking-about-the-name-maddock-nickname-mac","type":"text","date":"2014-09-12 00:57:37 GMT","timestamp":1410483457,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"2liLkgQr","tags":["trans","ftm","renaming myself"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZFT-Wu1QbJVTJ","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"","body":"I‚Äôm thinking about the name Maddock/ nickname Mac. 00:28:52 GMT","timestamp":1410481732,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"t3nqOvLO","tags":["coming out","transgender","trans*","trans","ftm","f2m","coming out letter"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnJgZv1QbBHoX","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"title":"Coming out as trans* to my parents - thoughts?","body":"Dear Mom and Dad,\n\n  Before I really begin writing this letter, I want to ask that you read the entire thing. Some things that I say here may be difficult to process, make you feel anxious, angry, hurt, or even scared. But I‚Äôm not writing this letter to make you feel those things. I‚Äôm writing this letter because I‚Äôve struggled for a long time now to find the perfect way to tell you what it is that I need to tell you, and this is the best way I can think of that will both allow me the time I need to comprise all of my thoughts, and you the time to process what I‚Äôm going to tell you before you respond.\n\n  I am a transgender man. I have been living as male and as Ashton since December 4, 2013. I‚Äôm sure you may be wondering whether this is my way of fitting in with my friends, especially considering that my best friend, Jay, is also a trans man. Let me dispel that notion from the start. I have more non-trans friends than I do trans friends. I have never felt right in my body. I thought that coming out as gay would fix that, and in some ways, it did. It gave me access to the LGBT community, and I was able to find friends who were more like me. However, even after immersing myself in the LGBT community, I didn‚Äôt feel whole. I felt a rush of anxiety whenever I would shower or look at myself in the mirror, whenever I would shop in the women‚Äôs section for my clothes, whenever I would even hear the words ‚Äúshe‚Äù or ‚Äúher‚Äù in reference to me, and for a long time, I didn‚Äôt know where that anxiety was coming from or what it meant.\n\n  When I came to Wayne State, I met my first trans man ‚Äì my good friend, Charlie. However, because he was already out as trans and living as male when I met him, it didn‚Äôt ever occur to me that I might actually be transgender ‚Äì it never occurred to me that trans was something I could ‚Äúbe‚Äù (I put ‚Äúbe‚Äù in quotes there because being transgender is not something that one chooses to do‚Ä¶it is something one IS). Then, I met Jay. When I met Jay, he wasn‚Äôt out as trans. It was almost 6 months into our friendship before he told me that he had always felt like a male, and that he was going to start transitioning. That was the first time I realized that I might actually be trans, but I was far too terrified to even admit it to myself, let alone to anybody else. I spent the next few years denying the feelings I was having. Whenever I would look in the mirror, whenever anybody would use feminine gender pronouns when talking about me, whenever I would introduce myself as a lesbian at the GLBTA Student Union Meetings, I would feel my gut tighten, and I would ignore that feeling of discomfort that comes hand in hand with lying to yourself.\n\n  Finally, on December 4 of 2013, I was able to say the words out loud. I told the members of the GLBTA Student Union that I was trans and that, from that point forward, I would like to be known as Ashton, and be referred to by male pronouns. Now, everyone from my friends to my therapist to the Dean of Students knows me as Ashton and refers to me by male pronouns. I have never felt so happy and so complete as I have in the months since I‚Äôve come out as trans. I have also felt an increased anxiety about having to hide this huge part of myself from my family, who literally mean the world to me. I told Amy about a month ago, but I promised her that I would wait to come out to the rest of the family until after her wedding. Part of me wanted to make sure that I didn‚Äôt take any attention away from her on her day, because she deserved to have her moment in the spotlight. However, part of me felt that if I had come out in the chaos preceding Amy‚Äôs wedding, I would be more likely to get a negative reaction, and that terrified me. Even as I write this letter, I am more scared than I can possibly express that I will lose what means more to me than anything ‚Äì my family ‚Äì by telling you this. Believe me, if this weren‚Äôt literally a matter of life and death for me ‚Äì and it is ‚Äì I would not transition. It would be much easier for me to exist within our family as a gay female than as a trans male. But the thought of living a lie causes me so much anxiety, and puts me in such a deep depression, that I am actually afraid of what I might do to myself if I continue to hide from this.\n\n  I am hoping to start taking testosterone soon, so you will start to see some physical changes, including deepening of the voice, increased hair growth, and a general change in body shape (due largely to a redistribution of body fat). I realize this will be a lot to take in, and that it may be difficult to see me looking like a completely different person. I also realize that you may be afraid that I am going to have a more difficult life because of my trans identity. This may indeed be the case. I am not coming out because I think it‚Äôs going to make my life perfect. I am also not coming out so that I can get your blessing ‚Äì I am well aware that this is going to be incredibly difficult for you to accept, and that you only have my best interest at heart when you feel inclined to oppose my transition. I am coming out because I feel that I have no other choice if I am to live a full, happy life. \n\nI am truly sorry for any heartache this likely causes you. Please know that it causes me just as much heartache to know that I have to run the risk of losing my family in order to be true to myself. If it would help you, I would love to set up a session with my therapist ‚Äì we could speak either over the phone or via Skype (I can easily explain to you how it works, so don‚Äôt worry about not knowing how to use it). If you feel that you would be uncomfortable with that, please know that I am always open to answer any questions you may have about this. I also have several resources that may help you to understand both what I am going through and how you can navigate it as my parents. I want you to be informed, but I didn‚Äôt include any of the resources I have available to me here because I don‚Äôt want you to feel as though I am forcing any of it down your throat ‚Äì I want to be sure that it is information you are seeking on your own.\n\nPlease know that I love you, and that without you in my life, I would be lost.\n\nWith love,\n\nAshton","can_reply":false}]

00:04:01 GMT","timestamp":1410480241,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"yhiC0Ju7","tags":["trans","transgender","affectation","presentation","trans women","i had a metaphor i wanted to work in but it didn't fit within the flow so i left it out","for another time i guess"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-CYhu1Qb4Ks4","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"I‚Äôve been working on my voice, when I remember, in my car. I sit there for the thirty minutes or so of my commute and talk to myself. In fact, a sort of first draft, an oral version, of what I‚Äôm about to write came from today‚Äôs monologue.\n\nIt‚Äôs feels very strange and I feel very silly talking to myself the whole way home. When I pull up to a stoplight, or the traffic slows so that people can see clearly into my car, I stop talking and go into my pod people routine‚Äîyou know, emotionless so no one suspects you haven‚Äôt been taken. All of this is enough to make it difficult to even practice. But it‚Äôs not really the most difficult part. I mean, who really gives a fuck if some stranger sees me talking to myself? Besides, they probably just think I have a phone on speaker or am a weirdo‚Äîeither of which is fine.\n\nNo, the difficult part is hearing myself. Not because it‚Äôs bad, though sometimes it is. Mostly I can do a pretty good female sounding voice. I‚Äôve always had a knack for altering my speech patterns and accents and impersonations‚Äîtoo much time watching SNL growing up or something. I can do a girl voice. And a lot of times it sounds natural and good and exactly how I desire (basically equally adept at talking about postmodern fiction and some dumb reality show on MTV).\n\nBut it is not me. Not yet. It is an affectation. A put on. An act. And sure, that‚Äôs to be expected. With practice it should become easier and more natural. And really what the fuck, right. I mean, of course it is an affectation‚ÄîI need to affect this voice before I can have this voice. I‚Äôm not going to wake up sounding how I want tomorrow (though that would lead to some questions for my students if I did).\n\nSo why was I so hung up on this? Why was I so ashamed by the simple fact that I was trying? Red Durkin had a great post on this the other day too, about actively trying to not do things that would be construed as trying to pass and just the messed up head space you‚Äôre in when you try to navigate all this. It‚Äôs all this internalized transmisogyny and how it leads to these totally skewed thought processes. If I am trying to be a woman then I am not really a woman because women don‚Äôt have to try to be women, you think yourself into a corner.\n\nI bought a sports bra, a dress, and a belt a few weeks back. I don‚Äôt need any of them yet. The sports bra is sort of hedging against getting lucky early on and needing to hide a couple things in my male presentation. The others were a treat. I wanted girl clothes. I wanted clothes for me, because I felt fucking shitty with the coming school year and looking for shirts that were just another fucking reminder that every damn day starts with a lie to the world. But even though I don‚Äôt own any underwear, I bought the dress and the belt. Even though I wouldn‚Äôt have anything to put under it, I bought the dress. I bought it first because I felt strange as I thought about buying underwear. I couldn‚Äôt do it. It‚Äôs such a tired fucking cliche, the women‚Äôs underwear. And it felt like a confirmation of all the shitty stuff people say about trans women, that we‚Äôre just doing it for the thrills, that I needed to actively avoid it even though ABSOLUTELY NO ONE WILL KNOW WHAT I AM BUYING! And here‚Äôs a thing: women buy underwear every fucking day. It‚Äôs one of those things that literally everyone needs to do.\n\nI could buy the sports bra, because that I could legitimize in my mind as being utilitarian. It serves a purpose. I may need it in order to continue to look male.\n\nReread that last sentence. That one is the key here.\n\nMy everyday voice, my masculine voice, is a total fucking affectation. It is one that was gained through hours and hours of practice. Just in this case it was all unconscious. It was steered there by all the expectations and pressures that come with wanting to not be read as trans. It is just as constructed as my fem voice will be. Even what my voice is shifts throughout the day‚Äîas a teacher who talks in front of crowds a lot, I actively consider my voice and alter my speaking patterns all the fucking time. But when I don‚Äôt challenge the masculine assumption, when I don‚Äôt invite the criticism of the patriarchal response to a fem voice that resides in my own head, then it is assumed to be ‚Äúauthentic‚Äù or ‚Äúnatural.‚Äù\n\nIt is all presentation and it is all authentic. But when we look at how women affect their presentation suddenly it becomes artificial. We roundly criticize the use of make-up in our culture‚Äîthink of all the stupid shit people say about liking a girl who doesn‚Äôt wear make-up‚Äîas being false. We value the honesty of a ‚Äúnatural‚Äù look. We also criticize those who reject this. Every paparazzi photo of a women without make-up ought to just read ‚ÄúWhat will the menz think when they see your face!‚Äù Women must present themselves for the male gaze, but still maintain the respectable standards men set. And of course make-up is for men, as every makeover special reminds us‚Äîhowever will you find a man if you don‚Äôt look pretty! Make-up couldn‚Äôt be for self-expression, or to attract women, or to feel confident in yourself. All these same little thoughts can be put there for voice, dress, whatever. And we could extend the logic along the axis of race instead of gender and see how the culture paints people of color as putting more effort into their appearance than white people. The dominant structure claims it is real and authentic and therefore all others should act either in aspiration or response. But that‚Äôs bullshit. It‚Äôs all a fucking act, and it‚Äôs all real.\n\nAnd by all, I mean all. That includes the slob dudes in their ratty t-shirts. That is an affectation‚Äîthey are telling the world exactly what they do and do not care for. My brother was telling me once how he liked shopping at Costco because there‚Äôs no design, it‚Äôs barebones and because of that he knew their full focus was on just getting the job done. The Costco, in other words, was dressed like him. Plain jeans and a t-shirt, just going to work. It‚Äôs not as if Costco could have contemplated the look of their stores and considered the effect of design and decided that this exact look would convey the exact message my brother received. No, design was an unnecessary detail only. Ornamentation. All that frilly crap. But that‚Äôs a false dichotomy. It‚Äôs all design, and it is all an act. Sometimes it‚Äôs conscious, as with my voice, and sometimes it‚Äôs unconscious, as with my brother‚Äôs jeans and tee look.\n\nSo fuck those who tell you you are anything but real or try to tell you how you are unnatural. We are all natural and real and fake and artificial in equal measure. Trans women have just as much right to try on a look or a voice or anything as anyone else. Giving effort is not a sign of a lack of substance. It does not compromise our identity.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"anemicroyaltee","id":97258321912,"post_url":"http://anemicroyaltee.tumblr.com/post/97258321912/tomorrow-i-think-im-going-to-wear-my-lgbt-pride","slug":"tomorrow-i-think-im-going-to-wear-my-lgbt-pride","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 23:59:31 GMT","timestamp":1410479971,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"xd9nIzvA","tags":["lgbt","lgbt pride","gay","trans","transsexual"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZbrnCt1Qb33Vu","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"tomorrow i think im going to wear my LGBT pride shirt as a way of SLOWLY coming out. i hope no one says anything negative.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lgbtqblogs","id":97258300659,"post_url":"http://lgbtqblogs.tumblr.com/post/97258300659/we-need-a-national-conversation-about","slug":"we-need-a-national-conversation-about","type":"quote","date":"2014-09-11 23:59:12 GMT","timestamp":1410479952,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"L3HnTJBH","tags":["trans","transgender","trans*","lgbtq","lgbtq news","lgbt","lgbtq current events","lgbtqia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZBCnOy1Qb2_Jp","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":153,"text":"We need a national conversation about transphobia, which dehumanizes, demeans and disadvantages a specific group of people. Wait - WHAT?!?!?! How the FUCK can a fucking LESBIAN be in a happy romantic relationship with a MAN?!?!?!?! The answer is simple: her lesbianism is mostly physical. She is sexually attracted to her husband's female genitalia. For that reason, he is not going to change his sexual organs. He may undergo hormonal therapy, but his organs will remain untouched as long as they are married, in order to accommodate her lesbianism. Do you have any suggestions for how to stop feeling that way? The only way I really ever stop feeling like that is when I'm trying hard to be masculine.","answer":"Zak: I feel that way a lot. I don‚Äôt really have an answer for how to make it better, although one major thing that has helped me is just paying attention to other guys and realizing that there isn‚Äôt one set standard for masculinity. Yeah, I might cross my legs in a way that I feel is too feminine, but there are also plenty of other guys out there who cross their legs that way (or gesture when they talk, or call things ‚Äúadorable,‚Äù or whatever). Some of it is just self-acceptance. I‚Äôve kind of come to terms with the fact that I‚Äôm not a super masculine guy and I‚Äôll probably never be one. This self-policing is pretty common, though, I think. We feel like we need to prove/justify our genders to the rest of the world, and even to ourselves. Ideally, though, we should just be able to be ourselves without having to worry about it.\n\nTrans guys aren‚Äôt the only ones carefully policing their genders and worrying about this stuff, I‚Äôve met plenty of cis guys who are also concerned about coming off as too feminine. It‚Äôs practically an epidemic. So, I‚Äôd say try to find a way to accept the more feminine things about yourself and relax about it. [{"blog_name":"forevertestosteronemofo","id":97251401997,"post_url":"http://forevertestosteronemofo.tumblr.com/post/97251401997/i-was-getting-tired-of-people-misgendering-me","slug":"i-was-getting-tired-of-people-misgendering-me","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 22:24:41 GMT","timestamp":1410474281,"state":"published","format":"markdown","reblog_key":"Fzbf5fCg","tags":["ftm","trans","transgender","misgendering"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zd9p8t1Qaeg4D","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"title":"","body":"i was getting tired of people misgendering me. today i finally told someone that i was a boy, and that i wasn‚Äôt a girl. she responded with ‚Äúhow?‚Äù. when i told her i was trans and explained what that was, she said ‚Äúso you‚Äôre still a girl‚Äù. i told her i wasn‚Äôt, and then she asked me what my ‚Äúreal name‚Äù was. when i told her it was Riley, she refused to use he/him/his pronouns, and refused to let go of the fact that Riley ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt my name‚Äù and that i ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt a boy‚Äù\n\nthen she proceeded to tell me that she doesn‚Äôt judge anybody and respects people. no. just‚Ä¶ no.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"bigbadbaeddelborgs","id":97251295040,"post_url":"http://bigbadbaeddelborgs.tumblr.com/post/97251295040/manhood-trans-men-are-suspicious-when-you-have","slug":"manhood-trans-men-are-suspicious-when-you-have","type":"quote","date":"2014-09-11 22:23:17 GMT","timestamp":1410474197,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"O53r9CPd","tags":["transmasculine","trans men","ftm","trans","feminism"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zg3ham1QaeFz0","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"text":"Manhood\n\nTrans men are suspicious. When you have trans men, a population marginalised both for being trans and for having experienced a semi-marginalised status from their assignment at birth, the shocking incidence of misogyny, transmisogyny, MRA-esque bullshittery, ‚Äútruscummery‚Äù, a much higher rate of heterosexuality than trans women3 (55% versus 27%) ‚Äì which is, especially male heterosexuality, a patriarchal institution ‚Äì and general chauvinistic grotesqueness, I can‚Äôt help but start to question this state of affairs. What‚Äôs causing this? Bigotry is so much more endemic in trans men‚Äôs communities than should be expected of similarly marginalised groups. There‚Äôs definitely something going on, and I‚Äôm not intellectually lazy enough to presume mere accident.\n\nJust like there‚Äôs no such thing as a non-exploitative bourgeoisie, there‚Äôs no such thing as a non-sexist man, so how exactly do you sit down and think about gender then reach the conclusion that misogyny and exploiting women is the thing for you? Trans maleness, by definition, means overt identification with manhood and the decision to join the ranks of the patriarchs. The political and social signals that ‚Äúmoving into manhood‚Äù sends are not desirable at all. Having been on the receiving end of manhood from birth, cis men aren‚Äôt moving into it like trans men are, and are maybe not by necessity as active a participant in maleness as them.\n\nThe trans men who feel bodily dysphoria should absolutely and in no way be denied any opportunity to get that fixed (I understand that pain all too well), but critical self-examination is still required, manhood is still fundamentally and irredeemably a reactionary identity and social position. Does fixing bodily dysphoria require active identification with maleness? I don‚Äôt think so, and I don‚Äôt think that someone wanting to move into that space should be entirely trusted either.\n\nIt‚Äôs highly hypocritical on the part of trans activists to at once state that social conditions (transphobia, transmisogyny) are a deterrent to transition, but in the same breath say that social conditions (male privilege, for trans men) aren‚Äôt an incentive to transition. Trans men, upon transition, get a pay rise,4 after all.\n\nThe only progressive way forward is for men ‚Äì cis and trans alike ‚Äì to strive to give up manhood, to abdicate their patriarchal throne. To consciously decide to fight sexism at every opportunity and to disassociate as much as possible from their privileged position, masculinity, and exploitation of women. To try and undermine their own social position at every turn. Progressive men should stop trying to envision a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù manhood or a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù masculinity; men hurt themselves, other men, women, and non-men when they assert their masculinity, and they should stop trying to imagine ways to redeem themselves without fundamental change.\n\nJust like I strive to give up and end my position and the category of first world labour aristocrat, my position of whiteness, and my position of physical abledness, I call on men to strive to give up manhood. It doesn‚Äôt mean I shrug off the label ‚Äúwhite‚Äù or ‚Äúlabour aristocrat‚Äù, just the positioning of those identities as good, or at worst neutral. It means that I recognise that they are fundamentally oppressive social positions and that the only possible use for them are as political organising labels and for the recognition of my own privilege.\n\nThe call for the abolishment of gender isn‚Äôt quite correct, or at least requires a bit more nuance and elaboration. Women and men are not the problem, to be abolished on equal terms, it‚Äôs men who are the main problem. That‚Äôs where we need to focus our energy. You don‚Äôt abolish classes by trying to abolish the proletariat and the bourgeoisie both together, no, you focus on the bourgeoisie. You focus on the exploiters and the dominant class in the dialectic ‚Äì you abolish men first and foremost.\n\nWomanhood\n\nWomanhood and manhood are defined by their existence through each other and their violent struggle against one another. You can‚Äôt have one without the other, a contradiction (and an antagonistic one at that) in dialectics parlance. One is the struggle of the oppressed and one the struggle of the oppressor. It‚Äôs for this reason that a trans woman identifying with womanhood is fundamentally different from a trans man identifying with manhood. One is the reflexive cry of the downtrodden, and the other can be an angry request to be let into the exploiter clubhouse.\n\nWhen I say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a woman‚Äù I‚Äôm not saying I innately ‚Äúfeel like a woman‚Äù (I don‚Äôt think you can ever construct a non-patirarchal justification for that), I‚Äôm instead relating myself to other women and our shared experience as a class under patriarchy. I‚Äôm stating that my material interests and experience of the world are aligned with womanhood; my liberation is therefore fundamentally and intimately bound up with other women, and thus as far as I‚Äôm concerned, ‚Äúwoman‚Äù describes me.\n\nI ‚Äúidentify‚Äù with womanhood because it describes my political experience. It‚Äôs the category, or near enough (‚Äúgenderfreakhood‚Äù is also pertinent), that is imposed on me. Like the other oppressive social constructs ‚Äì blackness or queerness for example ‚Äì identification with them isn‚Äôt reification, but a recognition of the political and social reality of other‚Äôs reification of the concept.\n\nMy birth designation doesn‚Äôt matter. When I‚Äôm walking down the street, people gender me as ‚Äúnot male‚Äù, as a woman, and it makes me uneasy. When people spew biotruths or make sexist jokes, I know it‚Äôs aimed at me. When I see women objectified over and over and over again, I can‚Äôt help but learn to hate myself. When I hear about rampant rape, sexual assault, and general violence, I wonder, might I become one of those statistics? Even before I transitioned and started changing my body, the sexism I encountered was still generally aimed at people of a body type I needed for my health. Whenever I interact with a man there‚Äôs always a nagging in the back of my mind, how are gender relations coloring this interaction? Again and again, I constantly face misogyny ‚Äì I face womanhood.\n\nIt‚Äôs for this reason there are little points of unity between trans men/some CAFAB gendequeers (those who benefit from transmisogyny) and trans women/those who face transmisgoyny. I have a lot more in common with cis women than I do the majority of trans men. When CAFAB trans people talk about their relationship to ‚Äútrans‚Äù and ‚Äúgender‚Äù, it‚Äôs quite often in a decidedly ‚Äúnon-political‚Äù or non-radical manner. This isn‚Äôt how I feel about being a woman, my womanhood is strictly political.\n\nFor many trans men their transness is some kind of ‚Äúsubversive‚Äù gender performance, some sort of flight of fancy (to put it perhaps a little crudely). They adopt ‚Äúhe/his‚Äù pronouns and change their haircut and clothing in a limited capacity, and then just go on with their lives, coming first in the oppression olympics, winning various book deals, getting a multitude of spoken word performance awards, and so on, all on the backs of trans women (mostly of color).","source":"Trans People and the Dialectics of Sex and Gender: Against Radical and Liberal Feminism","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"pagingmisspage","id":97250650553,"post_url":"http://pagingmisspage.tumblr.com/post/97250650553/at-a-car-dealership-up-in-ocala-shooting-a-spot","slug":"at-a-car-dealership-up-in-ocala-shooting-a-spot","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 22:14:33 GMT","timestamp":1410473673,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"1Hcs4M5X","tags":["transgender","trans","dmab","amab","maab","mtf","male to female","transition","daily life of a trans woman"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZP9ewn1Qabocv","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":7,"caption":"At a car dealership up in Ocala shooting a spot for a news business program. I was never allowed to get men‚Äôs body wash or deodorant because my mother does not believe a ‚Äòwoman‚Äô like me should be using it. Now that I, and my partner, have money, we‚Äôre able to buy me things that I‚Äôve only wished I could get for a while.\n\nI‚Äôve had such a desensitized feeling towards women‚Äôs clothing now because of how long I had to wear them. Even though I‚Äôm a taller biological female, and have large feet (Usually a size 11.5 in women‚Äôs, USA), my mother always went out of her way to buy me women‚Äôs sneakers and such. Now that I own my very own men‚Äôs sneakers and my own socks that I didn‚Äôt have to steal from my brothers‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs honestly nice. You would never think a person would get so emotional or happy over getting a new pair of tennis shoes or a new wallet that actually fit who they feel like.\n\nBeing able to look at your face and see more of a man through your clothing and your accessories is a life saving feeling to me. After being able to throw away all those women‚Äôs clothing, it almost feels so surreal to be able to basically not wear any female clothing or have any female accessories anymore, but in a good way.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"prudence-lana","id":97249990273,"post_url":"http://prudence-lana.tumblr.com/post/97249990273/why-i-dont-need-surgery-to-be-transgender","slug":"why-i-dont-need-surgery-to-be-transgender","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 22:05:53 GMT","timestamp":1410473153,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"reSCYmp1","tags":["mtf","trans","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z03e6n1QaZHQ1","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"title":"Why I don't need surgery to be transgender.","body":"<!-- more -->\n\nIn the year 2000, a young boy puts on his clothes and eats his lunch. He is thinking hard about himself, something he‚Äôll continue to do a lot in his life. The boy turns to his mom and says ‚ÄúMommy, I want to be a girl.‚Äù\n\nThe mom, being a conservative Christian at that time, says it‚Äôs not possible. So the boy grows up to 15 before these feelings show themselves consciously again.\n\nThis boy notices that through his entire life, he‚Äôs always been girlish, from his personality right down to his slender curvy build. He notices that he‚Äôs always wanted to be ‚Äúone of the girls‚Äù ever since he got friends in his old town.\n\nThe boy is long gone from the suburban town where he lived as a three year old. Now he is in a big city and his parents have converted from Christianity to Atheism. So this boy, after speaking with a very special friend about what being transgender is, begins to have the thought: ‚ÄúWhat if I‚Äôm just masquerading as a boy?‚Äù\n\nIn that moment, it dawned on her. She is a girl. She never expected it coming, but she could feel the glass defog and she saw herself clearly. This is what her identity was missing. This is why she felt incomplete before. Because she was born without the right equipment.\n\nHer friends and family were mainly supportive and she is extremely thankful for that. But one surgery she gets asked often is, ‚ÄúAre you going to get surgery?‚Äù\n\nNow, at first she dodged this question by saying she didn‚Äôt know. But she did heavily consider it. When she factored in all the money, time, and effort that this surgery would take, she knew that she would be completely happy with a penis.\n\nSome people tell her ‚ÄúYou aren‚Äôt trans unless you are transitioning!‚Äù but they don‚Äôt understand that she is transitioning. Her identity as presented to other people is transitioning. The parent-son relationship she once had with her parents is changing into a parent-daughter one. Her life is transitioning from how she used to live, to how she truly wants to live.\n\nSo yes, she is transitioning everything except the physical aspects. And that‚Äôs her choice. It makes her no less of a woman than any other woman on Earth. She is an MtF transgender person.\n\nNow it‚Äôs 2014, and she is happily living as a girl. She has been fully accepted by her parents and all of her friends support her. A few still misgender or use her old name, but it happens so rarely (and almost always accidental) that she doesn‚Äôt even get upset anymore. She is finally secure with herself.\n\nI hope you have all learned something from my experience and have a lovely [{"blog_name":"k-con","id":97245099012,"post_url":"http://k-con.tumblr.com/post/97245099012/do-you-have-sensation-in-your-nipples-i-had-peri-but","slug":"do-you-have-sensation-in-your-nipples-i-had-peri-but","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-11 21:02:00 GMT","timestamp":1410469320,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"vbeUH2bs","tags":["Top surgery","queer","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zvndbw1QaGdG4","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":7,"asking_name":"mean1mrgrinch","asking_url":"http://mean1mrgrinch.tumblr.com/","question":"Do you have sensation in your nipples? I had peri but I'm curious because I was told by my surgeon it would be lost permanently with double incision.","answer":"One of my biggest fears going into surgery, aside from death, was the fact that I would permanently lose sensation in my chest. I was really afraid of waking up to a permanent state of chest numbness. Fortunately, those fears turned out to be unfounded!\n\nMy nipples don‚Äôt become erect anymore but they can seriously feel everything! It definitely feels different but for me, it‚Äôs a better different! Before surgery, my nipple sensations felt awkward and not the least bit arousing.\n\nNow, I find nipple stimulation to be quite pleasurable. My nips are totally an erogenous zone. Most sensations are brain powered anyway. For example, people with paralysis still experience erections. At this point in time, my nips might have less nerves than most, but they are still alive and full of sensation!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"teddywolfsong","id":97245081214,"post_url":"http://teddywolfsong.tumblr.com/post/97245081214/im-an-angry-vulcan-baby-trans-gay-transboy","slug":"im-an-angry-vulcan-baby-trans-gay-transboy","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 said:\n\nHow long on T did it take for your voice to drop? How much did it drop, and can you still reach your higher register?\n\nGood question! \n\nWithin a couple days of starting Testosterone I developed a cold. From that point on, my voice changed. It didn‚Äôt necessarily sound deeper, it was just different. Listening to old recordings, I‚Äôd say my voice started sounding noticeably deeper around 6 months on Testosterone.\n\nAt this point, I can‚Äôt reach the higher registers that I once could‚Ä¶ but my voice is still pretty high, considering. I‚Äôve included a clip of my voice today, for future reference. I‚Äôve got a cold so I sound a lot more nasally than usual.\n\nAccording to the Endocrine Society‚Äôs Clinical Guidelines for the Treatment of Transsexual Persons, the voice starts deepening around 6-12 months. The Endocrine Society has a timeline of the ‚ÄúMasculinizing effects in FTM transsexual persons,‚Äù which I‚Äôve opted to include below. \n\nHope this helps!","player":"<embed type=\"application/x-shockwave-flash\" src=\"http://assets.tumblr.com/swf/audio_player.swf?audio_file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tumblr.com%2Faudio_file%2Fk-con%2F97242968907%2Ftumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo&color=FFFFFF\" height=\"27\" width=\"207\" quality=\"best\" wmode=\"opaque\"></embed>","embed":"<iframe class=\"tumblr_audio_player tumblr_audio_player_97242968907\" src=\"http://k-con.tumblr.com/post/97242968907/audio_player_iframe/k-con/tumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo?audio_file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tumblr.com%2Faudio_file%2Fk-con%2F97242968907%2Ftumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo\" frameborder=\"0\" allowtransparency=\"true\" scrolling=\"no\" width=\"500\" height=\"85\"></iframe>","plays":100,"audio_url":"https://www.tumblr.com/audio_file/k-con/97242968907/tumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo","audio_type":"tumblr","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"brandonrandy","id":97242973030,"post_url":"http://brandonrandy.tumblr.com/post/97242973030/top-surgery-thoughts","slug":"top-surgery-thoughts","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 20:35:04 GMT","timestamp":1410467704,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"8glCqSiB","tags":["ftm","top surgery","garramone","transgender","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zty5Gt1Qa8WDc","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"Top Surgery Thoughts","body":"When I first began my transition I paged through top surgery results and always seemed to land on the same doctor, Garramone. Every time I would see a guy‚Äôs chest that I had thought had come out particularly well they had always gone to him. So, it seemed an obvious choice once I found out he was only a couple hours from where I lived. How convenient is that?\n\nI‚Äôve been spending the last fifteen months saving money for surgery, and at this point, I have about a third of it ready to go. That‚Äôs enough to at least book. To pick a date, and get myself prepared/save the rest of the money.\n\nBut for some reason, I haven‚Äôt made the call. I can‚Äôt really explain it. I don‚Äôt have a particular reason. I guess maybe there‚Äôs this part of me that just cannot imagine that I am about to spend this much money. I‚Äôm not really the type to buy big ticket items for myself. I see this price tag in my head as a new car, a down payment on a modest house, a way to invest in the future.\n\nI keep thinking, what if I hold out a little longer? Maybe I could get medical insurance that will cover my surgeries. Then, I start thinking about the process of waiting for that kind of approval, finding a new doctor, possibly ending up with horrible results. It‚Äôs a lot to reconsider on a timeline that may or may not even exist as a possibility. There‚Äôs no guarantee insurance will ever cover transgender surgeries.\n\nThere‚Äôs the picking a new doctor aspect of it to- I mean, who‚Äôs to even say I made the ‚Äúright‚Äù choice, no one is flawless. Dr. G does great work, obviously, but there‚Äôs this part of me that knows I only get one shot at this. If something doesn‚Äôt heal quite right it doesn‚Äôt look like he‚Äôs much into revisions unless you‚Äôre ready to shell out another $8,000. But who‚Äôs stuff is better and within such a close distance to my current location? No one as far as I know.\n\nAs many concerns as I have regarding the surgery itself, anesthesia, pain, everything- overall, if it weren‚Äôt for the money this would already be done. So that line of thinking leaves me wondering- now that it looks like saving this money may be possible, what ultimately is keeping me from making this call? Why do I feel so guilty about doing something I know will make me a happier and more well-adjusted person?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"bumpulp","id":97242796456,"post_url":"http://bumpulp.tumblr.com/post/97242796456/i-always-think-i-have-my-shit-so-figured-out-and","slug":"i-always-think-i-have-my-shit-so-figured-out-and","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 20:32:49 GMT","timestamp":1410467569,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Gm1H41WV","tags":["i need help","what is self acceptance even","trans","help me","suicide tw","self harm tw","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zi2Mom1Qa7r6e","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"I always think I have my shit so figured out and I‚Äôm soo comfortable with who I am but i think actually\n\nI‚Äôve just learned how to be comfortable being male and I never learned how to be comfortable with being trans and that might be like an important thing to do maybe but I don‚Äôt know how??\n\nbecause actually i‚Äôm still like how do i do the trans thing without killing/hurting myself???\n\nand like i‚Äôm pretty sure I dont want to kill myself buuut","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"atlasvertebra","id":97242549074,"post_url":"http://atlasvertebra.tumblr.com/post/97242549074/more-ugh-i-dunno-actually-blogging-makes-me","slug":"more-ugh-i-dunno-actually-blogging-makes-me","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 20:29:36 GMT","timestamp":1410467376,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"gfdePrqj","tags":["trans","dysphoria"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-xiZm1Qa6ujI","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"<!-- more -->\n\nugh I dunno, actually blogging makes me feel a bit better, having somewhere to go with my love of the stuff I blog about and my trans and asperger‚Äôs feelings\n\nbecause, like‚Ä¶. Transphobia","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lgbtqblogs","id":97240681216,"post_url":"http://lgbtqblogs.tumblr.com/post/97240681216/angelica-ross-the-dynamic-entrepreneur-who","slug":"angelica-ross-the-dynamic-entrepreneur-who","type":"video","date":"2014-09-11 events","lgbtqia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZBCnOy1QZ-mi0","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":94,"caption":"Angelica Ross ‚Äî the dynamic entrepreneur who recently founded Chicago-based nonprofit TransTech ‚Äî has personally seen the best and worst of what a transgender person can face on the job market.\n\nThat‚Äôs why she started TransTech, which will offer a training academy and apprenticeships for aspiring trans web developers and graphic designers this Fall.\n\n\"TransTech emerged from my story, [which] is the same story for so many trans women of color,\" Ross tells The Advocate. ‚ÄúWhen I began my transition, I was fired from my job, estranged from my family, and introduced to sex work and the adult industry.‚Äù\n\nSoon the technologically-inclined Ross decided to teach herself web coding and graphic design, and was able to become successfully self-employed as a freelancer.\n\n\"Over the course of 10 years ‚Ä¶ I discovered technology as a path to independence for trans people. I no longer had to face on-the-job discrimination and harassment if I didn‚Äôt want to,\" she explained. \"I could log-in and make money without people caring about what I look or sound like.\"\n\nHer experiences with Internet freelancing, as an Apple employee, and a stint in beauty school planted the seed for TransTech, which is now becoming a reality through help from an Indiegogo fundraiser.\n\n\"It is my mission to make TransTech the Apple of the nonprofit industry!\" Ross says.\n\nMore specifically, the project‚Äôs ultimate goal is to empower trans attendees to become self-employed independent contractors in the tech industry. Apprentices will accomplish this by practicing their skills in a training setting, similar to beauty school students. Customers will pay an affordable rate for web and graphic design, and apprentices will be able to earn income; any extra profit will be used by TransTech to continue the next cycle of apprenticeships.\n\nRoss says tht the program‚Äôs unique setup came to her after she began observing other employment programs in Chicago. ‚Äú[They] were focusing heavily on training people for food service jobs or manual labor jobs,‚Äù she recalls. ‚ÄúThe attitude was that tech skills would be over-the-heads of the populations typically served by social services. But I knew for a fact this wasn‚Äôt true, and I set out to prove it.‚Äù\n\nTech skills are, Ross believes, going to be increasingly in-demand in our tech-savvy world. She hopes TransTech will set its participants up for ‚Äúeconomic improvement,‚Äù and help ease the ‚Äúextreme levels of poverty, discrimination, harassment, and violence towards the trans community, especially trans women of color.‚Äù\n\nShe refers to this approach as ‚Äúsocial enterprise:‚Äù the maximization of both individual and community well-being, rather than profit. In the video below, she beams with confidence at how needed a program like TransTech is at a time like this. Trans community advocates ‚Äî including Trans*H4CK founder Dr. Kortney Ryan Ziegler, coder Naomi Ceder, and GLAAD Media Strategist Tiq Milan ‚Äî have agreed, coming out on social media in vocal support of the nonprofit.\n\nRoss‚Äô only lament so far, she says, is her inability to do more. ‚ÄúWe have received roughly 30 applications and they are still pouring in; my email and phone are bombarded by hopeful apprentices,‚Äù she tells The Advocate. ‚ÄúBut we can only afford to enroll 2 people [in the first session], which breaks my heart.‚Äù\n\n\"That‚Äôs why,\" she concludes, \"even though we are only looking to raise $15,000 to get us through the first 12-week apprenticeship, I am hoping the rest of the community understands how much of a difference TransTech can make in the lives of trans people and the LGBT community as a whole.\"\n\n\"The more money we raise, the more trans people we can enroll, pay, and set on the path to independence.\"","permalink_url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MAkIrmcgMoY","html5_capable":true,"thumbnail_url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/MAkIrmcgMoY/hqdefault.jpg","thumbnail_width":480,"thumbnail_height":360,"player":[{"width":250,"embed_code":"<iframe 18:08:00 GMT","timestamp":1410458880,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"MmZOKcSj","tags":["radfem","trans","TERF","libfem","feminism","women","gender","What is"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z6gxtx1QZXmxS","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":55,"title":"What is: To feel like a woman or a man","body":"Regarding why trans people say things like:\n\nI have always felt like a woman\nor\nI have always felt like a man\nor\nI have always felt like I am not a woman or a man\nor\nI have always felt like a woman and a man\n\nor similar expressions of such, what they are trying to express in colloquial and layman‚Äôs terms is the concepts of sex identity and gender identity.\n\nNow that is Two (2) concepts, each distinct, heavily conflated, because in layman‚Äôs and colloquial terms, they are readily intertwined and intermingled in actual life. \n\nRoughly translated, the whole thing means that a Trans person is aware that they are a woman, man, both, or neither, at the same core level as they are aware of themselves as a person, distinct from other people.\n\nSome people, primarily those who are ignorant and misinformed of what these concepts are, or who apply their own prejudice towards trans people and thereby discount 60+ years of proven science, would prefer to argue that what this is suggesting is that there is a ‚Äúbrain sex‚Äù ‚Äî and yet, that‚Äôs not what this is describing.\n\nIt is describing a sense of self-awareness ‚Äî which, while decidedly part of the brain‚Äôs physiology, is really part of the existential notion that one exists, and therefore is not part of that argument, nor even related directly to biological systems.\n\nThis is important to note, because what it means is that when someone talks to or about a trans person about this and says things like ‚Äúdo you mean it is about clothing, or about sexual intercourse, or about physiological process or genitals‚Äù or similar stuff, they are being fundamentally dishonest and deceitful, and displaying their ignorance and incompetence because they do not understand what the trans person is saying to them, and therefore not listening, and so are talking about something other than the actual concept being discussed.\n\nThese questions are a form of gaslighting of trans people, and seeks to corrupt and twist the words of trans people for the purpose of furthering their oppression, not proving something ‚Äútrue‚Äù about trans people, since they have nothing to do with the idea being expressed, which is that the trans person exists.\n\nFurthermore, if these people do not, themselves, have the ability to say what it means to them to feel like a woman, it is incredibly difficult for them to be honestly making a judgement about someone else‚Äôs understanding of themselves.\n\nThis is like looking at a person and telling them they are actually a dog, and they know they are a dog, but not willing to admit it. Seems pretty nasty, doesn‚Äôt it?\n\nTrans people are not immune to this ‚Äî and indeed, often when pushed, trans people will resort to all manner of reactions and arguments and justifications for this because they often are no more knowledgeable about this than anyone else.\n\nWhat that means, as well, is that this description has nothing whatsoever to do with biology, and therefore arguments about biology aren‚Äôt valid when contradicting it.\n\nIt would be akin to saying that the United States Army shouldn‚Äôt exist because of broccoli.\n\nThis all comes together in the core aspect here: like sexual orientation, this is part of what creates the sense of self in people, and it therefore is part of how they know that they exist as an individual human being, and is a part of that.\n\nSo the same question of how you know can be answered in as many different ways as there are people, and it is the still same way that those asking the question know what their social sex identity is.\n\nThis effectively makes it the trans version of the question ‚Äúhow do you know you are gay?‚Äù, with the same accurate answer of ‚ÄúI just do, because I know I exist.‚Äù\n\nThe answer may not satisfy those seeking some sort of concrete answer, but it is inevitable that they themselves will discount any answer because for them the same question remains unanswered in a way they would accept from a trans person, usually due to cis privilege.\n\nSo asking the question, especially in a venue such as Tumblr, is a form of logical fallacy and a trap, meant to defame and ridicule and provide justification for hate speech and violence against trans people.\n\n  This is especially a common tactic among transphobes, who can be identified using expressions described here.\n\nDO be sure to reference the links earlier in this post, as it is a part of the What is I‚Äôm stuck in a binary mindset that I totally can‚Äôt seem to shake. It sucks because like I am totally not trying to be ignorant or hurtful. \n\nSince being out full time I have gotten the stares and the glares, but for the most part I don‚Äôt have confrontation or get misgendered‚Ä¶ I know that I don‚Äôt have an ideal female figure coming from an hyper-masculine athletic guy being in the infantry, but I haven‚Äôt let that limit me in being me. It also helps that I was able to change my voice psychologically and it clearly passes as feminine. \n\nI still have to try to pull off male which I fail at for the army and I get gendered correctly (female) when I am trying to pull off an infantry soldier (only males) which in turn makes some people weird with me. \n\nI totally don‚Äôt know what I am ranting about anymore as I can was continually interrupted in making the post. *sigh*\n\nI guess I just wish that even though I know that the trans community is a minority in the public and in society that it wasn‚Äôt so feudal and butt hurt amongst itself as with others. Seeing things like die cis scum and transphobes or transphobia makes feel irksome amongst the community. I know that we aren‚Äôt accepted for the most part and that some of us come from cis privilege still expecting that privilege, but like sometimes you gotta just except what it is that you are giving up to be true to yourself. Like it sucks how many friends and how much family I have lost and it sucks that I continually have to face hardships not only within myself, but in public as being trans is hard, but like I don‚Äôt think that it is right to whine so hard that the world doesn‚Äôt accept you. Even if you were born cis most likely the world would seem like it is against you with every step that you take. Life is hard regardless. Trans just makes it even more harder, but once you free yourself from the constraints of everything that is holding you back you need to realize that is strength in itself. You might never truly pass, I might never fully pass, we all might never fully pass, but that is alright. As long as we live true to ourselves and try to be the best versions of ourselves we can make it in this world and we can be accepted by society. The first step is accepting ourselves and realizing that is who that matters at the end of the day. \n\nWith the current state that the trans community is at I fully believe that even though I am a part of it, I know that until it changes and becomes a source of power and support, that I don‚Äôt want to be involved with it because the backlash of trying to be proud for representing as trans in your own way seems to offend people who have different views or beliefs on what it means to be trans. In destroying the gender binary and realizing that there is many ways to being we have to realize that not everyone will look at how to be who they are the same way you are. \n\nI‚Äôm femme, I like girly things and try to live up to certain stereotypes. I am ok with that. I am ok with society the way it is. I am ok that I know I am going to have to fight for every inch that I can get in the world. I am ok with the fact that some people won‚Äôt accept me no matter how much I prove myself. I am ok with the fact that people will dismiss me because of my represented gender, race and that I am trans. I am ok with having to be different and I know that maybe I‚Äôll stand out. I am still proud to be trans, but the same kind of proud that Jen Richards, Janet Mock or Laverne Cox represents. To me it is just a factor in my existence not a limiter. \n\nWe all limit ourselves from the world and from our true potential because we believe in can‚Äôt. I believe in can and I can do anything that I want. Yes, there is the scary factor that I will be targeted for hate because of my existence, but that goes for all people. We can die at any moment and have horrible things happen to us for no reason, but that is life and if that point is reached I want to know that I lived a proud life of who I am and aimed at who I want to be. \n\nThis is how I represent trans and I still have much to learn, but hopefully I am somewhere on the right 16:49:00 GMT","timestamp":1410454140,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"kLYshEOL","tags":["trans","gender","age","nonbinary","mogai","lgbtqia","lgbtq","lgbtqai","mogii","intersex","activism","ageism"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZMr1Gq1QZG1Ot","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":12,"title":"Observations on trans support & activism within the community.","body":"One thing I‚Äôve been noticing, very increasingly, lately, is the age gap in trans support and activism.\n\nWe‚Äôre very intent on focusing on support for the next generation of trans youths, and incorporating them into our activism. This is no bad thing, in fact, this is quite a good thing. The other side of this, however, seems to be that the current generation of trans people, the ones in the 25-45 or so age bracket, often end up being ignored.\n\nBear in mind that throughout this post, I am speaking in generalisations. I know there are exceptions, and I know that not everyone will have experienced this, but I am speaking from my own experience, and it is not my intent to alienate anyone.\n\nExcluding places with incredibly large queer populations, like Brighton or London, it seems that support groups for trans people start with groups for youth and young adult ranges, serving people in age brackets like 15-18 or 16-25. And then you‚Äôve got your groups for the older people in the community, who are dealing with the issues of transitioning later, or dealing with their transitions later on. Unfortunately, however, there‚Äôs rarely anything for the less older adults, leaving a gap in the market. A lot of the groups attended by the older generation don‚Äôt appear to have age brackets, but the fact is that these groups end up attracting those people, and often feel uncomfortable for the younger folks - who aren‚Äôt welcome at ‚Äúyouth‚Äù groups, because they‚Äôre too old - because their support needs are different. There also appears to be a feeling within the medical and general support communities that people in this age bracket do not need support or help, which is clearly wrong. This is apparent in mental health services, I feel it is mirrored within support for the trans community as well. The support needs for people does differ between the different age brackets, however the current method of ‚Äúyouth‚Äù and ‚Äúeveryone else‚Äù is not working.\n\nThis is mirrored in activism as well. If you look at the majority (again, generalising) of the big name trans activists, they‚Äôre all older folks. Activists from our age bracket just ended up being branded as ‚Äúsocial justice warriors‚Äù or ‚Äúattention hogs‚Äù. But then you move down in the age gap slightly, and queer media is raving about the teenagers and young adults who are standing up for themselves and changing the world around them. I do feel that this needs to be celebrated and promoted, but it needs to be done in a way that isn‚Äôt at the expense of other people who are fighting the same fights.\n\nI‚Äôm completely aware that nonbinary identities are ‚Äúrelatively new‚Äù in the public perception, that intersex people have often kept quiet and out of the spotlight, and that trans people who don‚Äôt transition generally hid it in the past, but the public is hearing about us now. But they‚Äôre not hearing about us from ourselves. They‚Äôre hearing about us from the perspectives of trans people who fit the ‚Äútypical trans narrative‚Äù, the older trans activists, and generally in reference to the current generation of young trans people. And in many cases, these activists are acting in the role of allies, but they‚Äôre often speaking for us, not to us. Our voices are not being heard because trans activists will not leave a space for us to speak ourselves. There is an apparent ‚Äúhandover‚Äù going on, where we‚Äôre preparing to hand our fight from the older generation of big names to the younger, but in doing so, we‚Äôre skipping the people who are dealing with things right now. Just like the aforementioned support needs differ between the different ages within the trans community, so do the activism needs, and that‚Äôs not being addressed - no one has left a space for us, so we shout louder to make our own space. But then, instead of being activists, we‚Äôre ‚Äúoversensitive‚Äù, ‚Äúsocial justice warriors‚Äù, ‚Äúloudmouths‚Äù, ‚Äúwhiny‚Äù, ‚Äúattention seeking‚Äù or ‚Äújust being difficult‚Äù. And it‚Äôs people within our community that are telling us these things as readily as the people outside our community.\n\nThe recent Stonewall situation, for example, where a handful of the big name activists were selected for the initial meeting with Stonewall about including the trans community at large - yes, in this instance, the attendees for the meeting were selected by Stonewall themselves with little consideration for the rest of the community. However, while several of the attendees were willing to speak to the rest of the community and find out how they felt about the issues, and what they wanted brought to the meeting on their behalf, there was no shortage of people who were just willing to tell us to get over it while they speak for us. And I believe a large part of this is either because of our age, or because of the fact that we‚Äôre not big-enough-name activists, which I also believe is related to our age.\n\nThis is a trend that needs to stop. We have voices, and they will be heard. We have needs that need support, and we will get it. The question is, does the trans community at large want to help, or do they want us to do it for ourselves? This is not dissimilar to the situation that the trans community as a whole has been in with LGB(‚ÄúT‚Äù) activists for quite some time now, where they‚Äôve left out trans people (again, both in support and activism) or spoken on their behalf - but are we going to improve it, or just repeat what‚Äôs happened to us before?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"fromthecloudofowlyquill","id":97228014584,"post_url":"http://fromthecloudofowlyquill.tumblr.com/post/97228014584/boys-dont-spy-page-1-boys-dont-spy-page","slug":"boys-dont-spy-page-1-boys-dont-spy-page","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11
