15:38:41 GMT","timestamp":1410449921,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"HS5qbHAY","tags":["trans","transgender","what tags are even relevant anymore?","I should probably start a side blog for this but yolo"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zd761u1QZ17d4","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"The first of a series: Essays on being trans and living on both sides of the fence.","body":"One of the few good things about being transsexual is that is gives a unique insight into the way that both men and woman live, something few people will ever get to experience. Now, of course, this is not an absolute thing: Some trans people do not and never will pass, and we obviously cannot turn back time and experiences our childhoods as if we were the other sex.\n\nBut it does grant you conditional entry into the social reality of the opposite sex. It also, if you are being honest with yourself, forces you to confront these realities and the fact that men and women are treated very differently within our society from the very moment we are born.\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nNow, first I want to say that I don‚Äôt know a lot about feminism, queer theory, sociology, or any of that stuff on any side of the issue. I haven‚Äôt read any books on the subject (one part lacking time, two parts not knowing where to start). The extent of my education on these subjects is essentially reading statistics and the words of some very articulate women here on tumblr. That said, my beliefs tend to be most in line with radical feminism, a conclusion drawn partly through my own lived experiences and partly through reading the words of women.\n\nSecond, I want to establish my reasons for starting to write about this. For anyone who‚Äôs been following me for a while, you know that I very rarely write about being transsexual, and even more rarely write about it in depth. I will occasionally reblog something or throw out a comment or two, but that‚Äôs pretty much as far as I go. I am a hockey blog, first and foremost, and that won‚Äôt change (beware, all ye who enter for anything but hockey. Winter is coming).\n\nBut I wanted to start writing more about my experiences because there seem to be very few female transsexuals within this discussion. I have seen some FTMs and a few detransitioned women in discussions, but overall females who are trans or who have a history of being trans seem to be rarer than MTFs. As I said, I am not very educated on these matters, but I am well versed on my own experiences, and I like to think I am insightful enough to say something meaningful at least once or twice if I write a whole bunch of those experiences down.\n\nI also want to write more about this for personal reasons. I have thought long and hard about my transition and why I am doing it, but I rarely write anything down. I see this as a sort of way not only to share my experiences and hopefully contribute something to the discussion, but also as a way for me to organize my thoughts and analyze my choices and thought process. Ultimately, I am always on a journey to bring together my reality as a female person and my decision to take male hormones and socially transition to being a man.\n\nThird: Me. I am Jimmy. I am 24 years old. I am a female to male transsexual, and I spent the first 22ish years of my life living as a woman. I like hockey more than is probably healthy. I am a writer and a lover of the English language, for all its pitfalls. Reading has been the best teacher I‚Äôve ever had and writing the best therapist. I currently attend school online full time and also work full time as a live in nanny. I live in Arizona, which I hate both because of the politics and the weather.\n\nFeel free to comment on this or any future such posts to agree or disagree or simply spread the information. Keep in mind, though, that I do not, nor am I trying to, speak for all transsexual men. I simply want to use this as a means of documenting my experiences and organizing my thoughts.\n\nSome topics that I intend to explore in the future: Looking back at the differences between how my brother and I were raised, examining how losing my mother at a young age and being raised by my father impacted my life and especially how I interact with gender, my frustration with the trans movement as a whole, and many tidbits of analysis regarding how I have been treated as a man versus as a woman.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"makarad","id":97224149135,"post_url":"http://makarad.tumblr.com/post/97224149135/alright-so-i-dont-make-a-lot-of-personal-posts-on","slug":"alright-so-i-dont-make-a-lot-of-personal-posts-on","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 15:36:42 GMT","timestamp":1410449802,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"wqtgJfbA","tags":["inky spills","trans","transgender","ftm","misgendering","dysphoria","I don't know what else to tag this as","looking for advice","why is this so damn long","it's not even noon and I'm already rambling"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zg69su1QZ0iYF","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"alright so I don‚Äôt make a lot of personal posts on here, because I usually just reblog fandom posts and important news posts, but I don‚Äôt even know where to start for this.\n\n(everything under a cut because it‚Äôs longer than I thought it would be. misgendering and dysphoria and unsupportive parents, if you‚Äôd like a summary.)\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nabout a month ago (august 10th) I finally confronted my mother, hoping I‚Äôd just blown things out of proportion in my head after I‚Äôd tried to tell her I only liked girls, and wasn‚Äôt interested in guys. I told her I was trans(gender), and that I wasn‚Äôt a girl. that I am a boy, and I like girls. our ‚Äúconversation‚Äù - if you can even call it that - lasted an hour and a half. it only ended because I was sick to tears and wanting to express my pain in unhealthy ways.\n\nnaturally, she decided that the conversation - no, the entire topic - was over and done with after that.\n\nshe spent every opportunity I wasn‚Äôt interrupting her to correct her because she wasn‚Äôt listening to try and undermine me, and turn my past behaviour back on me. that I liked dressing up and looking nice, and it made me feel good. that I wasn‚Äôt like this before. that she swung both ways when she was younger, too. that I hadn‚Äôt even spent any time being a girl - in other words, wearing make-up and dresses and skirts and short shorts and tight shirts. that I just needed to find the right guy. that I could never pass for a guy anyway.\n\nshe suggested getting me a different counselor/therapist, and I‚Äôll admit - I laughed. her intentions were not to support me, and she made that obvious; I‚Äôm her baby girl, and she doesn‚Äôt want me to feel so uncomfortable in my own body. she decided that a counselor would ‚Äúfix‚Äù me so she could keep trying to live vicariously through me.\n\nevery ‚Äúargument‚Äù she tried to ‚Äúcounter‚Äù me with was selfish and uncaring. ultimately, she admitted, before I just couldn‚Äôt let her beat me down anymore, that she didn‚Äôt even know what ‚Äútrans‚Äù was, much less ‚Äútransgender‚Äù. that, of course, proved to me what I‚Äôd known the entire time - she wasn‚Äôt listening.\n\nmy father is a bit of a wild card, but seeing as he uses ‚Äúgay‚Äù, ‚Äúflamboyant‚Äù, and ‚Äúfag‚Äù as insults against feminine and/or flamboyant men, I‚Äôm glad I waited until he left on a business trip to try and speak with my mother on the subject.\n\nthe biggest issue is that she now makes even more attempts for ‚Äúvalidation‚Äù; that is, blatantly stating that we are women and we are female and we have to stick together and we need to stand up against men.\n\nthis post turned out longer than I thought it would, but I don‚Äôt know what to do - I can‚Äôt move out yet, having no driver‚Äôs license and no job (much less knowing a place I can stay that will take an unemployed 19 year old with his cat and rabbit). I‚Äôm already aware that my mother is emotionally/psychologically abusive, and now she has my gender to use against me as well.\n\nwhile it‚Äôs thankfully almost autumn, it‚Äôs never very cool in Florida thanks to the humidity. I wear a compression sports bra, a tank top, a t-shirt, and a hoodie. I‚Äôve fortunately got four pairs of men‚Äôs pants; all four of them miracles to acquire.\n\nI need to at least curb my dysphoria better, seeing as a counselor (and a plan to transition) are out of the question until I‚Äôm out of this house. google has only gotten me so far, and I‚Äôm so uselessly limited in what I can do right now and in the near future. I need a plan, or plans, or resources or something. I‚Äôm just‚Ä¶so lost in what to do.","can_reply":false}]

as the punctuation\n  mark after)\n\n  what would it mean to say that\n  after 9/11\n  my¬†?\nbecame¬†! \n\nwhat would it mean to say that\n  the war on terror made me trans?\n\n  would you believe me from violence?\n\n  because sometimes i wonder\n  if there would be gender if there\n  were no violence. \n\n  sometimes i\n  wonder if there would be body if\n  there were no trauma. \n\n  sometimes You can read the post and my response here. Besides annoying me greatly, it made me think about the trans women who have called me lucky and wish they had had some sort of odd physical development. \n\nBefore I go any farther, a few quick facts. When a male develops breasts it‚Äôs called gynecomastia. There are two types. Pseudogynecomastia is what obese men get and is just fat. True gynecomastia is actually not that uncommon. It‚Äôs usually a small lump of breast tissue about the diameter of a quarter. The majority of times it goes away on it‚Äôs own within 2 years.\n\nIn my case it didn‚Äôt. Before hormones I was 5‚Äô6‚Äù 180lbs and wore a 40C.\n\nLook I get it. I know exactly why a number of trans women think I‚Äôm lucky. They made passing a lot easier from the start. And if I believed differently, they could easily be used to argue that I really am a woman. \n\nThose trans women couldn‚Äôt be more wrong. There was nothing ‚Äúlucky‚Äù about it!\n\nYes, many women can understand the feelings of shame and hatred at their body‚Äôs development. They can emphasize with me in ways that few men can. Only another male who experienced developing breasts can fully comprehend the depth of shame we go to though.\n\nJust take a moment and try to imagine having your body develop in ways it shouldn‚Äôt. Everyone around you treats it like a deformity and you‚Äôre a freak. Multiple doctors poke and prod you before declaring that you must have surgery. Not because of any health reason, but purely cosmetic since they agree your deformed. Just imagine what that does to a person‚Äôs sense of self worth.\n\nMany guys jump at the chance of surgery too. They‚Äôll do anything if it means not being a freak any longer. Not me though.\n\nThe thought of surgery terrified me. No offense to any trans men who might read this, but I didn‚Äôt want to trade breasts for dead, trimmed nipples that might fall off and a chest covered in scars. I couldn‚Äôt see how that would make me feel less ashamed of my body.\n\nInstead I spent over a decade wearing a binder. Wishing they weren‚Äôt there but unwilling to get rid of them. Its only been in the past year that I‚Äôve been able to start connecting with this part of myself. To stop feeling shame and disgust, replaced with feeling of acceptance and love \n\nThis is why you can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm lucky. The vast majority of men who have experienced this definitely don‚Äôt consider themselves ‚Äúlucky‚Äù. Even for someone like me who transitioned, the psychological trauma far outweighs any minor benefit to passing that fate has bestowed upon me.\n\nAnd those of you who would use me to prove a point, your the worst!\n\nYou hide the complexity of life and rob me of my humanity. You turn me into an object. Evidence A, a pair of breasts and a dick. And in so doing, you completely miss the real truth.\n\nIt doesn‚Äôt matter what my existence proves or disproves. What matters is being a boy with breasts is a part of the male experience. A rare part, but decidedly male none the less. To be a boy with breasts only makes sense through a male lens. The effect it has had on my life only makes sense when you understand that I‚Äôm male. \n\nLastly, you strip all the men who don‚Äôt transition of their manhood. You become no better than the boys who held me against a wall when I was 13 and groped me to see if my breasts were real and whether I was a guy or girl.\n\nYour predators preying on those you feel are weaker than you! All you‚Äôve done is show how little you care about other people, and proved nothing in the PRONOUNS!!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"thefeministagonyaunt","id":97206060921,"post_url":"http://thefeministagonyaunt.tumblr.com/post/97206060921/okay-so","slug":"okay-so","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 culture"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zvph_m1QXxiTv","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":5,"title":"Okay, So","body":"It really annoys me, and I‚Äôve seen it a fair few times on this website, when someone will anonymously be like ‚Äúoh, some question about trans/cis/queer‚Äù and the owner of the blog will be like ‚Äúpipe the fuck down you cishet piece of shit! You better check your goddamn privilege!!!‚Äù\n\nLike dude, not everyone knows what cishet means, stop being so angry.\n\nAs I say, I‚Äôve seen this a lot of times.\n\nSo basically, I‚Äôm going to compile a basic list of some things you might not know, and if you want to ask anything or need to know more, please ask! I promise I will never be rude or tell you to check your privilege. Those things are frankly unhelpful to the cause; I will tell you, because the grand majority of people mean well, just don‚Äôt know quite the right way to do or say something. Here we go.\n\nCisgender/cis: Having a gender identity or gender role that society considers appropriate for the sex one was assigned at birth. (i.e. female on birth certificate and identify and feel like a female)\n\nCishet: Someone who is both cisgender and heterosexual (sexually/romantically attracted to the opposite sex)\n\nTransgender: Someone who feels that they identify with a gender other than what they were born with, or a person who feels that the body into which they were born doesn‚Äôt represent their true gender (i.e. female on birth certificate but strongly identifies as male or feels like a male)\n\nNon-Gender-Binary: A bit more complicated, this could mean you identify with both genders, no genders or fluid about the whole thing (i.e. if you feel like a boy one day and a girl another day)\n\nFeminism: It‚Äôs just equality, we want to be equal. Nothing evil or ‚Äúman hating‚Äù, it‚Äôs just about the fact that we‚Äôve been treated unfairly and we want that to stop. We want to be able to sleep with whoever we want and get cool jobs that pay the same as men‚Äôs and get abortions/birth control if we need them. Just equality. \n\nWhy can‚Äôt I call a black person an N word because they say it/ a queer person queer because they say it: They can call themselves queer if they identify as such or it makes them feel good to describes themselves as that way, but bottom line is, that word has been offensive for so long that it can really hurt if a straight person calls you queer, even if you say that about yourself (awful example: I call myself several cruel ‚Äúginger‚Äù names for fun, but it stings when someone calls me an ugly ginger fucker).\n\nCultural appropriation: When someone who doesn‚Äôt know much about another culture does something sacred to that culture just because it‚Äôs fashionable - it can be pretty offensive (i.e. me going to a Hindu temple when I travelled around Nepal, a country that I‚Äôm fascinated by, and receiving a bindi = fine. Skinny, white hipster wearing a bindi to a music festival to seem cool and boho = not really fine) \n\nThat‚Äôs about all I can think of for the time being, please let me know if this was helpful, want anything else added to the list, or if you need more questions answered, even if they seem a little silly, this is a safe space to ask! In the apprenticeship program, similar to a beauty school model, TransTech offers creative technology services including but not limited to, web development and graphic design, that are worked on by students and educators at affordable prices for consumers. 100% of the profits go back into the program. TransTech is a social enterprise structure that is meant to maximize economic improvement and well-being within the LGBTQ community, rather than focusing on maximizing profits for external shareholders.\n\nTTSE envisions a world where no trans person ever underestimates their value. We believe in a world where trans-identified people can improve their skills and increase their value and self-worth without the threat of harassment and discrimination. A future where everyone feels empowered. \n\nWe recognize the unlimited potential for growth in what we offer, how we offer it, and who we offer it to. Our trainings are delivered on-site and online. Our training focuses on basic jobs skill like data entry and administrative tasks to advanced skills like graphic design, and web-coding. We structure this academy around empowerment, and education, with the goal to secure employment.\nThese three tenets, Empower, Educate and Employ, are each important parts of the educational structure and will include instructions on topics ranging from Power, Privilege, and Oppression and Scholarship Essays to Coding Skills and How to Build a Professional Network.\n  We believe providing a space where anyone can interact with trans people in a business atmosphere will create a stronger relationship with the entire community and also demonstrate the capabilities and worth of Trans People.\n\nOnly 5 days left - please donate + no.","image_permalink":"http://lickyvobo.tumblr.com/image/97198259642","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":211,"height":238,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_250.png"},{"width":100,"height":113,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_100.png"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_75sq.png"}],"original_size":{"width":211,"height":238,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_250.png"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"twotransmen","id":97198185981,"post_url":"http://twotransmen.tumblr.com/post/97198185981/about-this-blog","slug":"about-this-blog","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 04:51:46 GMT","timestamp":1410411106,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"SXzOthFU","tags":["transgender","trans","ftm transgender","ftm transition","ftm","transition"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zt5QWm1QXTftz","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"About This Blog","body":"Cecil and Sebastian are two trans men from Columbus, OH. Though discovering their gender dysphoria separately, the two came together in late 2013 to pursue their goals. Cecil moved from NY, to Columbus to share a life and love with Sebastian, as well as to share the experience of transitioning together.\n\nRecognizing that most trans men resources on the web are written from the perspective of young and healthy men, we cooperatively decided to run a blog together about our experiences of transitioning as people beyond the age of 25, as well as of people suffering from disorders and disabilities, and taking medications. Our story is not necessarily unique, but different enough, and we hope that it can give others like us the hope, courage, and help to continue along their paths in life.\n\nImportant: This blog may contain triggering language, but only when necessary. Activism and posts related to activism may occur. It will contain posts of a personal nature. It will contain photographs, videos, and the life experiences of two people that live a bit outside of the norm. This is not a Social Justice blog. Please enjoy this as a resource, feel free to ask questions, and to reblog. But please try to refrain from harassment, aggression, and personal attacks.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"popculturecatchall","id":97197797843,"post_url":"http://popculturecatchall.tumblr.com/post/97197797843/fairly-soon-i-will-do-something-which-will-utterly","slug":"fairly-soon-i-will-do-something-which-will-utterly","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 04:45:00 GMT","timestamp":1410410700,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"BAVKh46K","tags":["trans","trans woman","transgender","personal","depression","personal history"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-CYhu1QXSB7J","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"Fairly soon I will do something which will utterly surprise every person I know. There may be a little bit of ‚ÄúOh, that explains some stuff.‚Äù There‚Äôll be some ‚ÄúWell, we thought you might be gay or something.‚Äù But there will most certainly be absolutely no ‚ÄúYeah, I knew you were trans but didn‚Äôt feel like saying anything.‚Äù\n\nIt‚Äôs kind of cool, if still incredibly scary. I mean, I assume at this point in life the people in my life probably think they have a very good handle on who I am. I‚Äôm 28, not so old that I‚Äôm expected to have everything figured out (like anyone ever does), but also not so young that I should have no clue who I am. And it‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt. Obviously, I have a very clear idea of who I am. It‚Äôs just that I cannot share it with anyone yet. And so it‚Äôs put a lot of discovery on hold. I can do self-reflection all damn day, but I can‚Äôt go out in the world and get a full sense of how I exist.\n\nI remember being about 23 or so and talking with my siblings over some food. It was likely some holiday, but nothing grand. Let‚Äôs just act like it was Labor Day and be done with the speculation. We were sitting around and talking, and one of them said, ‚ÄúWhen did ______ start reading?‚Äù They talked about how they out of nowhere, to them, when I was about 17 or 18 I had this collection of books and this little secret history of reading to where I could recommend all these books, yet they had never seen me reading during these years.\n\nSecret was always the default. Sharing isn‚Äôt easy for our family with anything, and when I add in basically hiding half my thoughts by default, that leads to some secret agent level shit. I used to sneak books home, hoping no one would catch me on the stairs and ask what I had in my bag. I would buy something else and hide the book underneath. When I went searching for a book, I did so alone. I had decided I would be a reader and I knew that if it were a true part of me it needed to be hidden from sight.\n\nI wonder what my dad would have answered if he were ever asked what my dream job was. Now, maybe he would know. I eventually brought my books out of the closet and majored in creative writing. But back then, could he even have sniffed the answer? I doubt it.\n\nThe last time I caught my family by surprise I was 17, almost 18. I packed everything I cared about and put it in my car and drove away. There was some vague idea of moving to Mexico and getting a job and writing‚Äîthough I don‚Äôt know if I ever really believed in the possibility. It was an act of escape. I ran away. Outside San Diego my resolve broke and the loneliness seeped in and I realized how dumb I was being and I just wanted to go back. I turned around and drove straight back. Other than stopping for food and driving along the coast, I really didn‚Äôt do much. I just drove and thought and thought and thought.\n\nThe return was a smart choice, but it was a coward‚Äôs choice. I went back and told a half truth of why I ran. I went back and cut myself off from the world and finished up school on my own. I went back and told myself it was okay. I went back and didn‚Äôt talk to people about having left.\n\nWhen I first tried to write about this event it came out completely muddled in one of those underground writing workshops that are more diary sharing hours than actual craft discussions (so, this basically). I was still trying to write around the depression. Some classmates were kind, and found parts to praise. Others were dicks, but that was always their role in those discussions. And I sat there, listening, but knowing ‚ÄúI cannot tell you the whole truth because I will not accept it is true.‚Äù\n\nRunning away was a long time coming and the culmination of one of the deepest depressions I‚Äôve ever dealt with. To those that knew me then, it seemed to come from nowhere. To me it was just the unfortunate peak of a lost year. It was the dumb stunt that granted me one of the few moments of control in a life I rarely felt was my own. The six months before I had been depressed and alone, the six months after I was depressed and alone.\n\nI got better, or something like better. I don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs hard to see the edges of this for me, but I know it faded and things grew better for me and it‚Äôs never really been quite that bad since, even when it‚Äôs been really bad sometimes. The depression always seems to lurk and the decisions I make in the fog carry the risk of fucking me over. I nearly quit my credential program with a month left to go and $20,000 of debt, a no gain all loss decision that seemed like the right thing to do in that moment. It grabs hold of your brain and seeps into your life and nothing feels worth the price of effort. That would have surprised everyone.\n\nBut I didn‚Äôt. I stuck with it and now I‚Äôm teaching and getting paid. The debt won‚Äôt go away, but at least I‚Äôll make a couple bucks and have some good work experience‚Äîthings the depression would have robbed me of. I did everything everyone expected of me. I‚Äôm very capable when I try, even when dealing with all of this‚Äîthough I‚Äôve never let anyone know about it in full. I think they can see it. I think they can feel it. And if I were to tell them I deal with depression they wouldn‚Äôt be surprised.\n\nBut no one at all will see me being trans. Being trans is not the only cause of my depression, but it‚Äôs a multiplier for sure. But ordering hormones, deciding on this path, this wasn‚Äôt a depression choice. This was the other me. The secret me that read books, even if she felt she needed to skip lunch to get money to buy them. The secret me that snuck into the library at school and borrowed Dostoyevsky, but made sure no one saw me enter or leave. I‚Äôve made my moves when no one else would notice, kept everything from their eyes, and cultivated their eventual surprise. This is an act of the full me, and one done from a desire for a future, not a fear.\n\nAnd then, once they‚Äôre all surprised, it‚Äôll be my turn. Honestly, I have no idea how people will react, other than generally shocked and less-than-positive. I have a certain idea of how people will act, but only a vague sense at best. The fact is the day after I come out, I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôll still have any of them in my life. I think a few will stick, but who the fuck knows.\n\nI‚Äôm rapidly approaching the unknown. But that‚Äôs never been the problem; it‚Äôs when I think I know all the awful things coming, the pointlessness of tomorrow, that the depression comes. The unknown is the exciting part and I‚Äôm ready for that to come.\n\n‚ÄîEmma","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lickyvobo","id":97197728152,"post_url":"http://lickyvobo.tumblr.com/post/97197728152/t-time","slug":"t-time","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 04:44:07 GMT","timestamp":1410410647,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"uwaT0yUs","tags":["trans","transgender","ftm","transwife","senecacrane","testosterone","ttime"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZDD2Qy1QXRw6O","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"T Time","body":"Yesterday was a big day at our house‚Ä¶ Jax started testosterone!\n\n I kept waiting for the whole day to be different, but it continued not be.\n\nWe sat in a regular old exam room where they took vitals and went over side effects. Like I‚Äôm going to wake up and in a matter of 48 hours he‚Äôs going to be Barry White with a ZZ Top beard.\n\n One injection of a low dose of testosterone isn‚Äôt going to change things, but it‚Äôs 03:33:38 GMT","timestamp":1410406418,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"pPLbfhrV","tags":["asks","trans","transgender","allies","femwork"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZoEgYu1QX9Z3c","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":14,"asking_name":"femwork","asking_url":"http://femwork.tumblr.com/","question":"Hi! Could anyone please help me to start using the correct pronouns and words for transgendered people? Eg. What are the correct pronouns? I want to make sure that I use the words that they prefer and I don't want to cause any offence. I would also like to know what is the best way a cisgendered person can support transgender people?","answer":"All right, let‚Äôs tackle this.\n\nIt is not transgendered or cisgendered. It is transgender or cisgender, or trans or cis.\nAlso, it‚Äôs not ‚Äútrans*‚Äù.\nAlso, cis does not stand for ‚Äúcomfortable in skin‚Äù. Cis is simply the linguistical opposite of trans.\nBeing trans works like being queer - treat us in a similar way, I mean. Ex: don‚Äôt out them, don‚Äôt constantly compare them to other trans people you know of/have met, don‚Äôt say it‚Äôs a phase or any other invalidating thing, don‚Äôt make them a public spectacle or your token friend, don‚Äôt constantly ask them how sex, relationships, transness works ie use them as your go-to reference for ‚Äúlife as a trans person‚Äù, and so on.\nThere aren‚Äôt any special rules for pronouns for trans people. It‚Äôs the same way with cis people - you use the pronouns they want used. Trans women are women, trans men are men. There are no universal pronouns for trans people.\nIf you‚Äôre corrected on their identity or pronouns, say you‚Äôre sorry and work on using the pronouns they want. If you don‚Äôt know or are confused about conjugation, ask privately. \nAll pronouns are valid pronouns. Because words are all made up and language is constantly changing. Therefore, a new pronoun has just as much legitimacy as any other new word in our language.\nAll genders are valid. Gender is a human concept and as such it can be interpreted and classified in a variety of ways just like any other intangible concepts.\nSex is also a human concept. Please do not use terms like ‚Äúmale-bodied‚Äù or ‚Äúfemale-bodied‚Äù, do not identify any bodily characteristics as inherently male/masculine or female/feminine. Use DMAB (deemed/designated male at birth) and DFAB (deemed/designated female at birth) (and other terms like it) sparingly and only when necessary (many people tend to use them as replacements of ‚Äúmale-bodied‚Äù and ‚Äúfemale-bodied‚Äù when that is not what they are). Refer directly to the parts you are speaking about, ex, instead of saying ‚Äúfemale reproductive system‚Äù, say uterus, ovaries, etc.\nDo not use FTM (female to male) or MTF (male to female) unless the person in question has expressed a preference for these terms. Do not refer to trans people as ‚Äútrapped in a (wo)man‚Äôs body‚Äù or ‚Äúused to be a (wo)man‚Äù or ‚Äúborn a (wo)man‚Äù - only trans people are allowed to use this as part of their self identification. The proper way to say it - if you are allowed to at all - would be, ‚Äúused to identify as a (wo)man‚Äù and sentiments like it.\nDo not support truscum or T(W)ERFs (trans (women) exclusionary radical feminists). Do not separate trans women from ‚Äúreal women‚Äù, or trans men from ‚Äúreal men‚Äù. Do not support the idea of ‚Äútranstrenders‚Äù.\nDysphoria is a vague medical term that can be applied to a variety of situations, feelings, interpretations, and so on. It therefore is not the sole determiner in whether someone is trans. Being trans simply means you identify as something other than what you were assigned at birth.\nDo not call raising children gender neutrally child abuse. Do not call allowing children to break gender norms child abuse. Do not raise your children according to gender norms. Make it clear you are open to the idea that your child may be more than what they seem. Allow your children and the children and people around you to explore gender and identity.\nThey/them/theirs should be your default pronoun. Do not assume people‚Äôs gender. Do not use (s)he or she/he. Singular they is grammatically correct.\nThese are slurs (forgive me, followers): hermaphrodite, he-she, cuntboy, dickgirl, futa, tranny, and basically any term you‚Äôll find in a pornographic video or website.\nDo not ever misgender someone or deny their transness regardless of what they‚Äôve done, what they‚Äôve said, how they identify, how they appear, etc.\nNonbinary refers to trans people who do not identify as solely women nor as solely men.\nTransphobia and cissexism refer to discrimination against and oppression of trans people. Transmisogyny refers to the specific discrimination against and oppression of trans women, who face unique challenges from other trans people. Cisphobia does not exist.\nDyadism refers to the discrimination against and oppression of intersex people. Intersex and trans are different - intersex people can be cis or trans.\nCasual cissexism refers to the alignment of being a (wo)man to certain bodily characteristics, bodily functions, or biological or social issues (breast development, reproductive health, certain cancers, jokes about lesbians hating penises, etc).\nDo not argue with people about trans headcanons (or any headcanons involving marginalized people).\nTag appropriately; try to tag transphobia/cissexism, transmisogyny, hate crimes, truscum, radfems, casual cissexism, etc. Ask your followers what they need you to help them avoid.\nDo not use ‚Äúsame-sex marriage‚Äù or ‚Äúsame-gender marriage‚Äù as blanket terms for the marital rights movement. Do not use ‚Äúopposite gender/sex‚Äù.\nHere are relevant tags to browse: #trans | #trans rights | #transphobia | #casual cissexism | #transmisogyny | He pulled off his yellow zebra-patterned shirt, then sucked in his breath and looked at his reflection in the oven door. After pressing an arm over his chest and seeing how it would look if it were flat, he glanced out the doorway. The main area was empty. Party Poison was still in the gas station, and Fun Ghoul and Jet Star were on their way to Zone Two. Kobra swallowed down his nerves, then unrolled the bandage.\n  [[MORE]]\n  Holding his breath, he wrapped the bandage once around his chest and pinned it into place, wincing when the safety pin jabbed his skin. When he exhaled, his chest ached from the tight compression. He wrapped the bandages around himself as closely as he could, pulling tight as if he were wrapping a Christmas present. His breathing grew restricted and the pain increased, but his chest looked flat in the oven reflection.\n\n  Just when he was about to snip off the bandage from the roll and pin it together, someone said ‚ÄúKobra! No!‚Äù Kobra whirled around to see Poison standing in the doorway, wearing the blue gas station apron. ‚ÄúShit, Kid, what are you doing?‚Äù he said, hurrying into the kitchen.\n\n  He looked down at his chest in confusion. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just wrapping my chest,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTo make it flatter. What? You didn‚Äôt think I was injured, did you?‚Äù\n\n  ‚ÄúOh, no. It‚Äôs those bandages. You better take those off, Kid. Those could crack your ribs.‚Äù\n\n  Kobra‚Äôs eyes widened. ‚ÄúWhat? Seriously?‚Äù\n\n  ‚ÄúYeah. They can be dangerous.‚Äù Poison crouched down beside him. ‚ÄúCome on, you better take them off. Do you need some help?‚Äù\n\n  ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôve got it.‚Äù He unwound the bandages, then dropped them on the floor and wrapped his arms around his chest. The tight compression was gone, and he took a few deep lungfuls of air.\n\n  ‚ÄúIt looked like you had them on pretty tight,‚Äù Poison said, winding the bandage around the roll. ‚ÄúThat could‚Äôve hurt you pretty badly.‚Äù Suddenly he paused. ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt done this before, have you?‚Äù\n\n  ‚ÄúOh, no,‚Äù Kobra said as he slipped his T-shirt back on. ‚ÄúThis is the first time. Try it on.‚Äù\n\n  After taking off his yellow shirt, Kobra pulled the Frankuloid shirt over his head and squeezed his arms through the sleeves. It was flatter than it had been before.\n\n  ‚ÄúYeah, that looks good,‚Äù Poison said, holding him at arm‚Äôs length. ‚ÄúJust wear that until we can get a binder, okay?‚Äù\n\n  ‚ÄúYeah. Thanks, man. Thank you.‚Äù\n\n  Poison smiled at him. After closing the cabinet, Kobra joined him in the gas station, where he helped him figure out an order they needed to place. characteristics that would make them clearly not bigoted - there are plenty of good cis social justice bloggers that don‚Äôt fuck up regularly and yet are shut down merely on the basis of their gender identity\n\nthey do this partially as a defense mechanism, which is somewhat understandable considering the real and present danger to many trans people in the real world (and sometimes even on this site from those few strangely bigoted blogs that exist despite the majority of this site being minorities)\n\nbut it‚Äôs not understandable if you toss out the phrase cissexist like damn confetti whenever you think it‚Äôll bolster your argument. it‚Äôs not understandable to send hate to fucking thirteen year old cis girls on this site and making them think it‚Äôs a crime just because they‚Äôre is 100% by and for LGBT people/allies. some of the people in charge are doing a fantastic job recruiting by being welcoming and very civilly educating people when they see that they‚Äôre willing to learn. one of the recruiters, however, is very abrasive and at times aggressive to people who make mistakes in the learning process, and she‚Äôs having a harder time getting people to want to stay and better themselves and become a good part of the community. i get the anger behind it because being oppressed fucking sucks, yeah. it does. but we have to learn not to expect the worst from people, especially if they seem like they‚Äôre willing to improve. \n\nso‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ had a sub par day, let‚Äôs say, and nothing terrible even happened. It‚Äôs like- damn, my mind is so far ahead of my body, gender-wise. I know I want to be a woman, and I find it funny that I even once questioned such a thing. But my body is like‚Ä¶ snails, turtles, sloths and other slow-moving creatures. Anyway, I don‚Äôt work this week, but I told my coworkers, half-jokingly, that I was going to come back a woman. My boss, the same one I made that post about earlier this year listing the many bigoted things he says, said basically ‚Äúyeah, we know, we just didn‚Äôt know if you were going to have the surgery yet‚Äù. So, on one hand- fuck yeah, everyone knows, on the other- shit, I hope they don‚Äôt expect me to come back a completely different person, I mean, nothing can make me magically pass in a week, even ignoring the fact that I‚Äôm not going to have any surgeries for quite a while, if ever, I‚Äôm going to look mostly the same as the last time they saw me, and they‚Äôre gonna see just how terribly slow a gender transition is. Anyway, I just might be like ‚Äúok yall, I‚Äôm a chick now‚Äù and hope they understand.\n\nAnother thing about me- okay, I work with all het males mostly, and their jokes about me are pretty consistent- every night, at least a few times a night- somebody will say something regarding me being feminine or me liking men or something of that nature, often overtly sexual things. A lady who sometimes works with us came up to me one time and said ‚ÄúI really hope you kick their ass for some of the things they say about you‚Äù, I said that I don‚Äôt mind it, and in fact, I encourage them to talk that way. Because, at this point, I really don‚Äôt mind it, and I think it‚Äôs a way of them reacting to someone quite different from themselves in a not-overtly-hostile way while still managing to retain their status as a het male (and all trivial machismo crap that goes along with maleness), a status I gladly gave up long ago. Also, a few guys have told me one-on-one, stuff like ‚Äúyou know all that stuff we say about you‚Ä¶we don‚Äôt really mean that right?‚Äù and I ‚Äòm like yeah, I‚Äôm cool with it, because I am.\n\nI was driving home tonight, and I listened to a song from Justin Sane‚Äôs solo album (which, tbqh, wasn‚Äôt that great) several times, the song that goes ‚Äúi‚Äôm a boxer, I‚Äôm from the southside of town, and I‚Äôm the toughest motherfucker around‚Äù, on a side note- this is an instance where I like that his voice is high-pitched for a guy.. Ok, so I might not be the toughest of anything- nor do I want to be- but sometimes we can talk about ourselves better after a disappointing day and staring at an uncertain future, or some shit. I don‚Äôt really know where I‚Äôm going with this‚Ä¶do I wanna change my name to Ivy or keep it as Ryan or go by Rivy, I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm ready for a female name yet, it still feels like something I don‚Äôt deserve at this point I have to earn it. This has a been on ongoing theme in my transition- me thinking I‚Äôm not worthy of something yet. My therapist said ‚Äúya know, you could probably get away with going by Ryan‚Äù but she also thought Ivy was a cool name, so who knows, the name Rivy sounds cool too‚Ä¶. maybe want all three. tes","id":97186561747,"post_url":"http://transquotes.tumblr.com/post/97186561747/text-reads-every-single-day-i-am-told-i-am-not","slug":"text-reads-every-single-day-i-am-told-i-am-not","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 A transgender person‚Äôs gender is ‚Äúon the opposite side‚Äù from the one which they were assigned at birth. Cis means ‚Äúon the same side‚Äù, so cisgender people are on the same side as their assigned gender. You follow? Good.\n\nSo imagine if we didn‚Äôt look at a newborn‚Äôs genitals and immediately go ‚Äúthere, a penis; it‚Äôs a boy!‚Äù If that penis-having baby grew up to be a woman in the aforementioned society, she would not be a trans woman. We would not really have the need for trans/cis labels because there would be no assigned gender to oppose or side with. The person could perhaps still experience dysphoria and want to undergo surgery, but they would always have been considered a woman simply by the merit of their self-assertion as a woman. In this formula there would also be no truscum. No pathologizing of identity = no truscum.","can_reply":false}]

She loved pink and dressing up as a mermaid and didn‚Äôt feel like herself in boys‚Äô clothing. This confused her family, until they took her to a doctor who said that Jazz was transgender and that she was born that way. Jazz‚Äôs story is based on her real-life experience and she tells it in a simple, clear way that will be appreciated by picture book readers, their parents, and teachers.\n\nThis new book is awesome! Glad Gender is becoming more of a nuance conversation! Great to think kids can have a book to help them feel more at home in their body! Excited to get this for our class. I experience dysphoria entirely because I‚Äôm not a girl and being seen as one or seeing myself as one causes me significant discomfort. To me at age 15, this meant that I must be a boy. To me now, this seems more indicative of something of which I‚Äôm becoming increasingly aware - I don‚Äôt really understand gender all that well, nor does it matter to me overmuch.\n\nI identify with the word ‚Äúboy.‚Äù I also identify with the words ‚Äúsmall,‚Äù ‚Äúcute,‚Äù ‚Äúneuroatypical,‚Äù ‚Äústudent,‚Äù and ‚Äúqueer,‚Äù and honestly, I can‚Äôt decide which means the most to me. discussion and commitment to helping reduce the number of people we lose each year to this act.\n\nFind out more here: http://www.iasp.info/wspd/\n\nI believe there is so much more that the trans community can be doing to prevent suicides of people struggling with gender identity. I am just as guilty as anyone. Handwringing can only go so far. Last weekend I started the process of volunteering for the Trevor Project. It is a very small step but a lot of small efforts from many people can make a BIG difference.\n\nI also think that, for those of us in the trans community, it is good for us all to stop at least this one time of year and look at how we are talking about suicide amongst ourselves. It is a subject that at times needs to be acknowledged and discussed, but when it does it must be done mindfulness‚Äîboth for the people who are listening to our words and also for our own selves so that we are aware of how to keep our own mental wellness when we are engaged in these conversations.\n\nI know that some LGBT and Trans-focused organizations and individuals have done a lot of advocacy in this area year round. I have named the Trevor Project, but there are others out there. I would appreciate it if you know of any of these resources to please reply to this thread with information as I would like to compile as many as I can and make them available online.\n\nThere are a few other things that I would like to see happen and am willing to be involved in creating if I can find a few partners.\n\nI think someone might have already done this but I can‚Äôt find it (again‚Äîplease send me links or contact info if you know where it is.) I think that there needs to be some readily accessible guidelines for how members of the trans community might want to think about when talking about suicide. I have watched countless threads on internet forums where a gender questioning visitor (usually a young person or, increasingly, children) will ask if they should start the process of transition. In most of these threads a number of respondents (much older adults) will immediately tell that person that they will likely get to the same point that they themselves did - ready to get a gun out and pull the trigger. I really do believe that we are helping ‚Äúnormalize‚Äù suicide within the trans community by speaking of it so often especially in occasions such as this. (If anyone is familiar with trans forums they will know exactly what I am talking about.) For many, I believe that this moment of very seriously contemplating or (in many cases) attempting suicide has almost become part of the Trans Mythos - a story of rebirth out of the debris of a life that had been there before. I am not here to discount those stories. I believe most of them are true. I even have one myself. But I believe that for those of us in the older ‚Äútrans generations‚Äù can help younger generations find a new narrative, and set a tone where suicide is not something that is presented to someone right as they are ‚Äúwalking in the door‚Äù as it were. Let‚Äôs be mindful in our speech. \n\nI sometimes search for the term ‚Äúdetransition‚Äù on social media because that is something that I am STILL struggling through. So many of the results I get are along the lines of ‚ÄúI would rather kill myself than detransition‚Äù. I totally support the right of people to say that, but just keep in mind that for someone trying to hold their detransition together seeing this stuff online does have an impact and will have consequences of one form or another. If you need to say it, do say it. But maybe it is something you need to be saying to a therapist instead of shouting blindly out into the internet.\n\nA lot of trans people use social media to make suicide threats. I think it is a good thing that they are at least calling out for help. Many in the trans community rally around to assist these people in their time of crisis to keep them talking and distracted enough so that the suicidal moment will pass. Again, I would like to see guidelines for how these conversations should be conducted. Maybe this is already out there on the net (I know there are a number of things for the general population and I will be gathering those as well as publishing them.) If anyone has anything they can let me know about I would appreciate it. \n\nThe reason why guidelines are important here is twofold - both equally important. Firstly, it is important to know how best to interact with someone in this situation and how to make sure that they are safe and will ensure that they connect with the resources and professionals who it is critical they speak to. Secondly, and just as important, how to keep one‚Äôs self healthy in the process. Talking to someone about suicide can be extremely draining and, if not done mindfully, can seriously impact the ‚Äúhelper‚Äôs‚Äù own mental wellness. Boundaries are really important here. I think a lot of people don‚Äôt really take care of themselves when they are trying to help others.\n\nOne of the resources available to anyone in the US is the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ Their phone number is 1-800-273-8255. For those who are not familiar with how the crisis line operates, it is a federally funded non profit organization that serves as a coordination point for 165 independent crisis centers through out the country, fielding calls from people in crisis. If you are trans and in crisis, this could be a good resource for you if you are unable to find anyone else to talk about.\n\nI deliberately used the word ‚Äúcould‚Äù because right now I know that a lot of trans people will not call this number because they feel that the people answering the calls will not be sensitive to their trans identities. I was curious about this so I reached out to the training department (in another lifetime I used to do training and quality control for a group of call centers so I am interested in this stuff.) I was surprised to learn that they have not received any guidelines on how to handle trans* identified people in crisis. (This is what I was told‚Äîif this is not the case, again someone please let me know.)\n\nWhen I first approached the training department, I believe they thought I was suggesting some sort of intensive new training curriculum for ‚Äúall things trans‚Äù that I wanted the crisis line and all of its independently affiliated call centers to adopt. This is not the case. I think it can be as simple as a one sheet page of things to be mindful. I think that there is probably a way of establishing that when a caller in crisis comes through that caller is immediately given the confidence that they will be treated with the dignity and lack of judgement that is their birthright. It is also important to find a solution to ‚Äúneutralize‚Äù the negative impact that a callers perception of being ‚Äúmisgendered‚Äù might have on them. For those call centers (or individual counselors) who have difficulty using the caller‚Äôs prefered pronouns, a few tips for effective ‚Äúgender neutral‚Äù communication would be extremely helpful. It goes without saying that crisis counselors should not attempt to ‚Äùcounsel‚Äù the caller‚Äôs actual gender identity struggles. I think a reminder in guidelines would be helpful.\n\nI would like to work with others to put together such guidelines. I believe I can offer some valuable input, but I do not have the expertise to do this alone. Additionally this really needs to be put together by a diverse but unified group of stakeholders. If anyone would like to assist me in this or has recommendations of people I can approach to partner with please let me know j@retransition.org.\n\nThere is no guarantee that the National Suicide Prevention Crisis Line would follow these guidelines‚Äîbut I say it is at least worth a try and I believe these may be useful for other non LGBT-specific points of contact for people in crisis. \n\nAlso, I am hoping that some of the more prominent activists out there will build awareness that, yes, being referred to as one‚Äôs affirmed gender is important, getting ‚Äúmisgendered‚Äù is not the end of the world‚Äîespecially in matters of life or death. I believe that if the gravity and catastrophizing of getting ‚Äúmisgendered‚Äù was de-escalated a bit a lot of our trans family would find more wellness. \n\nAnd speaking of ‚Äúwellness‚Äù, there is one last point I want to make. I have watched over the last ten years as the subject of ‚Äúmental health‚Äù has been purposely driven from the larger conversation we are having about trans issues today. This is also happening at the therapeutic level‚Äîso many who express feelings of gender confusion actually lose potentially helpful psychological assistance because of the fear on the part of many providers that to dig a little deeper looking at and working through potential root causes for GID would be to dishonor their patient. A false equivalence has been set up between the unspeakable and unnecessary damage done by so-called ‚Äúreparative therapy‚Äù to some members of the LGB population with spending a little bit of time with a client presenting with gender identity issues to look for what really might be going on. I believe that it is possible to live in a world where we acknowledge that being gender non-conforming is a perfectly valid (and quite possibly immutable) foundation of many people‚Äôs identities, while also recognizing that some cross-gender behavior and ruminations can also be a red flag for something much more serious going on in the background.\n\nAnd that is the final point I want to make. We all know that the suicide rate (and the number of people who have at least contemplated it) is unacceptably high in the trans community. A lot of this IS situational. The effects of bigotry and discrimination due have their cumalative toll and there is no doubt they have been a contributing factor to some trans people‚Äôs arrival at a place where they felt they truly had no more options. Again, practicing steps toward mental wellness can be helpful here, as well as the continued efforts to promote a more tolerant and compassionate world. But I also strongly believe that there are also many deaths within our community that actually have little to do with being trans. What makes me frustrated is that I believe that many of these are preventable, but because mental illness has now been deliberately stigmatized even further in the trans community than it is for the general population (where it already carries a huge stigma all on its own) these people are slipping through the cracks. \n\nI say it is time to step forward to work toward building an environment that is safer for all and is even more respecting of everyone‚Äôs dignity. My fellow detransitioner thirdwaytrans is trying to untangle some of this in his website. Again, I know there are others out there (again, please let me know of any that you are familiar with.) In the coming days I too will be launching a website devoted to trans mental health based on some of what I have described here. It will be simple‚Äîit is just meant as another signpost for those who are struggling to find their way. In my case, my own path involved detransition, but I know this is certainly not for everyone so that is why I am planning on this second site that only focuses on trans mental health. My hope is to be one of many trans related sites that remind those who are suffering that we always have more options in life than we realize. We are never really ‚Äústuck‚Äù as long as we are here in this world alive today. \n\nI hope you join me in this conversation.\n\nJoel\nSurvivor","image_permalink":"http://retransition.tumblr.com/image/97161661248","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":1280,"height":439,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_1280.png"},{"width":500,"height":171,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_500.png"},{"width":400,"height":137,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_400.png"},{"width":250,"height":86,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_250.png"},{"width":100,"height":34,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_100.png"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_75sq.png"}],"original_size":{"width":1280,"height":439,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_1280.png"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"glaminthebox","id":97161294208,"post_url":"http://glaminthebox.tumblr.com/post/97161294208/i-swear-these-two-hate-their-photo-anywhere-but","slug":"i-swear-these-two-hate-their-photo-anywhere-but","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 feed:\n\nMost of the comments are all ‚Äúthere‚Äôs no need for this!!! We all have the same needs!‚Äù and going about how it sounds like segregation.\n\nMost of them have forgotten trans people again.\n\nI think most of the people here understand how difficult it could be for a trans woman to go to get her prostate checked or for a trans male to get a pap smear.\n\nMost of the people probably just think ‚Äúwell, suck it up and go to the doctor, it can‚Äôt be that bad‚Äù while it actually is bad enough for us to avoid them, it‚Äôs not that simple.\n\nThe doctors don‚Äôt usually know what to do with a trans person who has been taking hormones for years and suddenly they‚Äôve started getting their periods/spotting or anything else related to reproductive organs.\n\nThey haven‚Äôt been trained for those cases. I have had a doctor who didn‚Äôt even know that it‚Äôs possible to have reproductive organs removed without having a cancer or other dangerous reason for it.\n\nAnd I want to tell something from a personal experience that could have been solved in a so much easier way if we had a hospital that was specialized in trans people:\n\nDuring the summer my periods stopped. I haven‚Äôt gone on T yet and I were happy about not getting my periods, because periods are something I don‚Äôt want to think about ever let alone deal with.\n\nBut they were replaced with this continuous pain. It wasn‚Äôt as bad as period cramps, but it hurt and sometimes when I stood up I couldn‚Äôt stand because the pain became sharp and strong.\n\nIt didn‚Äôt stop during the summer but I didn‚Äôt want to go to a gynecologist. This is countryside and all of the doctors that work in the reproductive health side are really clueless about trans people. They don‚Äôt even realize that misgendering trans people is wrong.\n\nSo of course I refused to go to the doctor. I knew I‚Äôd have to go to a gynecologist if I went there. \n\nI dealt with the pain for months. My pain meds didn‚Äôt work and I admit that I were terrified about possibly having a cancer (there have been quite a lot of cancer cases in my family).\n\nI never went to the doctor and turns out the reason why my periods stopped was that I didn‚Äôt eat enough (my body had gone in to the starvation mode). Except T shirts and gym shorts or sweatpants? identity","gender expression","Chris Rijksen"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnO4pr1QV0PDb","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":42,"caption":"The Advocate had an article today on transmasculine Dutch artist Chris Rijksen‚Äôs latest work ‚ÄúGender as Performance.‚Äù \n\nGender as performance is an interesting topic for someone like me, whose sex, gender identity, and expression do not always line up. In some ways it feels shallow to imagine that such a core part of my identity is just about performance, but when you consider ‚Äúgender performance‚Äù as more than just clothes and as something we all engage in (consciously or not), it becomes a little more nuanced and complex. We all have range and variance in our identities, we all deal with the difference between our own expression and others‚Äô perceptions, and we all negotiate the expectations (on our appearance & behavior) of different spaces and contexts.\n\nThis quote from the article in particular stuck out to me in thinking along those lines:\n\n\"Some people ask me which one of the pictures I identify most with. This is a funny question, since the goal of my photo series was to go beyond this unambiguous \"real\" identity and to propose a multitude of possible identities. I do not believe in one form of identity. The spectator most likely projects its own framework of identity on the person in front of them, whether it is a photograph or a real person.\n\nWith my photos I ask viewers to reconsider the fixed I've never really known many of the names so it gets confusing a bunch of the time","answer":"well those are two very different terms and i suggest that you look into the gender portal on Wikipedia or genderspectrum.org for a more complete education on the ground level but here are some basics\n\n[all pertinent terms will be bolded with each use - i prefer bolding to quotations as quotations can sometimes give the impression that the writer doesn‚Äôt take the quoted word seriously.]\n\ncisgender: a gender identity that aligns with the physical sex you were assigned at birth (so words describing gender (girl, boy) and words describing sex (female, male) can be the same in layman‚Äôs terms, especially for cisgender [cis] people).\ntransgender: a gender identity that does not align (either partially or fully) with the physical sex you were assigned at birth; subdivisions of transgender [trans] include genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, bigender, etc., but these terms and classifications might be defined differently for every trans person you ask.\ntruscum: a class or niche community of trans individuals who believe that being trans is a medical condition, and that you must experience physical dysphoria (aka discomfort with your physical primary or secondary sex characteristics or anything else that causes people to perceive you as a different gender than you identify as) to be considered trans. \n‚Äî‚Äîthis movement finds its opposition in the next term‚Ä¶.\ntucute: a class or niche community formed in response to truscum; people who label themselves tucutes believe that you need not experience physical dysphoria to classify yourself as trans - you simply must identify with, or have gender ‚Äúfeelings‚Äù of, a label other than cis. \none could say there are varying degrees of tucute. some are simply people who do not wish to go through GRS (gender reassignment surgery), nor do they experience physical dysphoria, yet they consider themselves not cis (like my identification with the genderfluid label - i am happy presenting feminine and keeping my biologically-classified-as-female physical characteristics, but i feel like my gender is both male and female at times, or it switches, and i would be equally happy presenting as masculine except i personally feel i can‚Äôt pull it off right now).\nothers are more radical - these are the ones who come up with new gender identities daily and insist that people use nouns as pronouns (which goes against the linguistic purpose of pronouns it‚Äôs not supposed to be that repetitive that‚Äôs why they invented pronouns foir fuck‚Äôs sake) despite the fact that the pronouns may not even relate to their gender identity in any tangible way. the most extreme form of tucute (and perhaps the most pure, as it transitioned from just anti-truscum) is the idea that anything can be a gender identity and anything can be a pronoun set. \nhope that cleared some things up.\n\nnote: if anyone in these tags feels like taking me to task for the use of the words ‚Äúphysical sex‚Äù or ‚Äúbiological _______‚Äù or anything i have said that‚Äôs based in well established science, you better come correct. there‚Äôs a 99% chance i will shut you down for your ignorance - however, if you have extensive and up-to-date experience in biology and can inform me differently, i‚Äôll welcome that do I tell my parents I'm transgender how do I even tell my friends??","answer":"Zak: There isn‚Äôt one single universally good way of coming out. It really depends on your relationships with your parents and friends, what you‚Äôre comfortable sharing with them, how you think they‚Äôll respond, and the method you‚Äôre most comfortable with (some people express themselves better in writing, other people prefer face-to-face conversation). We have an article on coming out to parents that contains some advice that might help a bit. We don‚Äôt have anything specifically on coming out to friends, but a lot of the advice would be the same. \n\nI personally told a lot of my distant friends and acquaintances through a Facebook note where I could explain everything, I told many of my family members via letter, and my close friends in person. I didn‚Äôt just sit everyone down and tell them at once, for most of my friends I came out to them by telling them I was questioning my gender (because at the time I was) and keeping them updated as I figured stuff out. Since many people already have everything figured out by the time they come out to people, it makes more sense to do things differently then that.\n\nOne thing you could do with friends is show them a movie with a trans protagonist, a youtube video of a trans person, or bring up a story about a trans person and then you can start the conversation by saying ‚Äúthat‚Äôs kind of how I feel about myself‚Äù or something like that. In general, I think that giving them some context or information about what it actually means to be trans can really help make it easier and make more sense to them. Again, there‚Äôs no right way to do it. rumer","pennsylvania","mytransition"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZxWuho1QUXrCo","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"title":"Top Surgery","body":"I would like to start off by thanking everyone for the good wishes. I had been super nervous days before, and was glad that I maintained a calm composure (for the most part). I arrived at the surgery center around 6:20, waited for it to open, and headed in around 6:45. I filled out some paper work and then got taken back to get prepped for surgery probably some time after 7:00. I got into my dressings, got my vitals checked, and then signed a few more things. Another nurse came by to hook up my IV and then soon after, Dr. Rumer came over and drew on me with a purple marker.\n\nFrom there, I hopped back into bed and was then wheeled to the surgical room.\n\nMy surgery time listed on my paperwork was 7:40, but I heard a few nurses say I would be taken back at 8:00. I had no way to tell the time, so I assume I went to the operating room some time between.\n\nMy emotions and nerves were coming out in awkward laughs. I remember rolling from the bed onto the surgery table, spreading out my arms, getting my legs wrapped in something‚Ä¶and then nothing!\n\nI awoke in the recovery room with absolutely no memory. I was so out of it, and was trying really hard to wake up. A nurse kept checking on me and we had like mini conversations with me half awake. As I gained my focus back, she came over again and fed me graham crackers and apple juice, followed by a Percocet. I was still super giddy, but she commented that it was nice that I was a cheerful patient and was glad I wasn‚Äôt crying or screaming from pain. It was also great that I was not nauseous or dizzy!\n\nI was not in pain so much as discomfort, but even that wasn‚Äôt so bad. I felt like I had a super tight binder and could feel a slight ache in my chest. Honestly, from having my arms spread out, my arms were a lot more sore. \n\nSurgery was two hours long, but basically it was a gap in time for me. I was in recovery for an hour. I was supposed to fall back asleep during that time, but once the adrenaline kicked in, I was wide awake and ecstatic.\n\nThe nurse helped me get dressed and shortly after, my parents came to get me. She went over the post-op basics and the medications I had to take. She then showed me how to measure and empty my drains.\n\nFrom there, I was helped out of bed, put in a wheelchair, and taken down to my car. My dad reclined my chair, and I brought a pillow to prop myself up and be comfortable.\n\nThe car ride was fine, and I arrived at my home a little after 12:00 PM.\n\nI took some pictures for my own documentation while my parents got the couch (aka my new temporary bed) situated. I took my first antibiotic and will take my pain killers later today. And then tomorrow, I will also start back on Arnica for a week to help with the bruising.\n\nThat is it for now; I will keep you updated! I do not like people treating those headcanons like they are actual representation, because that excuses the fact that acknowledged, canon trans people are woefully under-represented in media. So trans headcanons = yes, yay, great. But please don‚Äôt act like they replace actual canon representation, because they do not.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"alexisarealboy","id":97141912862,"post_url":"http://alexisarealboy.tumblr.com/post/97141912862/so-i-just-gave-myself-my-first-shot-and-it","slug":"so-i-just-gave-myself-my-first-shot-and-it","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 15:15:20 GMT","timestamp":1410362120,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"gRIvQPhH","tags":["transsexual","transgender","transguy","hormones","trans","ftm","testosterone"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZZzDoo1QU6-KU","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"So I just gave myself my first shot and it actually wasn‚Äôt even hard. \n\nIf the needle were any bigger, we might have a problem though‚Ä¶","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"aidenparkerstransition","id":97141873294,"post_url":"http://aidenparkerstransition.tumblr.com/post/97141873294/had-my-blood-work-done-today-if-everything-goes","slug":"had-my-blood-work-done-today-if-everything-goes","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 15:14:32 GMT","timestamp":1410362072,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"a8KVBpMU","tags":["ftm","trans","female to male","transguy","transman","f2m","ht","testosterone","transition","t"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-49cm1QU6rgE","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"","body":"Had my blood work done today! GMT","timestamp":1410361080,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"3jeR1FPm","tags":["darkmatterrage","poetry","poem","spokenword","trans","lgbt","violence","america","queer","sadness","depression","trauma"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zeieis1QU3qAv","followed":false,"post_author":"queerlibido","highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":263,"title":"funeral","body":"our train is delayed and i am late for lunch\n  with a boy i like because he makes me feel\n  less lonely and that seems like a sufficient\n  definition for love these days\n  in this city where it is possible to be surrounded\n  by the warmth of millions of apartment lights and\n  still feel cold\n\n  the lights turn off.\n  and it‚Äôs one of those moments\n  when we are forced to look up from our screens \n  and remember that we exist outside of them\n\n  they tell us that someone jumped in front of the tracks\n  that he died upon impact\n  so we just sit there in silence \n  as they remove his remains. \n\n  and some part of us\n  is happy because this, \n  this is the first time we have\n  felt like part of something greater than ourselves in a while\n  in this city where sometimes it takes\n  an accident to remember what the purpose of a\n  body is to begin with.\n\n  when the train starts up again\n  the woman next to me starts complaining\n  and asking why he didn‚Äôt do it at home\n  how he could have saved us the trouble and time\n  by taking a bottle of pills before leaving the house\n  how selfish it is to delay others with your death\n\n  and i want to hug her \n  say: ‚Äúremind me the purpose of this arm‚Äù \n  want to love her \n  say: ‚Äúremind me the purpose of this heart‚Äù \n\n  but you see this is america\n  where people scatter on streets like discarded leaves ‚Äì \n  only touching accidentally as we\n  land on these cities we grew up circling on maps\n  saying ‚Äúremind me happiness‚Äù\n  and somehow convinced ourselves they did\n  the same way we believed in the borders between\n  countries so well that we built a wall around\n  them: called it ‚Äòmine‚Äô\n\n  this is america \n  where pain is a ritual we are required to conduct in private:\n  an elaborate symphony on mute\n\n  call it ‚Äúhe died in his sleep peacefully‚Äù\n  (as if the stroke did not tear him to pieces)\n\n  call it ‚Äúhe lived to be eighty six years old‚Äù\n(as if he didn‚Äôt hate himself for at least thirty of them)\n\n  call it ‚Äúaccident‚Äù\nnot no healthcare \n\n  call it ‚Äúcasualty‚Äù \nnot calculation\n\n  in america:\n\ndeath is a distraction.\n  it is thirty of us sitting together underground on a subway train\nunable to hold each other and weep so instead\nwe sit in silence and wait until we can move again\nback above ground\ninto the light\nand forget how much death must be in the soil\nto grow such \nbeautiful \ndenial\n\ni want to text the boy above ground waiting for me, ask:\n\"have you ever been to a funeral with complete strangers?\"\n  but instead i look at the woman next to me, the one\n  who told a dead man to die more considerately and\n  i remember that to live in america is to attend\n  a funeral with complete strangers: \n  how many ghosts does it take for a cemetery to call itself a country? \n\n  to live in america is to blame the\n  dead for their own death, not\n  the country for creating the very\n  conditions that already killed them\n  before they caught up and\n  made things more clear\n\n  which is why when i tell the\n  liberal who wears words like ‚Äòdiplomacy‚Äô\n  and ‚Äòdemocrat‚Äô that i will not pay his taxes\n  because i do not want my coins to cause carnage\n  and he calls me a terrorist\n  (i understand)\n\n  which is why when i tell him\n  that i do believe in monsters who come\n  out at night, call them ‚Äòmen‚Äô for short\nand he tells me that i only dress femme because i want to be bashed\n  (i understand)\n\n  which is why when i tell him\n  that the very women who started our movement\n  are still being murdered in the same cities where\n  men are getting married and calling it momentous\n  and he gasps: ‚Äúthat happens here? in america!‚Äù\n  (i understand)\n\n  the ways we have been taught\n  to apologize for our sadness.\n  to blame ourselves for the hurt.\n  to erase the violence.\n  to numb the pain.\nto normalize the death.\n  to wake up in the morning and\n  deny that sometimes when the\n  train crawls into the station that\n  we may see a pill in its place. \n  that we may wonder what it\n  would mean to have people\n  empathize with our suffering\n  for once in our goddamn life\n  what it would feel like\n  to hold the captive attention\n  of a funeral of strangers\n\n  so i want to embrace to this woman on the train\n  and say: ‚Äúi am afraid too‚Äù \nsay: ‚Äúremind me trust‚Äù\n  say: sometimes this silence feels like the highest pitch of screaming. \n  say: i understand. say: these past thirty minutes were the first time i have \n  been forced to publicly grieve death in a long time\n  and there is something\n  beautiful about that \n  say: what if we stopped moving more often, \n  took a second to \n  absorb the pain,\nlet it fill us a little less empty.\n\n  but instead i will sit here and wait until the train starts up again.\n  i will exit the car without saying goodbye to her.\n  i will walk up the stairs to the boy outside with the smile that makes me feel less lonely. \n  i will apologize for being late.\n  i will not have the words for a type of loss that is so distant it is intimate.\n  after lunch later i will get back on the train.\n  i will remember. \n  i will soon forget.\n_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ \nthis is an original poem by alok of returnthegayze.com . please consider supporting the artist","can_reply":false}]
