trans","lgbt","lgbtq","lgbtqteens","youth","college","Lance Cox"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZOVy1n1QTx3Mj","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"For Trans Students, College Can Be a Safe Haven....But What If Campus Isn't Trans-Inclusive?","body":"This week, transgender writer and activist Lance Cox ‚Äî who is currently a Junior at an art college ‚Äî describes his personal experiences facing barriers to trans-inclusion on campus, and pinpoints where changes need to happen.\n\n[This piece is excerpted from a longer anthology chapter entitled ‚ÄúDid I Ask For This?‚Äù in Manning Up: Transsexual Men on Finding Brotherhood, Family, and Themselves (Transgress Press, 2014)]. \n\n~~~\n\nAs I entered my senior year of high school, I couldn‚Äôt help but count down the days until I could escape my town, my small-minded classmates, and even my family. I decided on an art school that I thought would completely fit my needs: it had a diverse curriculum and a supposedly diverse community, with resources for LGBTQ students and several queer events each semester. [‚Ä¶] I hoped that by leaving my hometown, I could get a new start in the city and leave everyone, including my ‚Äúformer self,‚Äù behind. \n\nAnd, in essence, I succeeded. \n\nWhen I started college, I got the fresh start I was looking for, found allies on campus and off, and now have a sizable community of other trans*, queer, and allied individuals that love and support me. \n\nBut at what cost?\n\n~~~\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nThis experience hasn‚Äôt turned out to be everything I expected.\n\nWhen I came to campus, there wasn‚Äôt a process to get one‚Äôs preferred name on class rosters, IDs or any other documents. I had to email every administrator and instructor I was going to come into contact with and explain not only what the word ‚Äútransgender‚Äù means, but that I will need them to make a mental note of my name and pronoun preference.\n\nI was frustrated by having to disclose my identity without meeting these people beforehand, but I was also scared. I constantly found myself wondering, What happens if an instructor disregards my requests and uses an incorrect name or pronoun during class? What will the other students think? Is this safe?\n\nI didn‚Äôt have the answers and I was terrified ‚Äî not only that I might be misgendered, but that the other students in the room wouldn‚Äôt know what that meant and that they would react in a violent way.\n\nAt the absolute least, being misgendered in the classroom was a huge distraction. Around week ten, after everyone in my classes started to get to know each other, I once had an instructor refer to me with female pronouns. I could sense each of the fifteen students in the room take a breath together, and time seemed to stop to allow everyone to process what had just happened.\n\nAfter that, not only were my classmates confused because they knew me as a man, but I became completely closed off; it made learning astonishingly difficult. There were times that I would skip class in order to avoid being put in that situation again.\n\n~~~\n\nGender-inclusive housing wasn‚Äôt an option for me either and I found myself living with four girls.\n\nI ended up spending most of my time outside of my dorm, in study lounges or with friends, and avoided being ‚Äúhome‚Äù as much as possible. My roommates would consistently use my preferred name and disregard pronouns, which made me weary of spending time with them or around anyone I hadn‚Äôt yet met. \n\nEvery time I walked up to my apartment door, I began worrying that someone would see me enter it or spot our names on it and wonder why there was a male name among four female ones. What would happen if someone saw that? Would they ask someone about it? Would they ask me about it?\n\nMy first year in college was meant to be a new beginning ‚Äî a way out of a destructive space. The problem is, as an incoming freshman, I wasn‚Äôt prepared to embark on a journey of activism or become the face of the trans* rights movement on my campus.\n\nPolicies should have been in place to accommodate my requests as a transgender student before I ever set foot there. I shouldn‚Äôt have to be asked time and time again to educate the faculty and staff, regardless of whether or not I would like to do so. Theoretically, I should be able to let my studies come first but the fact is, it doesn‚Äôt always happen that way.\n\n~~~\n\nFor some students, entering college may be a time when drugs, alcohol and socializing are their main focus; for others, student organizations and leadership roles fill that space. For me and other transgender students, activism becomes our main priority because it has to.\n\nThe need for safe, gender-inclusive housing and restrooms, a name-change process, inclusive health insurance, and a large range of queer studies courses is stronger than ever. College is a time of awakening, self-discovery, and growth, but until institutions embrace gender variance, higher education will continue to be as dangerous as elementary, middle, and high school can be.\n\n[‚Ä¶] Today, after finally coming to terms with my trans* identity as well as my queer sexuality, I have found myself in an incredible place. Sure, I‚Äôm working non-stop to pay my bills, both transition-related and otherwise, and I‚Äôm always a little worried that someone is going to disclose my identity without my consent in the classroom.\n\nBut now I choose to tell my story to faculty, staff, and students alike to create impactful change on our campus.\n\nIn the year that I‚Äôve been doing this work, a name-change process has been put in place, single-stall restrooms now have proper, gender-inclusive signage, and we are working on safer, trans*-friendly housing. \n\nI didn‚Äôt necessarily seek to be an activist, but I‚Äôm not sure anyone does. Activism comes with a sense of necessity: If my college isn‚Äôt inclusive enough for me to be fully content, how do I make it so? How will what I do affect those who come after me?\n\nSo, did I ask for this? No. Is it fair? Definitely not. Does it take away from my studies and other college experiences? Sometimes. But is it important? Is it rewarding? Absolutely.\n\n~~~\n\nPhoto courtesy of Flickr. this about getting drunk?\nYesterday, after the Otoo-san LIVE was over, I went to eat with Yamada.\n\nAh, Yamada is‚Ä¶\n\nA member of Gekidan Patch, a Kansai version of D-BOYS, he is a guy that loves anime and idols, and somehow me? \n\nHe came to my solo event ‚ÄúPotential in about Lukewarm Water‚Äù in July this year when it was held in Osaka.\n\nThat was a chance to be friends with him, just nice he came to Tokyo so we went to eat together.\n\nIf I say this it might anger those living in Kansai, but I heard that Kansai people can speak really well and its true.\n\nI was defeated by him speaking from the beginning to the end (laughs)\n\nLeaving that aside I, drink liquor which was uncommon for me.\n\nStarting with beer.\n\nI drank a sip and gave it to Yamada, next is plum wine.\n\nI drank about this much.\n\n\"Eh? You aren‚Äôt even drinking at all!\"\nI heard a voice saying that, but for me drinking this amount is already amazing.\n\nSomehow my head felt howan~, and my eyes felt toran~, is this getting drunk?\n*howan and toran are sfx, basically there are things mostly used in manga for sound effects.\nHowan - soft and warm\nToran - drowsily\n\nPerhaps this is the first time experiencing being drunk.\n\ntrans. cr; shin @ bakamitaii¬†; take out with full I‚Äôm that vintage and I loved the New Kids On The Block back when I should have been wearing acid wash guess jeans, pony tails, hair bows, reading seventeen, indulging in other terrible fashion trends and talking with friends on my phone tethered to the wall. \n\nInstead I was the girl hiding from everyone but still listening to NKOTB, only in my case with headphones so to keep to myself. \n\nOne evening in the privacy of my own room I tried to steal a moment for myself to be real. I was rocking to Hanging Tough, it just happened to be the song at the moment. I was singing out loud even though no one else could hear the music playing. My sister walked in on me and caught me singing to her favorite band. I don‚Äôt even know if she knew I listened to them before that time, I hid well.\n\nEither way, she laughed, I did too, I was embarrassed but it wasn‚Äôt a bad moment. I just thought I was alone. Kind of like when you are caught dancing by yourself and for yourself, you might be startled and embarrassed but it‚Äôs not a big deal. I don‚Äôt remember much else about that night. I do remember the solitude of my room, the comfort I found there. Sometimes I felt safe enough to peak out and take a look around, in this case singing along to NKOTB as a thirteen year old girl.\n\nSo I told her this memory not even an hour ago by text and she remembered it well. I said, ‚Äúthat was me.‚Äù I think something happened to us both. I cried, I think she teared up. We had a moment. We had a moment that connected our new sisterhood to our unknown past sisterhood.\n\nWe can‚Äôt read seventeen together or talk about boys, or complain about the mean girls or help each other with the struggles of early fashion and the pressure to be cool, what to say and who to be friends with and all the drama as we both emerge from childhood into our teens, but we can still be sisters even if we missed the dress rehearsal.\n\nWe still are sisters and now we have a memory of our past to share and to build upon as we take on the current challenges of parenthood, marriage, career and life together. \n\nI love you.\n\n-brunette","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"radiowiresoverthesea","id":97110168919,"post_url":"http://radiowiresoverthesea.tumblr.com/post/97110168919/i-just-want-to-give-a-shoutout-to-some-transmen","slug":"i-just-want-to-give-a-shoutout-to-some-transmen","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 03:12:36 GMT","timestamp":1410318756,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"EFTe61Yz","tags":["transgender","ftm","transguy","trans","transman"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZH5pmw1QSDvLN","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"","body":"I just want to give a shoutout to some transmen. being trans, is sex weird for you? have you ever felt like having a sex change? were you trans before meeting your wife? does your wife call you her wife?","answer":"I will answer these in reverse, because, reasons!\n\nMy wife calls me her partner, just as I call her my partner. It works for us!\nI definitely had trans feelings before I met my now partner. We met in high school, and so at the time I was unfamiliar with the term transgender, and was still very closeted. I had the (false) impression that maybe having a girlfriend might stop them‚Ä¶so I did not tell her until we had been dating a little longer and were both in college. But yeah, I first noticed my gender dissonance around age 10/11 and it has been with me ever since.\nI talked about gender confirmation surgery a little earlier today, so I am not going to rehash that too much. I have done my research, and I am just not interested in pursuing a full medical transition. I have absolutely had days where I have wondered if a social transition with (or without) hormones might be the right path for me, but for now this is where I am‚Ä¶somewhere in a fuzzy middle-ground. It works.\nI do not go too many into (personal) details about sex on here most of the time, but yeah, as a trans person there can definitely be some extra layers when it comes to my gender identity/body dysphoria and intimacy. Is sex weird for me? Not particularly, I am a very sex-positive individual, and have learned to love myself. There may be some extra layers, but that is about it.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"plankingsucks","id":97104076328,"post_url":"http://plankingsucks.tumblr.com/post/97104076328/im-kinda-cute-sometime-idk","slug":"im-kinda-cute-sometime-idk","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 Holyoke's President Announced a Huge Change for LGBT Students With an Emotional Speech","url":"http://mic.com/articles/91479/mt-holyoke-s-president-announced-a-huge-change-for-lgbt-students-with-an-emotional-speech","link_image":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbnbrtofOq1rge4f6_og.png","description":"It‚Äôs the second women‚Äôs college to enact this new policy.\n\nFor several years, America‚Äôs most prestigious women‚Äôs colleges have opened their hallowed halls to scores of eager incoming freshmen ‚Äî that is, unless you‚Äôre transgender.\n\nThis week, Massachusetts school Mount Holyoke became the second women‚Äôs college (after Mills Collegein California) to announce it will be accepting applications from female transgender students. Mount Holyoke president Lynn Pasquerella made the decision public during an emotional speech as part of the college‚Äôs convocation.\n\n\"We recognize that what it means to be a woman is not static ‚Ä¶ We acknowledge that gender identity is not reducible to the body,\" Pasquerella said in the speech, appearing to wipe away tears. \"Our new policy formally welcomes applications from ‚Ä¶ anyone who is female or who identifies as a woman.\"\n\nPasquerella clarified that Mount Holyoke needed a ‚Äúformal policy‚Äù that would ‚Äúarticulate our commitment to core values of individual freedom, social justice and diversity and inclusion.‚Äù The college, she said, ‚Äúhas welcomed trans students in the past and for several years ha[s] been in conversation with campus constituencies about how best to foster a respectful environment for all students.‚Äù But it was still important for university administrators to send a clear, welcoming message to the trans community.\n\nThe change in policy comes amidst a tense debate within feminism about transgender inclusion. In her speech, Pasquerella referenced the thinking of mainstream feminists, who decades ago argued against biological determinism in order to gain societal advancement. This logic, she observed, can be similarly applied to the decision to accept applications from all students.\n\nSo far, the new policy has received unanimous support from the LGBT community, which has called for women‚Äôs colleges to open its doors to trans students in recent years. While they have generally been considered bastions of the liberal arts, women‚Äôs colleges have stayed surprisingly conservative in their understanding of gender when it comes to their admissions policies. Some cite the red herring of Title IX which, up until this summer, provided a loophole to women‚Äôs colleges regarding their single sex status. The Department of Education has since extended protections to trans students.\n\nThe issue attracted national attention last year, after Calliope Wong was denied admission into Smith College due to a so-called ‚Äúgender inconsistency‚Äù in her application. The Federal Application for Student Aid (FAFSA) identified her as male, and this inconsistency effectively nullified her candidacy. ‚ÄúYour FAFSA,‚Äù read Wong‚Äôs rejection letter, ‚Äúindicates your gender as male. Therefore, Smith cannot process your application.‚Äù\n\ncontinued‚Ä¶","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"aerinisababe","id":97093000192,"post_url":"http://aerinisababe.tumblr.com/post/97093000192/i-know-there-was-a-post-going-around-a-little","slug":"i-know-there-was-a-post-going-around-a-little","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 I've found this prosthetic tht has absolutely everything I need but it's on the (very) expensive side of things. Do you have any tips on how to save up at least $1,000 + and relatively fast?","answer":"I have no brilliant schemes to making money fast, sorry! My suggestions are probably ones you have already thought of, but: are there ways you can pick up extra work/hours? Someone understanding who you can get a loan (full or partial) from? Odd jobs you can do (animal watching? yardwork? whatever?)? Gofundme? Camming? There are obviously pros and cons to each.\n\nI am no expert on packers, but $1K+ definitely strikes me as expensive. Not saying it is not the right one by any means, but is there any way you can manage with a lesser/cheaper packer while you save up for the perfect one? Might help ease the waiting process a little.\n\nTake my advice with a grain of salt though, my breast forms are on the cheap side‚Ä¶but hey, only Navyy and I get to/have to see them, so it does not bother me. am a cis female, but from my extensive work with the trans community, the majority perfer to just be asked \"what are your pgp? (perfered gender pronoun)\" but only if the topic has been brought up. You obviously don't ask a person out of the blue if they're trans. If a misgender has been made, simply say \"sorry\" and move on (drawing attention and making a big deal makes the misgendering worse) and TRY VERY HARD NOT to make the mistake again.","answer":".","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"kityanpoet","id":97085736150,"post_url":"http://kityanpoet.tumblr.com/post/97085736150/fall-tour-season-has-started-im-heading-to-suny","slug":"fall-tour-season-has-started-im-heading-to-suny","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 21:53:58 GMT","timestamp":1410299638,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"CcyBLKw3","tags":["queer","trans","qtpoc","asian american","trans*","lgbtqia","activism","art"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZIp8_q1QQmiJM","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"caption":"Fall tour season has started! You are pretty awesome.\n\nCrowdfunding for trans-related care (hair removal/surgeries/therapy/etc.) seems to be pretty common these days, which is maybe both a good reminder of how cool the internet can be and just how crappy healthcare coverage is for this sort of care. But I am glad that option is out there for people, cool stuff.\n\nThat said, I feel a little hesitant about accepting money from other people for this stuff for me. I may not be as financially comfortable as I would like to be, but I do have a good job and with a little budgeting and the help of Groupon this seems pretty attainable with my current means. While some new scandalous trend is emerging every day, there‚Äôs one particular LGBT (famed for their questionable morals) fad that is hitting the surface: transgendered children.\n\nThis one has republicans dazed and confused and parents wrapped in knots. Children as young as five years old are being given the chance to choose which gender they‚Äôd like to mirror. In this, parents allow their daughters or sons to wear the opposite sex clothing, and they take further measures to present the appropriate gender‚Äôs style, i.e. long or short hair, or in older ages, makeup.\n\nIt‚Äôs arguable to say that there should be no borderline for people and what they do, and all should be able to choose what they wear and do with their hair and faces limitlessly, but it is clear that parents and their children are going for choosing between a boy or a girl for their everyday life. In fact, in ages as young as eleven, parents have taken steps to insuring that puberty is stinted for their children by administering a certain drug. For Dr. Olson, a specialist in this bizarre condition in Los Angeles, it is called ‚ÄòSupprelin.‚Äô\n\n‚ÄòSupprelin‚Äô is an implant that goes in the arm and provides enough hormones to block puberty for a year. It‚Äôs a thin, inch-long capsule filled with the hormone stuff. With this, girls who long to be boys may avoid developing breasts and other methods of maturation, and boys wanting to be girls evade facial hair and other pubescent nuances.\n\nThis growing swell of children who seek early gender reassignment suffer from a dysfunction known as ‚Äúgender dysphoria.‚Äù\n\nAccording to the DSM, gender dysphoria is the ‚Äúconflict between a person‚Äôs physical gender and the gender he or she identifies as.‚Äù\n\nDr. Olson tells CBS News that the number of people with this odd condition has had a 330 percent increase over the year of 2013. Estimated, it effects 0.5 percent of the adult population, or 700,000 Americans.\n\nWho‚Äôs to say why this condition is suddenly poking its head? Is it a matter of more children being born with this dysfunction? Is it something in our food or something in our lifestyle? Or is it merely the way of life morphing into that of a more accepting one? With the growing LGBT support, with numerous allies all across the world, it could be that people who had long suffered with this condition are coming out of the woodworks, and in turn encouraging children to do the same. Our young people are being taught that it‚Äôs most important to feel comfortable in your own skin, despite the repercussions.\n\nIn reported cases of gender dysphoria, 89 percent of children experience harassment at school or other social venues. This couldn‚Äôt be some game to them if it meant risking any friendships they once had to be the black sheep.\n\nMany agree that the parents are to blame, as well. (Also sorry for any possible English mistakes, I'm not a native speaker.)","answer":"Men and women are binary genders, binary meaning ‚Äúrelating to, composed of, or involving two things.‚Äù. For a long time gender has been considered binary except for in a few cultures that have third genders based off gender roles. However, in most cases, these genders aren‚Äôt considered trans due to the facts that they‚Äôre based on gender roles and that third gender members of the cultures have asked to not be considered trans.\n\nNon binary is a word to describe trans people whose gender is not the two binary genders (man and woman).\n\nAgender and bigender are non binary genders.\n\nNon binary people face a unique set of problems specific to them. While trans men and women are gaining visibility and acceptance, though at a slow pace, and have hormone therapy and surgeries available to them, there is currently very little visibility for non binary people, a lot of gender therapist are unaware of non binary genders, and little to no research has been done for hormone therapy and surgeries for them.\n\nAlso, trans people are considered freaks by a lot of people and even more people consider it freakish to desire no sex characteristics or characteristics of both sexes.\n\n  \n\nI‚Äôve personally looked up the possibilities for agender people and came across a story of someone who wished to neutralize the sex characteristics of their body but was instead pushed into a full transition to female instead.\n\nI‚Äôve asked people about it as well and been blown off with a ‚Äúwhy would you want to mutilate your perfectly fine body?‚Äù\n\nI‚Äôm hoping as binary trans people get more recognition, non binary trans people will as well.\n\n(you‚Äôre not coming off as rude at all! I made this blog so I could help out and one of the best ways to do that is answer questions. Also, I didn‚Äôt notice any english mistakes! There‚Äôs only one problem with Maxine‚Äîshe already has a girlfriend, perfect Becky.\n\nJayla quickly falls under Maxine‚Äôs spell, and she‚Äôs willing to do anything to win her. But when Becky turns up dead, Jayla is pulled into a tangle of deceit, lies, and murder. Now Jayla is forced to choose between love and the truth.\n\n Jayla will need all the strength she has to escape the darkness that threatens to take her very life.\n\nReview: This book is so refreshing! It features a lesbian trans lead, with a sassy bi trans best friend. The writing is really tight and focussed and the background of the characters transition is explained quickly without seeming like an info-dump. \n\nThe story starts at a queer prom, after an intriguing flashforward prologue. I love how the story shows trans people how to deal with unwanted attention and awkward questions about their body and gender, which is something that can be really useful for teenagers.\n\nOverall this seems to be a trans story with a lot of potential! I‚Äôm saying that self medication isn‚Äôt ideal (it objectively isn‚Äôt), but that it‚Äôs sometimes necessary and a good option for people who otherwise have no access to healthcare. Self-medication can be life-saving, as I wrote in the article.\n\nStill, in a UK context, where there‚Äôs a national health service that‚Äôs free to use, the fact that self-medication persists shows that the health & social care system has big problems. Trans: A Straight, Cis Man Tells a Trans Woman How to Behave","url":"http://www.slate.com/blogs/outward/2014/09/01/a_straight_cis_man_tells_a_trans_woman_to_take_the_night_bus.html","link_image":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbn6jqR8v21r1legn_og.jpg","description":"I was raised and socialized as a boy, and I was read as a boy everywhere I went. Getting to be a boy, socially, was the definite upside to the experience. So by social protocol, a guy can talk loudly, interrupt a certain amount, and arrogantly presume his righteousness, all while remaining safely within the social ‚Äúbro‚Äù zone. On the other hand, if I perform too many of the same behaviors, I would cross the ‚Äúbitch‚Äù threshold, and thereby lose my credibility at the table.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ellen-is-on-oestrogen","id":97063221359,"post_url":"http://ellen-is-on-oestrogen.tumblr.com/post/97063221359/gender-identity-clinics-have-a-reputation-in","slug":"gender-identity-clinics-have-a-reputation-in","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 16:13:01 GMT","timestamp":1410279181,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"oGvVgwQq","tags":["transgender","trans","trans healthcare","hrt","self-medication","mental health","northern ireland"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZwIxis1QPQpXl","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":85,"caption":"Gender Identity Clinics have a reputation. In times gone by (and still to this date, at some clinics), healthcare providers have required trans people to navigate ridiculous and unreasonable obstacles before being granted access to treatment. Requiring stereotypical gender presentation, being ‚Äúout‚Äù to everyone prior to treatment, ‚ÄúReal Life Experience‚Äù (the requirement to change gender presentation prior to treatment, a practice that still exists and puts patients in danger), insistence upon gender-nonconforming career changes, unhelpful mental healthcare and the rejection of patients seen to be ‚Äúnot trans enough‚Äù are just a few of the historical problems with GICs. \n\nI don‚Äôt think we talk about self-medication in the trans community nearly enough. In a UK context, the fact that self-medication still exists shows big problems with the healthcare system, and addressing the need to self-medicate is useful for addressing larger problems in GICs and gender services as a whole.\n\nI wrote this in a short span, and although I‚Äôm not happy with it, I‚Äôm out of things to say on the issue right now. Self-medication is (rightly so) a controversial issue, but I don‚Äôt think ignoring it does any good, and nor does outright condemning it.\n\nLike everything, middle grounds can be useful.\n\nHave a read, sure! It‚Äôs about 2,000 words but it‚Äôs not that long.","image_permalink":"http://ellen-is-on-oestrogen.tumblr.com/image/97063221359","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":1280,"height":960,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_1280.jpg"},{"width":500,"height":375,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":300,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":188,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":75,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":1280,"height":960,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_1280.jpg"},"exif":{"Camera":"LGE Nexus 5","ISO":248,"Aperture":"f/2.4","Exposure":"1/100th","FocalLength":"3mm"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"queerinshiningarmour","id":97063141458,"post_url":"http://queerinshiningarmour.tumblr.com/post/97063141458/someone-message-me-and-be-friends-with-me","slug":"someone-message-me-and-be-friends-with-me","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 16:11:33 GMT","timestamp":1410279093,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"nxMWVd4i","tags":["bored","talk to me","ask me","trans","queer","teach me stuff"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnAV5r1QPQW1I","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"Someone message me and be friends with me.","body":"I‚Äôm bored and wish to talk about things.","can_reply":false}]

If I want a really close shave, like if I am going out, I will often shave once with and then once against the grain. That seems to work fairly well for me. I am planning on getting some laser hair removal done in the not too distant future (maybe this next year?) which, if nothing else, should help to reduce the number of darker hairs I have on my face. That is definitely going to be a big help in giving me more confidence to wear less (or no) makeup out more often.\n\nBeyond that electrolysis is the most permanent solution for removing facial hair, and is the recommended route to go (after laser) for most people who are transitioning.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"theyarebangtan","id":97061713336,"post_url":"http://theyarebangtan.tumblr.com/post/97061713336/starcast-bts-changes-into-flower-youngsters-for","slug":"starcast-bts-changes-into-flower-youngsters-for","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 15:45:53 GMT","timestamp":1410277553,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"bdaW8PiR","tags":["bts","bangtan","bangtan boys","star cast","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z5Bger1QPL3Mu","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":51,"title":"[STARCAST] BTS, changes into ‚Äòflower youngsters‚Äô for Chuseok! excellence"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZhhVMp1QPKlRK","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"So I came out to my Speech professor as genderneutral last week, and I just wanted to write about how it‚Äôs actually been really, really amazing. More after the break, if you care to read. \n\n<!-- more -->\n\n  My Speech professor is an older guy, and a longtime theater professional. He‚Äôs performed all over the world, with a ton of very prestigious companies. Therefore, he‚Äôs a very intimidating presence in my campus‚Äô theater department. Phil is the kind of person who you would grovel to get his approval, and probably cry if he ever got mad at you. I was thoroughly scared to have a class with him this semester, but I knew as long as I did the work and applied myself, it should totally go okay. \n\n  Well, I discovered that Phil has a very strange way of trying to include everyone. He‚Äôs making an effort not to be sexist - which I can totally appreciate - when he says things like ‚Äòladies and gentlemen‚Äô and things like that. Turns out he was completely ignorant to the category of ‚Äòother‚Äô than I and other non-binary students fall into. \n\n  One day last week, he said something about ‚Äòladies and gentlemen,‚Äô and for whatever reason, went onto a tangent (as he‚Äôs prone to do) about all the million ways one can say ‚Äòladies and gentlemen.‚Äô I felt so uncomfortable; I‚Äôd honestly never wanted to leave a classroom as badly as I did right then. But I took a deep breath, steeled myself, and just chimed up ‚Äúor others!‚Äù\n\n  He stopped, sort of cocked his head, and said, ‚ÄúWhat does that mean?‚Äù \n\n  I said, ‚ÄúLike trans people. Not everyone fits into ladies and gentlemen.‚Äù \n\n  He then told us a story about a trans woman actress he used to work with, doing his best to use correct pronouns (something I can sort of excuse - he‚Äôs an older gentleman, I give him credit for working to correct himself), and told us that she played ‚Äúthe best Richard III I‚Äôd ever seen.‚Äù It was a clue that I could continue and correct him to what I was speaking about. \n\n  ‚ÄùYes, that‚Äôs important, but I was talking more about non-binary trans people.‚Äù\n\n  He naturally gave me a look of confusion, having never heard the term before. So I explained in a very general sense what the phrase could mean and the people that could use it, and explained how I personally use it. Now, mind you, this was in front of my whole class, which is a small core of about 12 people that I‚Äôll be spending the rest of my college career with - my voice was shaking and I wanted to throw up. \n\n  However, Phil just sat back, listened patiently, and thanked me for bringing it up. He apologized, saying, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry that anything I‚Äôve said has made you uncomfortable, that‚Äôs not at all my intention.‚Äù And I accepted his apology, told him it was really only that day. \n\n  We continued on with class, and I went home. I felt pretty good about the whole scenario; he had seemed genuinely interested in what I was saying, had agreed to work on using my preferred pronouns, and the class seemed to also show a lot of support. Any sick feeling I had had dissapated, and it was really validating to have found a professor who genuinely cares - I know that‚Äôs actually pretty rare to find. \n\n  The next day, I was walking into my morning class and I got a text from Phil. He was thanking me again for bringing something up, and told me that he had been doing research on his own all night the previous evening. I almost started crying in the middle of the hallway - he has no investment in me or non-binary trans people, he doesn‚Äôt really have to care, but since I introduced him to it he took it upon himself to seek information. He genuinely wanted to make his classroom better for me and for any student like me who might follow. I was overwhelmed, and I texted him back with a profuse gratitude. I also mentioned that I have a ‚Äòzine written by the amazing Ollie Schminkey, full of information and resources for instructors with trans students. He was so excited and wanted me to email it over to him as soon as I could. \n\n  Well, funny thing. For whatever reason, I kept getting error messages that said the file was too big. The whole weekend went by and I couldn‚Äôt get it to him or think of a way to link him to this .pdf on my computer. \n\n  When we walked into class yesterday, he said his hellos and then looked at me with a little point and head nod of ‚Äòoh, I just remembered!‚Äô He asked me about the ‚Äòzine, and if I had sent it. I told him I was having troubles, and he sat with me for about 10 minutes, sending test emails, making sure I had the right address, and eventually came up with a solution to get the ‚Äòzine to him. After class, he even pulled me aside and asked for my help to brainstorm better ways to speak, and very respectfully asked what he had said that bothered me so he could eliminate it. I gave him a huge hug before I left, almost wanting to cry out of joy again.\n\n  I‚Äôll be hearing from him probably tomorrow about the ‚Äòzine, and any other questions he was left with after reading it. I guess I just wanted to write this to let people know that coming out, talking about things you have problems with, and asking for respect isn‚Äôt as terrifying as I think most of us believe it is. I knew it could have gone horribly wrong. I know that there are quite a few of my professors that I couldn‚Äôt have that kind of conversation with. However, I was stunned to find out that things could also be so positive. I‚Äôm still a little in disbelief over the fact that someone I barely knew devoted an evening to research, and actively working to get a better understanding on my situation that didn‚Äôt involve drilling me with a million questions. \n\n  Don‚Äôt be afraid to demand the things you deserve. Don‚Äôt be so petrified by the fear of everything that could go wrong that you never find out if it could be great. \n\n  And thank you again to Phil Hubbard, probably the best teacher I‚Äôve ever encountered. \n\n  For anyone else that wants the ‚Äòzine: I have a .pdf on my computer that I would absolutely be willing to send out. It‚Äôs very well-written and is full of other links, resources, and ‚Äòfurther reading,‚Äô written by the brilliant Ollie Schminkey. They‚Äôre one of the leading queer activists and poets, who attend Macalaster University and runs the slam poetry team there. They have one published book of poems, and they‚Äôre featured in an anthology compiled by Andrea Gibson. They‚Äôre the best of the best and would love the ‚Äòzine to be distributed. If you‚Äôd like it, shoot me a message with your email and I‚Äôll send you a Dropbox link, and you can use it to send to your professors before the semester (or during!) as an aid in coming out and asking for your preferred name/pronouns.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"trans-parenting","id":97061557705,"post_url":"http://trans-parenting.tumblr.com/post/97061557705/wondering-why-you-arent-interested-in-a-sex-change","slug":"wondering-why-you-arent-interested-in-a-sex-change","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-09 15:43:04 GMT","timestamp":1410277384,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"8M5QvYbT","tags":["transparenting","trans","transgender","surgery","gender identity","gender dysphoria","questions","Anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnO4pr1QPKTN9","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":33,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Wondering why you arent interested in a sex change?","answer":"Because for me it is not worth it.\n\nI am really glad gender confirmation surgery options exist for trans people who need them - and I am a huge advocate for making them more accessible and affordable. That said, they are not for me.\n\nMore after a break, because, genitals, oh my!\n\n[[MORE]]\n\nGender confirmation surgery (aka. sexual reassignment surgery‚Ä¶or a ‚Äúsex change‚Äù) is expensive - like thousands or tens of thousands of dollars expensive (often not covered by insurance). You have to jump through a number of medical hoops to make it a possibility, and like any major surgery there can be complications - it is not uncommon to have at least some loss of sensation, and that is not even taking into account what impact it can have on relationships. Trust me, the people who are seeking this surgery really need it.\n\nI do not. I have come to terms with having a penis, and I feel like the trade-offs are simply not worth it. I do not see myself as any less ‚Äútrans‚Äù or any less ‚Äúfeminine‚Äù because of it.\n\nTo put it another way, from a recent Huffington Post article by Justin Ropella: \n\nSurgery is absolutely not a requirement for or condition of trans*ness. For some people gender-confirmation surgery is a personal necessity, a life-or-death need. For others it‚Äôs not. For some the medical risks aren‚Äôt worth it. For some it‚Äôs a financial impossibility. And, believe it or not, some trans* people simply don‚Äôt want any kind of surgery. Each person is different.\n\nThere are times where having a penis can be inconvenient, like wearing a bikini to the beach - as I pointed out in my post on swimming & dysphoria. And yeah, the whole testosterone thing is not really up my alley. But the rest of the time, non-issue.\n\nMy dysphoria is mostly social in nature - having to do with where/how/when I can express my gender - beyond that my physical dysphoria comes almost exclusively from secondary sex characteristics, rather than genitals. I worry about losing the hair on my head, I feel discomfort with having the extra body hair that testosterone brings, beard shadow is lame, and I can get bummed about not having boobs. I am planning on having some laser hair removal done on my face, and if I were to transition I would most certainly do hormone replacement therapy, but I have no need for surgical interventions.\n\nIf I were to wake up tomorrow in a body that was fully female with nothing else changed I would be happy and have no regrets or feelings of loss. But as it stands, I embrace the body I have and deal with the things that are dissonant as I need to.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"t-dude-diego","id":97061256071,"post_url":"http://t-dude-diego.tumblr.com/post/97061256071/mornin","slug":"mornin","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 15:37:00 [{"blog_name":"atranspaige","id":97051189556,"post_url":"http://atranspaige.tumblr.com/post/97051189556/new-narratives-2014-a-needed-breath-of-fresh-air","slug":"new-narratives-2014-a-needed-breath-of-fresh-air","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 12:05:00 GMT","timestamp":1410264300,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Zlokr7Sg","tags":["transgender","trans","transsexual","trans activism","new narratives","NN2k14"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZoCmnm1QOiw4q","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":21,"title":"New Narratives 2014: A Needed Breath of Fresh Air","body":"I mentioned it before, I was one of the people who attended New Narratives. There‚Äôs already a couple of excellent posts,about NN2k14 from two of the organizers, Snowflakeespecial and Mindergenfield, that you can read. \n\nI wasn‚Äôt one of the organizers, so I can‚Äôt really tell you about the goals of the event or if it should be considered a success. I wasn‚Äôt even one of the good people who took notes. What I can tell you is my personal thoughts and feelings from NN2k14.\n\nIt was amazing!\n\nI was surprised at how quickly I became comfortable around everyone there. In many ways New Narratives felt more like a support group than the trans support group I had attended. I actually felt safe to talk and voice my opinions. \n\nIt‚Äôs a good thing too because we talked and talked and talked. We talked so much that even after it was over several of us went to a bar and talked for like 2 hours more!\n\nYou‚Äôd think with all that talking that we would have come to some sort of consensus, but no. The only consensus was when we already agreed with each other.\n\nMostly New Narratives was a chance to air my grievances with certain aspects of the trans community; share my story with people I felt would actually listen and could understand; and gain some new perspective from listening to other people talk about their life and being a trans woman.\n\nMost importantly to me, it was a chance to do all this in person. Writing online is great. It‚Äôs let me talk to so many people across the globe that I‚Äôd have never met in my lifetime otherwise. Still real conversations are lessened when they only occur online. There‚Äôs something missing when you can‚Äôt see someone‚Äôs face. When you can‚Äôt hear the emotion behind their words. I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs some people who would describe it as better and more ‚Äúrational‚Äù that way. I don‚Äôt know about you, but rational does not describe the internet I‚Äôve been on. \n\nWe didn‚Äôt just talk that day. In fact the thing I remember best was when we did a group walking meditation. It seemed a little silly, but it also felt good. It was supposed to help reconnect with your body, and I think it could it could really help. There were a few times I had to stop myself from laughing though. I couldn‚Äôt help it, I just started picturing some random person walking by and seeing a group of people walking in circles with their eyes closed.\n\nOnce everything was said and done, well everything that could be said in a day, I was really glad I‚Äôd gone. I loved New Narratives. I made some new friends there. It‚Äôs what pushed me to start this blog and actually start talking to some people in real life about the problems within the trans community. (+)","answer":"(-) I don‚Äôt really worry about other people‚Äôs sexualities and genders as long as they‚Äôre happy with themselves (and I would want to help the fight you‚Äôre all giving from my position as much as possible) but it would be awesome to understand it because if I understand it maybe I can make other people understand and maybe stand from a less (unacknowleding) transphobic position? Idk. Anyways, thank you! :)\n  _______\n  Hi! Not sure how specific you‚Äôre wanting but I‚Äôll give a quick run through of the basics and add a few helpful links. It‚Äôs always nice when allies want to help.\n\n  First off, a few distinctions should be made.\n\nSex- one‚Äôs physical attributes which distinguishes them as male, female, or in the case of intersex people, somewhere in between (there is a wide variety of intersex conditions, but that is another topic for someone more informed on them such as prototran).\n\nGender - how one‚Äôs mind perceives what sex they should be. When one‚Äôs mind perceives they should be neither male or female they are agender. When one‚Äôs mind perceives they should be both simultaneously, they are bigender.\n\nNonbinary- genders other than male or female\n\nGender roles - societal roles based on one‚Äôs gender. As society in most cases does accept non binary genders, there are no roles for bigender or agender people. This is just as well as gender roles are basically society/culture wide stereotypes and I think we can all pretty much agree stereotypes suck.\n\nGender non conforming - cis and trans people who don‚Äôt conform to gender roles\n\nTrans - people whose gender does not match their sex.\n\nDysphoria - the feeling one gets when their sex and gender do not match. It can vary anywhere from a mild disconnect to a hatred of sex characteristics. It can also manifest as disassociation or depression.\n\nPrimary sex characteristics - sex characteristics pertaining to the reproductive system\n\nSecondary sex characteristics - Characteristics that are basically side effects of sex hormones, suxpch as amount of facial/body hair, size of hands, facial structure, breasts or lack of and so on.\n\n  Sometimes it can be tempting to ask trans people invasive questions out of curiosity but always consider first if you would ask a cis person the same question and if the question could possibly trigger the trans person‚Äôs dysphoria. Before delving into their personal life, ask yourself if you really need to and ask them what they‚Äôre comfortable talking about if anything.\n\nQuestion that would be helpful to ask a trans person would be things like ‚Äúwhat topics should I avoid around you to make sure you‚Äôre comfortable?‚Äù (A good question to ask any friend really, trans or not) ‚Äúwho are you out to/what gender should I refer to you as with who?‚Äù (To avoid outing them and making situations unsafe for them) and similar things.\n\n  An important thing to remember is that gwhile gender dysphoria can lead to hatred of sex charectistics gender dysphoria =/= self hate. Body dysmorphia and gender dysphoria are very different things and I think this link describes the differences well- http://amydentata.com/2012/03/06/the-difference-between-dysphoria-and-negative-body-image/\n\nA simple guide on how to respect trans people: http://m.wikihow.com/Respect-a-Transgender-Person\n\nFor those dating a trans person (it was written specifically for those dating trans men but can easily cover other transgender partners): http://theartoftransliness.com/post/5017698937/how-to-love-and-support-your-ftm-partner-or-your-soffa\n\n  If you‚Äôd like to help support trans artists, here‚Äôs our pages for that (and if you know anyone we can add, please let us know. We‚Äôre also open to adding other minority artists/authors/etc.): http://notyourqueertheoryposterchild.tumblr.com/trans%20artists\n\nhttp://notyourqueertheoryposterchild.tumblr.com/tagged/support\n\nIn comparison to gender, sexuality is a bit more straightforward, especially when keeping it simple and general.\n\nIt‚Äôs what gender you‚Äôre attracted to.\n  Heterosexual - attracted to the opposite sex/gender\n  Homosexual - attracted to the same sex/gender\n  Bisexual - attracted to two or more genders\n  Asexual - sexually attracted to no one\n\nAsexual people can still be romantically attracted to people, just not sexually attracted. They can have relationships. I‚Äôm an asexual trans person in a relationship with a cis hetero man.\n  Bisexual people can have preferences of one gender over another.\n\nAnother person you can ask about these things is genderspatial, he‚Äôs pretty knowledgeable, and if you have more specific questions, I‚Äôm open to answering more.\n\n***\n\nI (Wulver. ohai.) would like to add some tidbits.\n\nIf someone whose gender is masculine/male is ‚Äúgender nonconforming,‚Äù that does not mean he is transgender. If someone‚Äôs gender is feminine/female, but they are physically male, and YET, they are still more socially masculine, that doesn‚Äôt mean they are not transgender. Gender and gender ROLES are two separate things.\n\nIf a woman is very socially masculine, but her gender is still feminine/female, she‚Äôs not trans just because she is gender nonconforming.\n\nFor a real example - I am a transgender man. My body is female, and I have the dysphoria (disconnect, which is unsettling, but not the same as hate - I‚Äôm pretty darn pretty, I just am disconnected and it‚Äôs not the place I feel I should be) and yet, I‚Äôm still socially feminine. The gender role says that if I‚Äôm female, then I have a certain place in society and have a socially stereotypical way to act, think, and talk, etc.\n\nBut because my gender is not female/feminine, that contributes to people not taking me seriously whenever I talk about this kind of thing. I may like to sew and art and cook and do my hair (like the stereotypical woman) but my brain still tells me, through dysphoria (again, not hate, just disconnect) that things aren‚Äôt quite right. I‚Äôm trans when I‚Äôm doing my makeup. I‚Äôm trans when I‚Äôm squealing like a little girl over something. I‚Äôm trans when I‚Äôm shopping and cooking and picking out my clothes out of a huge collection.\n\nI‚Äôm done. Just wanted to clarify that point because it seems it‚Äôs one of the points people have a particularly hard time with.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"insidethechrysalis","id":97042721223,"post_url":"http://insidethechrysalis.tumblr.com/post/97042721223/had-my-first-transgender-support-group-meeting-in","slug":"had-my-first-transgender-support-group-meeting-in","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 07:53:32 GMT","timestamp":1410249212,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"rurA6YMV","tags":["trans","transgender","ftm","support group"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZCAA0s1QOCcd7","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"Had my first transgender support group meeting in a long time.\n\nThen I get home and dad has a go at me because for some reason he thinks he is entitled to know the birth sex of the people running the group, and doesn‚Äôt think that me refusing to tell him is fair.\n\nAll you have to know is who they identify as now. The rest doesn‚Äôt matter to you. Kindly get that through your skull, and stop yelling at me for respecting my fellow transgendered people.","can_reply":false}]

My dad‚Äôs blowing his shit at me because I‚Äôm not comfortable acting or looking ‚ÄúFemale‚Äù. \n\nI was always told to let the man handle it, to stay away from the tools and learn how to cook. Reprimanded for not knowing how to clean, and praised when I was able to do theatrical makeup simply because it was makeup. Now that I‚Äôm out these traits I was put down for are suddenly more desirable. I‚Äôm a techie on the drama club, in the robotics team, in a STEMs school, and now working on cold fusion. Why is it that if I happened to think that I was a female that I would be frowned upon? Why is playing with the neighbors‚Äô kids suddenly okay?\n\nAnd yet, my parents will still correct people when they call me male. Even complete strangers still get a tongue lashing. Just the other day I was at the vet‚Äôs office, crouching down to check on one of the animals. I was asked politely to move so someone could get past me, and this person added the formality ‚Äúyoung man,‚Äù to the end. I was pretty pleased, but my mother felt the need to stop this man and correct him, saying I was biologically female, and then proceeded to point at my chest. \n\nNow, I love my mother to death. She‚Äôs a very sweet person and a huge factor as to why I‚Äôm still around, but holy fucking shit did that hurt. I was out to her, and she still found the need to call me ‚ÄúHer little girl‚Äù and buy dresses and offer to enroll me in Girlscouts. It‚Äôs the same thing with my father, only without the passive-aggressiveness and mutual caring. Why do parents feel the need to try and change something that‚Äôs already set in stone? You can‚Äôt melt the stone down and reforge it. You can weather it, crumble it. Take the dust and put it under pressure so it reforms, but that isn‚Äôt the same rock. It has a different composition, and it‚Äôs much weaker than it was before. \n\nI just want to know how to talk to them without being ignored.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"yunhoparadise","id":97037455075,"post_url":"http://yunhoparadise.tumblr.com/post/97037455075/trans-night-watchman-jung-yunho-the-tears-acting","slug":"trans-night-watchman-jung-yunho-the-tears-acting","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 05:42:37 GMT","timestamp":1410241357,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"1Br3Aiwh","tags":["tvxq","dbsk","yunho","trans","proud fan here"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZyyEdr1QNuWxZ","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":43,"title":"[trans] \"Night Watchman\" Jung Yunho, The \"tears acting\" which overpowered the controversy over his acting abilities","body":"*note - there are spoilers in this article.\n\n In the 11th episode of ‚ÄúJournal of Night Watchmen‚Äù, actor Jung Yunho has, through his ‚Äútears acting‚Äù filled with genuine emotions, overpowered the controversy over his acting abilities which had previously surrounded himself. \n\n -spoilers omitted-\n\nIn the past, Moo Seok‚Äôs sister was inflicted with smallpox and died while being watched over by Moo Seok. Moo Seok said while his tears spilled over, ‚ÄúIt would be great if I had been the one who got inflicted instead. There is nothing I can do for you. Even when our mother and father passed away, there was also nothing which I could do for them‚Äù.\n\n In this scene, Jung Yunho, who takes on the role of Moo Seok, let loose an explosive outburst of emotions when faced with the death of his sister, and displayed his smooth flowing acting abilities. Through his ‚Äútears acting‚Äù which captured the attention of viewers and his heart-wrenching gaze, it was sufficient to stimulate the tear glands of the viewers.\n\n In the past, Moo Seok consistently faced everybody and everything around him with a cold and serious attitude, and appeared as a character wearing a veil over him. However, while the past of Moo Seok whereby he had lost his sister in childhood and deeply kept the hurt in his heart was revealed in this day‚Äôs episode, the sympathy of the viewers built up when faced with Moo Seok, who had naturally fastly closed the doors to his heart and lived a lonely life to this day.\n\n U-Know Yunho, who had made his debut through TVXQ‚Äôs single album ‚ÄúHug‚Äù in 2004, held active activities as a singer and thereafter appeared in MBC‚Äôs Wednesday-Thursday drama ‚ÄúHeading to the Ground‚Äù in 2009 and last year‚Äôs SBS Monday-Tuesday drama ‚ÄúYawang‚Äù etc, building up his filmography as an actor. However, compared to the full-time actors, he was caught up in controversy over his relatively weak emotive expressability and excessive gestures.\n\n Prior to this, at the production press conference for ‚ÄúJournal of Night Watchmen‚Äù held in Junifer Hall of the 63 Building in Yeongdeungpo, Yeouido, Seoul, on 29 July, regarding the controversy surrounding him as regards his acting abilities, he had revealed his strong ambitions, ‚ÄúIt is my first time in a period drama, and having started out as an idol, I had heard a lot of various criticisms. I have said before that I want to become an actor who gradually grows / improves. I think that I should let my genuity-infused acting pick up through this production‚Äù.\n\n Jung Yunho has stamped on the controversy and he is resolutely attempting challenges in the new field of period dramas through ‚ÄúJournal of Night Watchmen‚Äù, showing his extraordinary courage. In this regard, he put in his never-ceasing hard work and effort (the Korean phrase literally means ‚Äúblood-inducing effort‚Äù, i.e. putting in tremendous effort), and showed everybody his surprising growth, personally proving that he is progressing as an actor. This is the reason why one cannot help but pay attention to the growing phase of Jung Yunho, reborn as an actor from being an idol.\n\n.\n\nf: newsen | Trans by LG-F400L"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"variegatedpoise","id":97036556198,"post_url":"http://variegatedpoise.tumblr.com/post/97036556198/we-need-a-national-conversation-about-transphobia","slug":"we-need-a-national-conversation-about-transphobia","type":"quote","date":"2014-09-09 05:24:00 GMT","timestamp":1410240240,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Agkd8VIP","tags":["feminism","feminist","lgbtq","trans","trans*","gender","equality","racism"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z7sU4y1QNr5Uc","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"source_url":"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/terry-oneill/why-transphobia-is-a-femi_b_5785820.html?ncid=fcbklnkushpmg00000046","source_title":"The Huffington Post","text":"We need a national conversation about transphobia, which dehumanizes, demeans and disadvantages a specific group of people. This is a feminist issue on two levels. First, like racism and homophobia, transphobia grows out of and helps perpetuate the same patriarchal ideology that dictates women‚Äôs subordination as second-class citizens. Second, transphobia disproportionately harms women.\n\nTrans women face higher rates of discrimination, violence, sexual assault, and poverty. Around half of all victims of anti-LGBTQIA homicides in 2012 were transgender, and all of them were women of color.\n\nBlack and African-American transgender women have a 50 percent greater homicide rate than their white, Latina, and Native American counterparts and were more than three times as likely to experience police violence more than any other group, according to a 2012 report by the National Coalition of Anti-Violence Programs on LGBTQIA and HIV Affected Hate Violence.\n\nThese are all civil rights violations because they are rooted in the denial of a person‚Äôs right to be who they are. Equal means equal. That includes equality for all women, not just a certain type of woman. Not just women who look like me!\n\nThe consequences of violating these fundamental rights are not just the alarming rates of homelessness, unemployment, access to health care, economic insecurity, depression and suicide, but also the weakening of the very fabric of our society.\n\nIt diminishes all of us when one type of person or group is targeted, and when they are denied the basic understanding, compassion and protection we all expect and deserve.","source":"From the article ‚ÄúWhy Transphobia is a Feminist Issue.‚Äù\n\nTerry O‚ÄôNeill President, National Organization for Women","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"edwarddequeer","id":97036554884,"post_url":"http://edwarddequeer.tumblr.com/post/97036554884/17-18-19","slug":"17-18-19","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-09 05:24:54 GMT","timestamp":1410240294,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"u6KTSFIh","tags":["personal","me","queer","gay","trans","books","death tw","suicide tw maybe","idk not exactly but i feel like i should probably tag it","notanotherprotagonist","ask","message","question"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZETyTv1QNr5A4","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"asking_name":"notanotherprotagonist","asking_url":"http://notanotherprotagonist.tumblr.com/","question":"17, 18, 19?","answer":"17. favorite fairy tale?\n\nI think Hans Christian Andersen‚Äôs The Little Mermaid. I like the strength and the integrity of the little mermaid. She‚Äôs a very self-motivated, independent, driven character. And she sacrifices so much‚Äînot just her tail, not just all her life, but she sacrifices herself and her happiness and puts the happiness of the one she loves ahead of her own. She‚Äôs very hard-working and also a dreamer, someone who believes she can shape her own destiny, as impossible as it may seem. Idk it‚Äôs a very depressing fairy tale but I‚Äôve always loved it. Also apparently it was supposed to be a metaphor for HCA‚Äôs own gay relationship, and I‚Äôve also seen trans interpretations. So that just adds another queer layer that I like a lot.\n\n18. what would you do if you knew it was the last day on earth?\n\nFind my way back to Paige and spend every last second with her. If the world is ending, I‚Äôm not going out any way other than wrapped in her arms.\n\n19. is there anyone you would die for?\n\nObviously you can never really know unless you‚Äôre in that situation. But I think yes. Maybe I wouldn‚Äôt if I were actually faced with the possibility, but at this moment in time, definitely yes. Paige. Children I nanny/teach. My friends. Tbh I‚Äôd probably die for most people, I don‚Äôt think my life is worth very much compared to so many others. There are amazing people out there who are going to accomplish so much with their lives and I‚Äôm probably not like I‚Äôm pretty useless as a human being, so yeah I‚Äôd probably sacrifice myself for a lot of people. wow okay that came out a lot more suicidal than I intended, don‚Äôt worry about me, I‚Äôm not planning on actually putting this into action or anything. I wouldn‚Äôt really be able to live with myself if I knew I could have saved someone‚Äôs life and didn‚Äôt, also, so that‚Äôs another factor to consider.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"weareone-blog","id":97036089213,"post_url":"http://weareone-blog.tumblr.com/post/97036089213/trans-140908-sm-choreographer-instagram","slug":"trans-140908-sm-choreographer-instagram","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 05:16:01 GMT","timestamp":1410239761,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"q2icKhrT","tags":["exo","exo-k","chanyeol","140908","trans","Sm","choreographer","instagram update","instagram","update","photo"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnEEpr1QNpJTz","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"caption":"[TRANS] 140908 SM Choreographer Instagram Update:\n\n\"Must be very busy‚Ä¶ Thanks to our EXO for taking care of me „Öã Lovely Chanyeoli~! GMT","timestamp":1410239700,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Ymgr0sLJ","tags":["transgender","trans","ftm","transwife","testosterone","ourstory"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZDD2Qy1QNpEdt","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"Tomorrow is a big day at our house‚Ä¶ Jackson starts testosterone!\n(I‚Äôm pretty sure I won‚Äôt be sleeping tonight.)\n\n It feels like it‚Äôs all happening so quickly, but it in reality, this has been a long time coming.\n\n Not long after Jax came out as trans, we began looking for a doctor who could help him start the process of transitioning. We found one doctor who decided Jax was just unhappy and needed some strong antidepressants. Needless to say we never saw him again. Living in such a small state, our resources felt limited as we continued to look for any sign of help.\n\n About two months ago, we found Amy Herb through our insurance provider, and since then, we‚Äôve never looked back She instantly recognized the fact that Jax had been living as a man for the last five years and referred us to the Mazzoni Center in Philadelphia.\n\n We were able to expedite the process of starting testosterone treatments due to a cancellation at the Mazzoni Center. \n\n Now we‚Äôre on the eve of a huge turning point in our lives and I‚Äôm feeling conflicted. I am so happy we‚Äôve finally reached the point where this is happening, but it doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs easy. There‚Äôs an uncertainty, the fear of the unknown.\n\n But above all that I realize that I am in love with this person. If he looked at me tomorrow and told me he wanted to be a zebra with purple stripes and plaid hooves, I would still want to be with him forever. We‚Äôve weathered so many storms, there‚Äôs no one that knows me better, and no one I would rather spend the rest of my life 03:09:25 GMT","timestamp":1410232165,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"yoZg7wIN","tags":["What is","Feminism","Radical Feminism","Trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z6gxtx1QNHxj9","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":10,"title":"What is: Microaggression","body":"A Microaggression is a brief, everyday exchange that sends a denigrating messages to certain individuals because of their membership in a group that is typically not the speaker‚Äôs own.\n\nMicroaggressions happen predominantly as a part of every day speech, and are matched to membership in the respective member‚Äôs out-groups and in-groups.\n\nAMITAI ETZIONI is a professor of International Relations at George Washington University, and finds the notion of microaggressions to be annoying because, in their words, they are ‚Äújust human nature‚Äù, citing sociological understanding of a social psychology and psychological concept that actually describes what he is saying is just human nature, and the negative effects thereby.\n\nIn fairness to him, he is more focused on international policy and tends to promote an idea of ‚Äúpost human rights‚Äù, so it isn‚Äôt exactly like he‚Äôs particularly good at these aspects. Just nosy enough to stick his nose into an area he knows little about. Which is notable since her refers to it as a new idea.\n\nThe idea of microaggressions was first broached by Harvard Professor Chester M Pierce, then later expanded by MIT Ombudsman Mary Rowe, and now covers a range of characteristics that describe the particulars of interpersonal communication.\n\nA key aspect to microaggressions is that they are not overt acts of hostility, but rather ones that happen without someone realizing it. This is what distinguishes a microaggression from outright discrimination. The user simply doesn‚Äôt know they are being a twerp, or, as described by Derald Sue Wing, ‚ÄúMicroaggressions are considered to be different from overt, deliberate acts of bigotry, such as the use of racist epithets, because the people perpetrating microaggressions often intend no offence and are unaware they are causing harm.‚Äù\n\nMost perpetrators of microaggressions consider themselves to be unprejudiced, with one U.S. study finding that even mental health professionals with extensive antiracist training engaged in microaggressions with African-American clients.\n\nSO they are something that we see quite often, and on tumblr, the use of microaggressions is often met with sharp criticism and cries of racism, sexism, etc, in an unusual demonstration of expecting people to be fully versed in them and hyper vigilant about their own language.\n\nAn intersting thing about microaggressions is that deeply stigmatized people will even use them self referentially, and perpetuate the cycle even when they themselves are hyper aware of these things.\n\nThis is one of the aspects of internalization.\n\nmicroaggressions make them feel invisible, exhausted, frustrated, powerless, emotionally detached, helpless or tense.\n\nThey may also feel a pressure to conform, a loss of their own integrity, or a pressure to ‚Äúrepresent‚Äù their group.\n\nOver time, the cumulative effect of microaggressions can lead to diminished self-confidence and a poor self-image, and potentially also to mental health problems such as depression, anxiety and trauma.\n\nMany researchers have argued that microaggressions are actually more damaging than overt expressions of bigotry precisely because they are small and therefore often ignored or downplayed, leading the victim to feel self-doubting rather than justifiably angry, and isolated rather than supported.\n\nOn the other hand, some people report that microaggressions have made them more resilient.\n\nResearch has shown that when women experience microaggressions, they may become depressed, develop low self-esteem, or experience sexual dysfunction. Some develop eating disorders and body image issues.\n\nResearch has shown that microaggressions can lead people of color to fear, distrust and avoid relationships with white people.\n\nThree commonly used forms of microaggression against trans people assert one of three aspects:\n\nBeing trans isn‚Äôt natural (trans women are men, it is a choice, etc)\nConflation with child abuse/Sexual abuse (trans women represent a threat to children/women)\nBeing Trans is sinful\nThe astute may note that the same three core concepts are used against most groups that are marginalized at some time or another (lesbians, gay men, women, Black people, etc).\n\nTumblr happens to house one of the most important collections of microaggressions on the web: http://microaggressions.tumblr.com/\n\nI heartily recommend you follow them.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"autumn-in-washingtonsquaregarden","id":97027260373,"post_url":"http://autumn-in-washingtonsquaregarden.tumblr.com/post/97027260373/some-people-are-trans-some-people-are-cis-male-or","slug":"some-people-are-trans-some-people-are-cis-male-or","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 As much as I applaud others who have transitioned in life, I didn‚Äôt want it for me. I see how society at large is still unaccepting of trans people. I just want to live a normal boring life. As much as I want to further LGBT rights, I want to do this as an ally, not one of the letters. But I‚Äôve finally accepted that I am in that acronym. I am a ‚ÄúT‚Äù. The thing I struggle with now is to let everyone else into the revelation or not. My choices seem to be; live as an unhappy woman accepted by people, or live as a trans man and face a life alone. Neither seems particularly great.\n\nI‚Äôve had many people tell me to just be me. That I‚Äôm the only one I have to live with. If people can‚Äôt accept me than I don‚Äôt need them in my life. I know my family will always love me and accept me. But I‚Äôm scared of them not accepting the real me. Seeing who I am on the inside. I worry it will cause a divide. I‚Äôm very close to both my parents and my brother. It would devastate me to lose that closeness.\n\nMy other concern is romantic in nature. I‚Äôm attracted to men. So, I‚Äôm a gay trans man. I‚Äôm also a virgin. Not the best combination. I‚Äôve hated my body so much that I can‚Äôt imagine letting someone touch it. I can‚Äôt even find someone to love me now. But there are far fewer than there are straight men.\n\nOr, I can just act like a straight woman and hope despair doesn‚Äôt take over my life. If there was a pill that would make me cis, I‚Äôd take it in an instant.\n\nThe point of this post is not to get sympathy. And I don‚Äôt want platitudes or ‚Äúanswers‚Äù. have been seeing a therapist for a while now. First, it was a marriage and family therapist with no specific knowledge of transgender issues. She was very helpful and allowed me to lay my thoughts and feelings out and help organize and make sense of them. She didn‚Äôt do that much work but she sure helped me do some.\n\nNow I have begun to see a therapist that has far more intimate knowledge of the LGBTQ community and is very much involved in the local transgender activities. She has been very helpful. Guiding me and asking thought provoking questions of me but not guiding in the sense of ‚Äúoh yeah! you need hormones and surgery and stuff‚Äù. She allows me to open up and she pokes me enough to help me evaluate me. She helps me find the tools to speak with my wife about these issues and where we should go. I am feeling better with her.\n\nAs of our chat today I will be setting an appointment to see a local doctor. He will be doing my blood panel and we will be discussing hormone treatments. This step may be the one that destroys my marriage. The step that begins the true transformation into womanhood. For me this is huge. Finally moving toward the goal. Being a woman in more physical form. \n\nI‚Äôm so very excited but now there is homework to do. I have been assigned, by my therapist, to go home and talk to my wife. Talk to her. Calmly with no yelling and wanton destruction of pedestal fans. To gently re-invite her to look at this journey that I am taking. To allow her to see what she can or will. To also re-invite her to see this therapist or one of her choosing. For me to help give her the tools to examine her love for me and how she may, or may not, accept my being transgender.\n\nIf she can take time to learn, even if she decides to move on she may do so with the knowledge of what‚Äôs happening and not just myth and superstition. Maybe she will take my invitation or perhaps she won‚Äôt. We have not had a really good productive talk for a long time. This will be a bit hard for me, to speak with her honestly and plainly without having a fit and acting like an idiot.\n\nI am also supposed to sit with her, if she‚Äôll let me, and watch the documentary Trans. I have not yet seen it and I hope she‚Äôll watch it with me. We can only wait and see.\n\nI‚Äôm still excited no matter what happens. I‚Äôll keep you posted.\n\nHUGS for all of you.\n\nKatie","accepts_answers":true,"can_reply":false}]

Whether or not someone is cis is not grounds enough for me to hate them, and it would be utterly pointless. Just like how it would be pointless for someone that is cis to hate me because I am trans*. 21:29:31 GMT","timestamp":1410211771,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"uo2TP64U","tags":["Transgender","Trans","gender","Transgender Transitions","Kay Siebler"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZMn2Nw1QLfJo3","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"So that ugly ‚ÄòTransgender Transitions‚Äô reading of course had a prompt on my D2L.\n\nHere‚Äôs the prompt and my response:\n\nPrompt:\n\nRiki Wilchins (transgender activitst and founder of GenderPAC) wrote in her piece entitled ‚ÄúA Continuous Nonverbal Communication,‚Äù that ‚ÄúGender is like a lens through which we‚Äôve not yet learned to see. Or, more accurately, like glasses worn from childhood, it‚Äôs like a lens through which we‚Äôve always seen and can‚Äôt remember how the world looked before. And the lens is strictly bifocal. It strangely shows us only black and white in a Technicolor world.‚Äù\n\nDo you think Siebler would agree with this idea? What issues of gender politics are a play in the (attempted) cultural and social undestanding of transgender identity and media respresentation? Does an individual‚Äôs ability to consume and create content (and identity) via a digital medium help to mitgate the issues of gender politics? What examples of a mediated trans identity do we have? \n\nMy response:\n\nI wrote two posts on my personal blog while reading this piece, I had a very strong reaction to it, and was, honestly, offended that the first time I find transgender people discussed in an academic textbook it starts off talking about and framing the conversation around a white, cisgender, heterosexual man.\n\n‚Äî-\n\n\"Transgender characters such as Laverne Cox on ‚ÄòI Want to Work for Diddy‚Äô, Carmelita on ‚ÄòDirty Sexy Money‚Äô, and Isis King on ‚ÄòAmerica‚Äôs Top Model‚Äô all fit the ‚Äòchick with a dick, gay barbie‚Äô stereotype of MTF transqueers.\" (136)\n\nTwo of the three people that Siebler is writing about here are transwomen. One I know for a fact is self-identified as a transwoman. Siebler, who just earlier was praising Tim Curry for his embracing of femininity (‚ÄúIf we did not want to be just like Curry *and* his character, we wanted to be his friend.‚Äù) Boldly attacks tranwomen for theirs, ‚ÄúShe (Laverne Cox) is articulate, smart, and politically astute. But these dynamics of her politics and intellect never make it to the ‚ÄòI Want to Work for Diddy‚Äô show where she plays a stereotypical ‚Äúgay Barbie‚Äù with big hair, Valley Girl language and glamorous fashion.‚Äù\n\n‚Äî-\n\nSiebler does not write of trans people in a language that suggests that they are trans themselves. And yet, whether trans or not, they seem hyper-critical of the fact that transpeople go to great lengths to ‚Äúpass‚Äù without giving any space to discussing the experiences that trans people have as living trans and navigating the world as trans that causes them to feel a need to move towards spaces of ‚Äúpassing‚Äù one way or the other.\n\nWith those posted, I can more directly address the prompt now.\n\nI very much believe that Siebler would agree with Wilchins. Siebler espouses how much they view Dr. Frank-N-Furter as the technicolor to an otherwise black and white world.\n\nWhat issues are at play? We have issues of representation - both quantifiably, but also qualitatively. What qualitatively qualifies as a transgender person in the media. Siebler gives the reader the impression that Timothy Curry and Ru Paul in drag are at the forefront of what it means to be transgender, while transwomen such as Laverne Cox and Candis Cayne are simply reinforcing gender stereotypes and acting out for the camera (see my quote from Siebler above). So there we have what qualifies as a stereotype and what qualifies as authentic gender expression at play. We seem to also have at play this cissexism and man-identified-centrism that plays out (thus why we see Curry raised up and praised, while Cox is vilified). This all seems to play into, or at least feed off/fuel the oppositional idea, that these women (Cox, Cayne) are not real women, and so when they enter women‚Äôs spaces, they are thusly violating women and their (women‚Äôs) spaces. This can be seen exemplified best in the fascination with genitalia, which I‚Äôve already talked about extensively, and in the bathroom panic craze that is fuel by the media.\n\nI fully believe, and have it exemplified in my own life, that a person‚Äôs ability to consume and create content via a digital medium can help to mitigate the issues of gender politics. The popular blogging site Tumblr is where I finally found the language and community to be comfortable and out, at least to myself, as transgender, as a transwoman.\n\nBy ‚Äòexamples of a mediated trans identity‚Äô, do we mean, like in my case, that I mediated my gender identity (in part) online? Do we mean the way that trans people are prevalant in media (i.e. Laverne Cox, Buck Angel, Ryan Cassata, Fallon Fox, Janet Mock, Laura Jane Grace, etc.) or do we mean the overall ways in which trans identities are mediated (ie. by actual trans people, by heterosexual cisgender men, by heterosexual cisgender women, etc.)?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"rimjets","id":96999469591,"post_url":"http://rimjets.tumblr.com/post/96999469591/hudsons-guide-myths-and-misconceptions-about","slug":"hudsons-guide-myths-and-misconceptions-about","type":"link","date":"2014-09-08
