(1/2)","answer":"(Label person - 2/3) Also, I read that blog, even though seeing a website with the word ‚Äútheist‚Äù in the URL did somewhat deter me at first I still read it; it wasn‚Äôt really focused at people like me who think, in a simple sense, we ‚Äúhave enough labels‚Äù, it was primarily directed towards people who disagree with labeling on the whole, which I do not. If you‚Äôre curious by the way, I‚Äôm also someone who disagrees with the hijacking of the word ‚Äúgender‚Äù - there are only two genders in my opinion.\n\n(Labeling person again lol, I changed my mind from X/2 to X/3, so 3/3) Also, in terms of biology and representation, I understand that someone who was a woman and now is a man is now a man, I‚Äôm not saying they aren‚Äôt, I‚Äôm just saying beyond a man and a woman there‚Äôs nothing, even asexuals for example, they‚Äôre still either men or women, having sex or lack there of doesn‚Äôt define your gender etc.\n\nI needed to add a ‚Äòtransphobic‚Äô to it too, which I have just done (since you were primarily attacking trans people, seems like). It doesn‚Äôt matter if you think non-binary genders exist or not, they do & will exist with or without your input. Your opinion is irrelevant to their existence.\n\nAlso, you don‚Äôt know what asexuality is. Asexuality is not a gender, it‚Äôs a sexuality (or a lack of, if you prefer). You might want to google it.\n\nWhilst we‚Äôre at it, you don‚Äôt really know what gender is, either. 19:11:39 GMT","timestamp":1410203499,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"JeepYwV2","tags":["trans","definitions","Anonymous","rezi gets asks"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZYHEZq1QL0OYk","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Could you explain what a- or bigender is? If gender is the set of genitals you're the most comfortable with, then a/bigender should mean that you want neither/both of them, shouldn't it? But AFAIK, no one gets their genitals removed without a substitute, or the \"missing\" set together with the one they already have. If it's more like a Idon'tgiveafuck-gender, then why make a big deal out of it by yelling at people who got your pronouns wrong? I just don't understand it.","answer":"To the best of my knowledge:\n\nAgender- Needing the sex characteristics of neither sex in order to lessen dysphoria. This is a sucky situation to be in, because without massive nullification surgery (which is usually illegal), it‚Äôs nearly-impossible. Of course other dysphoria-reducing methods can be employed, hormones, pronoun changes, surgeries to remove obvious secondary sex characteristics, etc. \n\nBigender part one- Someone who fluctuates between two genders. Some believe this to be a case of mistaken normal symptoms as something else. Since dysphoria fluctuates in every trans person, binary or no, it might be possible bigender people are binary but have very strong fluctuations. My thought is that it is most likely that, but it could also (maybe) be a rapid-cycle version of part two.\n\nBigender part two- There is a known phenomena where people will have sex dysphoria very strongly for years, and then shift back to having none (being non-dysphoric about their birth sex) for years. (Which could become a case of having dysphoria towards the sex they transitioned to.) Then they shift back after years, etc. It‚Äôs insanely, extremely rare and controversial (maybe they were never dysphoric and transitioned and acquired actual dysphoria.)\n\nPeople who don‚Äôt give a fuck about their gender- This is a result of cis privilege. Not having think about your gender constantly is a privilege we are in possession of. Trans people have to be aware of their gender constantly- sometimes for safety, sometimes because of dysphoria, sometimes because of the millions of things it takes to transition. Like how white people don‚Äôt have to think about race, cis people don‚Äôt have to think about gender. So it‚Äôs upsetting (and rude!) to call someone a wrong pronoun, even if they don‚Äôt give too many fucks. So stick to whatever you‚Äôre told to use (or, if you use one and no one corrects you, stick to that.)","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"edman93-t-diary","id":96988457044,"post_url":"http://edman93-t-diary.tumblr.com/post/96988457044/sometimes-i-look-back-at-old-photos-in-disbelief","slug":"sometimes-i-look-back-at-old-photos-in-disbelief","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-08 19:01:04 GMT","timestamp":1410202864,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"1wbAtnXB","tags":["ftm","trans","transition","testosterone","transman"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZVY9av1QKzcXK","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":108,"source_url":"http://edman93-t-diary.tumblr.com","source_title":"edman93-t-diary","caption":"Sometimes I look back at old photos in disbelief. In times gone by (and still to this date, at some clinics), healthcare providers have required trans people to navigate ridiculous and unreasonable obstacles before being granted access to treatment. \n\nRequiring stereotypical gender presentation, being ‚Äúout‚Äù to everyone prior to treatment, ‚ÄúReal Life Experience‚Äù (the requirement to change gender presentation prior to treatment, a practice that still exists and puts patients in danger), insistence upon gender-nonconforming career changes, unhelpful mental healthcare and the rejection of patients seen to be ‚Äúnot trans enough‚Äù are just a few of the historical problems with GICs. \n\nIn the past, clinics were places of genuine discrimination based upon gender presentation, and stereotypes and unreasonable gatekeeping were rife. Then you are a fucking idiot. It is in fact that simple. To do that is the height of ignorance and stupidity. If you were to judge an individual on their own behavior (being rude or cruel, kind or caring, accepting and progressive, bigoted or racist) then you are saying ‚ÄúHey person, I don‚Äôt/do like what you‚Äôre doing‚Äù. You cannot EVER apply what SOME people in a group do to the WHOLE GROUP. You cannot hate an entire race because a person of that race treated you badly. You cannot hate an enter gender because someone of that gender treated you badly. You cannot hate an entire religion, faith or belief because someone treated you badly. \n\nAs a trans person, I know how it feels to not quite fit in with the ‚Äúnorm‚Äù (whatever the fuck that even is), but I have never decided that an entire group is against me. Because I‚Äôm not fucking stupid. I take the problems that are faced by trans people as they come. If (hypothetically speaking and because this is what Tumblr seems to get its panties in a knot about the most) a white/cis/male gave me shit, I would be hating on that person, not the entirety of white/cis/males. If you hate on an entire group because of your treatment at the hands of one asshole belonging to that group, guess what, you are the fucking problem, not the group. There are, however, some problems faced by the trans community that are there because of social (again, what even) ‚Äúnorms‚Äù like public restrooms and gender specific areas etc. But you still cannot label everyone you meet that is cis as ‚Äòscum‚Äô because of this.\n\nHating a whole group because of your shitty treatment at the hands of a few is going to have the exact opposite effect if you want their support or acceptance. Rather than waging war on groups of people and generalizing the shit out of them, maybe you should focus on waging war on the assholes who give the groups a bad name.\n\nI cannot believe how many people on this site are so pathetic they can‚Äôt want to be offended and try to start shit. What boring, sad and unfulfilled lives you lead. To hate a group or to generalized a group so completely is exactly what you should be fighting against, not doing yourselves. In your fight against oppression, you have become the oppressors.\n\nAnd as for the privilege argument, to hate someone based on what they were born with is just flat out discrimination. Who the fuck do you think you are to complain that someone is oppressing you just by being born a certain race or gender/sex. You shout for equality, but you don‚Äôt even know the meaning of the word. You don‚Äôt want to be equal to the ‚Äòprivileged scum‚Äô you want to be the privileged scum. You want to reign supreme above the people you hate. You are a fucking idiot. \n\nAnd I would also like to point out that every minute of everyday you are using something that was created by a person from a group you hate. For example all the cis hate on Tumblr, people saying that cis people should all die, BY POSTING ON A SITE CREATED BY A CIS PERSON. \n\nBasically when you discover what equality really means and if you decide that that is what you actually want, then we can talk. An asshole is an asshole regardless or race, sex, gender or religion. If you are not an asshole we should get along 17:23:15 GMT","timestamp":1410196995,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"naQlBQEo","tags":["Anonymous","trans","transgender","bisexual","social justice","panesexual","lgbtqia+","mogai","transphobia","cissexism"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZHQdjr1QKcIs0","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":19,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"I identify as pan. I thought being bi meant you were attracted to those who identify as male or female (I also include trans people in this definition of bisexuality) ? Have I got this wrong? A couple of friends get offended when I mention we should support each other rather then moan because  we both face the same lack of representation, as it suggests we are the same when obviously I'm completely happy to engage in a relationship with cis trans or non binaries lovelies, & they don't","answer":"Nah, bisexual means that you‚Äôre attracted to two or more (or same/other) genders, but not necessarily all genders. So for example you might be attracted to non-binary people and women, and you would be bisexual. Pansexual, in comparison, means that you‚Äôre attracted to all genders. So there is a difference, albeit a fairly subtle one, and there‚Äôs a fair bit of crossover.\n\nThe thing is, a lot of people do use bisexual in a cissexist way (i.e. just male/female), often cutting out non-binary people (or even not recognising binary trans people), but using it that way is transphobic & cissexist.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"rachel-rebellion","id":96981749210,"post_url":"http://rachel-rebellion.tumblr.com/post/96981749210/so-in-the-class-that-i-ta-for-there-is-a-girl-who","slug":"so-in-the-class-that-i-ta-for-there-is-a-girl-who","type":"text","date":"2014-09-08 17:13:14 GMT","timestamp":1410196394,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"z2ODQMOK","tags":["trans","bullying","students","school","thank you","we all have something that can be made fun of"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZgR2tt1QKa0tQ","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"So in the class that I TA for there is a girl who is trans. Then we notice that our spirits still reside within us, and that that essence is pure, and we celebrate the return of our souls into our bodies after that absent time during our slumbers.\n\nEach morning we look out upon the world and offer up gratitude because a day that begins with gratitude is a better day. A day that we transform with words of thanks in turn transforms us into grateful people.\n\nI am so grateful to be among all of you today. \n\nSo I offer you another blessing from the opening prayers of a Jewish morning service:\n\n◊ë÷º÷∏◊®◊ï÷º◊ö÷∞ ◊ê÷∑◊™÷º÷∏◊î ◊ô÷∞◊ô÷∏ ◊ê÷±◊ú÷π◊î÷µ◊ô◊†◊ï÷º ◊û÷∂◊ú÷∂◊ö÷∞ ◊î÷∏◊¢◊ï÷π◊ú÷∏◊ù, ◊©◊Å÷∂◊¢÷∏◊©◊Ç÷∑◊†÷¥◊ô ◊ë÷º÷∞◊¶÷∂◊ú÷∂◊ù ◊ê÷±◊ú÷π◊î÷¥◊ô◊ù\n\nPraised are You, the Infinite source of a miraculous creation, who made me, and all of us, in the divine image.\n\nEach and every one of us here today reflects another gorgeous facet of the image of the divine. appearances.\n\nLet our time together be filled with soulful beauty, and pure diversity, and let us say: Fi"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z9ZQkn1QJQ-pp","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":7,"title":"Everyone knows it's monsters who live in the closet (not that there's any correlation)","body":"[Content note: body horror/cosmic horror, ref. to transphobia]\n\n*\n\nExcerpts from the lives of several people who wish you‚Äôd stop turning it all into a first year writing student‚Äôs allegory.\n\n*\n\nHe was living as a man now. He was definitely living, and he was definitely a man. There were sharp angles casting shadows around his face that spoke to masculinity, and when you laid a hand over his chest there was a pulsing, twisting heartbeat at odds with a staccato drawing of breath. Sometimes the shadows joined in. Definitely living. Definitely a man.\n\n *\n\n<!-- more -->\n\n Anna thought she had two neighbours for the longest time. Brother and sister, perhaps even twins. Perhaps even identical twins, she thought, silently assuring herself she was an open-minded young woman who certainly wouldn‚Äôt ever bring such a thing up.\n\n When she discovered her misunderstanding, she laughed and thought, open-minded, open minded.\n\n \"The whole having two names thing kind of throws people,\" her neighbour says, Jennifer today. Her hair is long and her eyeliner spectacular. Anna would probably at least punch someone for her cheekbones. \"It always ends up like some shitty sitcom.\"\n\n \"It was the hair that threw me,\" Anna says, still laughing. \"I guess it must be a wig?\"\n\n \"Oh, no,\" says Jennifer, looking surprised, \"Hang on. Let me show you.\"\n\n Her face liquifies and rearranges itself, slipping out of reality like running water down a plughole, and Anna thinks blankly- I thought gender fluid was a metaphor.\n\n *\n\n It‚Äôs true she has a girl inside her waiting to get out. It‚Äôs true the girl doesn‚Äôt match her outside body yet, as much as it tries.\n\n Explaining that she‚Äôs actually a girl already regardless of all this, she isn‚Äôt talking about ‚Äúthe surgery‚Äù or HRT or whatever, and that what she actually means is the botched summoning and resulting possession‚Ä¶ is honestly even more inconvenient than the damn thing‚Äôs attempts at taking over her body.\n\n Her teeth keep lengthening and her skin sheds scales sometimes. At least it puts the awkwardness of a second puberty into perspective.\n\n *\n\n People tell hir self determination is important, so zie goes into hir core programming and starts fucking around. Two hours later, zie‚Äôs settled on a wonderful mess of code that doesn‚Äôt have a name and is probably full of glitches, which is marvellous fun; as much as infection and replication. It makes much more sense, zie thinks, than programming hir to be ‚Äòfemale‚Äô, however that concept even translates into someone without a body.\n\n \"Gender is a construct,\" says one young woman, frowning.\n\n \"The building blocks are fun,\" zie agrees serenely, exiting the chatroom before an argument about disassembling the whole idea starts up.\n\n \"You can‚Äôt choose it,\" says one rather more well meaning person, and zie sympathises, but also reminds them that zie is a self-replicating piece of malware and doesn‚Äôt really have to care about things like biological arguments and medical science, what with having access to all hir servers whenever zie wants and no hormones, brain or genitalia.\n\n \"Could you create a subroutine that generates one randomly?\" asks one curious person, and zie considers the question for a brief moment before realising zie isn‚Äôt sure.\n\n \"Let‚Äôs see :)\" zie sends in a PM.\n\n*\n\n[I wanted to write cosmic horror mundanity. I wanted to riff on annoying things trans people deal with. I wanted to riff on the idea ‚Äòmonsters‚Äô and ‚Äòtrans people‚Äô somehow parallel each other as though that isn‚Äôt both silly and gross. I wanted to write trans people. This happened.]\n\nThis piece is by James Elizabeth Cook. Since March, they have toured around four continents in their Pacific Tour, meeting their fans around the world. Since their debut in 2012, although it has only been 2 years, with this momentum, it is as if B.A.P does not know how to stop.\n\nIn their last interview, they said they ‚Äúwanted to create a meaningful concert which has something that remains even when it is over‚Äù (HIMCHAN). After 3 months of the Pacific Tour, what has remained with them?\n\nYOUNGJAE: Really, I think the time spent with meeting the fans was the most precious time. There was an urge to start a tour again as soon as possible, to use our experiences this time as a basis to build upon an even better tour next time.\nYONGGUK: In this tour, we have visited many countries and places that we haven‚Äôt been to before, like Europe, Australia, Chicago and LA in the States - every one of them have left a deep impression!\nZELO: The impressions of fans in different countries are very different. In the States, although we were performing a distance away from the town centre, we were very happy that there were still lots of people who came to cheer for us.\n\nThe last stop of the tour was Japan. The 8500 fans at the final stop in Chiba Messe were very excited.\n\nJONGUP: The cheering from fans has got louder than before, and we could feel that we are having fun together. We were very surprised that the fans stood up and waited before the concert started, and were very touched.\nYOUNGJAE: In the last concert, I went down to the audience seats. Then one fan came and caught me‚Ä¶ (laughs). Although I was happy and laughed at the spot, as there were many people, I was worried about [the fan(s)] being injured. I am glad it did not turn into an accident. It left a big impression.\nHIMCHAN: It is lonely once the tour has ended, and there are fans who feel sad as well. It is overwhelming for me too.\nZELO: I noticed that the age range of fans who enjoy our concerts has widened from previous concerts in Japan. I am surprised that there are also elderlies and families who come to our concerts.\n\nAlthough B.A.P says that it‚Äôs their first time going to lots of places on this tour, when asked about how they spend their time on days other than the concert, it seems that all of them replied with ‚Äúshopping!‚Äù.\n\nDAEHYUN: When speaking of an activity that we all enjoy together, it has to be shopping (laughs). After sight-seeing and taking photos, if there is time left, it‚Äôs mainly shopping.\nYONGGUK: We would all go to shops that we wanted to visit, right? Then we would visit landmarks, and there would also be times when we just drink coffee at a cafe and observe people.\nJONGUP: Also, we would play basketball at the place. In America, we played basketball in a nearby court with the locals. It was a lot of fun (laughs).\n\nHaving grown after a long overseas tour, B.A.P is releasing ‚ÄúEXCUSE ME‚Äù in Japan on 3 September. Having been compiled into their 3rd Korean album ‚ÄúBADMAN‚Äù, it is the Japanese version of a song that has gathered a lot of popularity.\n\nHIMCHAN: Although it‚Äôs originally a Korean song and is now being made into Japanese, I think it‚Äôs been made into a song that is easy for our Japanese fans to sing along together. It‚Äôs a cheerful song, so let‚Äôs enjoy it together!\nYONGGUK: It is a strong hip-hop song that has our colour. It has received a lot of positive response during our tour, so now it has become the title song of our Japanese album. The coupling song ‚ÄúCOFFEE SHOP‚Äù is a bit different from our usual strong style, being a soft jazz. ‚ÄúZERO‚Äù is hip-hop style, but its atmosphere is again different from ‚ÄúEXCUSE ME‚Äù, being more of a ‚Äúprankster‚Äù kind of song.\nDAEHYUN: The song that we would like [you] to listen to in the summer onwards, really, is probably ‚ÄúEXCUSE ME‚Äù. It is the most exciting song, so I recommend it for summer!\n\nIt has been 10 months since your debut in Japan last autumn. To B.A.P what do these 10 months mean?\n\nDAEHYUN: I think these 10 months has been a time for us to experience what we haven‚Äôt experienced before. Being able to finally meet lots of fans, it was precious and meaningful time.\nZELO: I also feel that we have grown bit by bit through tours and concerts. We have visited lots of countries that we haven‚Äôt been to before, and through interacting with fans of different nationalities we have learnt a lot about cultures as well. It was a time when we learned about a lot of different things.\n\nAlthough you‚Äôve been to Japan lots of times, after these 10 months, are there any moments when you have realised some ‚Äúsurprising Japanese culture‚Äù?\n\nHIMCHAN: When we were having an event in Odaiba, there was a huge Gundam! It was very surprising (laughs). I was so surprised, this is what that has left the greatest impression on me (laughs).\nYONGGUK: Croissant taiyaki! (T/N: Taiyaki: a fish-shaped sweet bun with red bean paste filling) It‚Äôs covered with sugar and packed with fillings inside. It was really delicious!\nHIMCHAN: Regarding food, the strangest one are probably Monjyayaki (T/N: a sort of savoury pancake) and Gyutan (T/N: ox tongue) (laughs).\nJONGUP: Ah, gyutan‚Ä¶ When I knew what it really is, there was a weird feelings‚Ä¶ The tongue of a cow‚Ä¶\nALL: (laughs)\nZELO: During the hand-shaking events, I am surprised by the number of fans who cosplayed as me. ‚ÄúNO MERCY‚Äù era and ‚ÄúWarrior‚Äù era when I first debuted were all cosplayed so well, I felt slightly weird as if seeing myself (laughs).\nHIMCHAN: Because Zelo always has a very characteristic style like hair style and outfit, it is always very easy to spot fans who are cosplaying as him.\n\nIt is B.A.P‚Äôs Japan debut first anniversary this October. The anniversary is very soon, and events are being held in September just before. Let‚Äôs hear from the members what they would like to try during their first anniversary.\n\nYOUNGJAE: As it‚Äôs our first anniversary, maybe we can hold a special event. Something like a discussion meeting where fans consult us about their troubles would be great. We would consult them about our troubles too. Then, should we go shopping together? In practice, that would be difficult (laughs).\nHIMCHAN: On our first anniversary, I would like to go to Japan with our members not for work but on private. It will be a secret from the staff (laughs). Going to shopping, sight-seeing and eating delicious food on our own!\nYONGGUK: For me, on a special day like the first anniversary, I would of course like to spend it with fans.\nYOUNGJAE: Then we can celebrate ourselves. It would be great if we can even make couple rings (laughs). Pajama party sounds good too (laughs).\n\nB.A.P runs their daily schedule as one of the groups who strive to reach the top of K-POP. While your private time lessens, if you walk on the streets fans would be drawn and stir things up. If they had a day when they wouldn‚Äôt catch anyone‚Äôs eye, what would they do?\n\nDAEHYUN: I would like to go to the sea and the beach. FRIENDS:\n\nThis is Konner. He‚Äôs one of my best friends in the whole world, and he‚Äôs having a lot of trouble right now. Konner is transgender, and while he has been out to his family for several years now, things have not gotten any better for him at home. Konner is about to start testosterone in the coming weeks, and his father has already told him he will stop supporting him financially as soon as he does. This means that Konner will have to pay for everything, including college, on his own. If he is unable to stay at school, Konner will either have to find a way to afford his own apartment, or live with his parents in an extremely unhealthy and mentally abusive environment. Konner is at the point where he needs to start testosterone for his own health and well-being, no matter what his parents decide to do in response. Female describes an organism that has/had the potential to produce ova, and male describes an organism that has/had the potential to produce sperm. The biological states of either being able to produce sperm or eggs (which exist independent of gender) have become so enmeshed with gender that for many they are inseparable. I think many people would be spared a lot of stress and heartache if the terms female and male were not treated like they are interchangeable with woman and man. Words and language are so (*Ôæü‚àÄÔæü)","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"snowdressedinblack","id":96942304925,"post_url":"http://snowdressedinblack.tumblr.com/post/96942304925/hi-i-seen-you-on-the-crossdiversitycheck-blog-and-was","slug":"hi-i-seen-you-on-the-crossdiversitycheck-blog-and-was","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-08 03:30:00 GMT","timestamp":1410147000,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"dZkQmQhA","tags":["Anonymous","diversitycrosscheck","Trans","Transgender","mtf"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZQ_vdw1QIDYwT","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"hi, i seen you on the crossdiversitycheck blog, and was wondering if you could give me a hand with my trans character? She's 15 in my story, and she stared her transition from male to female at about 13. BUT im not entirely sure how to represent this like she wears makeup and dresses feminine and everything, but like what would she do about her voice and facial hair?","answer":"Hi Anon,\n\nSince I don‚Äôt know anything about your story or the characters background I‚Äôm going to assume they have a supportive family, and everyone (Doctors, therapists etc) is okay with her transition.\n\nSo if she started at 13, she would likely have been put on Testosterone blocking medication to stop puberty happening. Because of this, she would not really have to deal with facial hair. Maybe pluck the rare one that might grow, but nothing major.\n\nAs for the voice, with puberty delayed, I‚Äôm guessing the voice wouldn‚Äôt drop, or drop as much, so would still seem quite feminine.Sorry, I don‚Äôt know too much about this, I transitioned at 25, so my voice has already suffered the effects of Testosterone.\n\nTo sum it all up, your character is a girl who is about the same height as other girls, takes a pill every day or two to block Testosterone, has a feminine voice, and looks and dresses like a girl. She might have to get changed for gym class in private, but aside from that, she is just going to look like another girl.\n\nNext year, when she turns 16 (depending on where the book is set), she will have access to Estrogen or the like, so that she starts to go through puberty as a girl.\n\nI hope this help.\n\nSnow","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"zoe-cat","id":96941922602,"post_url":"http://zoe-cat.tumblr.com/post/96941922602/hormones-day-289-september-7th-2014-month-10","slug":"hormones-day-289-september-7th-2014-month-10","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-08 03:25:40 GMT","timestamp":1410146740,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"CTuoCbjx","tags":["daily selfie","hrt selfies","hrt","hormones","trans","transgender","transition","mtf","trans girl","trans woman","dmab","amab","zoe does Renfest"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZzkJYv1QIC5ag","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":66,"caption":"Hormones: Day 289; September 7th, 2014\n\nMonth 10, Week 42\n\nBody is dead. ‚Äòcould‚Äô have been a great article‚Ä¶ but it has fallen a ‚Äòbit‚Äô short.\n\n________________\n\nFuturist, pharma tycoon, satellite entrepreneur, philosopher. Martine Rothblatt, the highest-paid female executive in America, was born male. But that is far from the thing that defines her. Just ask her wife. Then ask the robot version of her wife.\n\nOnly about 5 percent of the companies in the Fortune 500 are run by women; double the sample size, and the proportion is the same. Compensation levels for female CEOs appear to lag as well, though it‚Äôs hard to tell because there are so few of them. On a recent list of America‚Äôs 200 highest-paid CEOs, only 11 were women, and their median pay was $1.6 million less than their male peers. Certain of these women are already household names: Yahoo‚Äôs Marissa Mayer, No. 34 on the list, who earned $25 million last year, and Hewlett-Packard‚Äôs Meg Whitman, No. 95, who earned $17 million. But the highest-paid female CEO in America is not nearly as well known. She is Martine Rothblatt, the 59-year-old founder of United Therapeutics‚Äîa publicly traded, Silver Spring, Maryland‚Äìbased pharmaceutical company‚Äîwho made a previous fortune as the founder of Sirius Radio, a field she entered as an attorney specializing in the law of space. But what‚Äôs really extraordinary about Rothblatt‚Äôs ascent is not that she has leaned in, or out, or had any particular thoughts about having it all. What sets Rothblatt apart from the other women on the list is that she‚Äîwho earned $38 million last year‚Äîwas born male.\n\n‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like winning the lottery,‚Äù Rothblatt said happily after seeing her name atop the list during one of the meetings I had with her this summer. But Rothblatt could not be less interested in establishing herself as a role model for women. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt claim that what I have achieved is equivalent to what a woman has achieved. For the first half of my life, I was male.‚Äù\n\nIn person, Martine is magnificent, like a tall lanky teenage boy with breasts. She wears no makeup or jewelry, and she inhabits her muted clothing‚Äîjeans, a T-shirt, a floppy button-down thrown on top‚Äîin the youthful, offhand way of the tech elite. Martine is transgender, a power trans, which makes her an even rarer species in the corporate jungle than a female CEO. And she seems genuinely to revel in her self-built in-betweenness. Just after her sex-reassignment surgery, her appearance was more feminine than it is today‚Äîold photos show her wearing lipstick, her long, curly hair loose about her shoulders. But in the years since she has developed her own unisexual style. She is a person for whom gender matters enough to have undergone radical surgery, but not enough to care whether she‚Äôs called he or she by people, like her 83-year-old mother, who occasionally lose track of which pronouns to use.\n\nWhat she prefers to be called is ‚ÄúMartine.‚Äù To her four young grandchildren she is ‚ÄúGrand Martine.‚Äù Bina Aspen, the woman who married Martine 33 years ago, when Martine was a man, and remains her devoted wife, calls herself not straight or gay but ‚ÄúMartine-¬≠sexual‚Äù‚Äîas in the only person she wants to have sex with is Martine. Together Martine and Bina have four children, and they refer to Martine as ‚ÄúMartine‚Äù in conversations with strangers. At home, they call her ‚ÄúDad.‚Äù\n\nIn 1995, just after her transition, Martine published The Apartheid of Sex, a slim manifesto that insisted on an overhaul of ‚Äúdimorphic‚Äù (her word) gender categories. ‚ÄúThere are five billion people in the world and five billion unique sexual identities,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúGenitals are as irrelevant to one‚Äôs role in society as skin tone. Hence, the legal division of people into males and females is as wrong as the legal division of people into black and white races.‚Äù Instead, she suggested people might better express their gender and sexual identities on a spectrum, perhaps in terms of color: Green might be ‚Äúan equally aggressive/nurturing person who does not try to appear sexy‚Äù (lime green would be someone a little less aggressive), and purple might be someone gentle, nourishing, and erotic in equal measure.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"prisonerofthetimewar","id":96938897065,"post_url":"http://prisonerofthetimewar.tumblr.com/post/96938897065/went-home-today","slug":"went-home-today","type":"text","date":"2014-09-08 02:49:52 GMT","timestamp":1410144592,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"8NFnYgVI","tags":["trans","transman","ftm","coming out","help"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-xtkm1QI0Ywf","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"Went home today...","body":"I don‚Äôt even know why I thought going home was a good idea.
